questions.text:
A 32-year-old lady underwent copper-T IUCD insertion 2 months after the delivery of her baby. She has now presented with pain abdomen. The tail of the IUCD is not visible. Her pelvic radiograph is shown below. The most appropriate step in the management of this patient is:

IUCD: Intrauterine contraceptive device
questions.solution:
The given radiograph shows the IUCD outside the uterine cavity, most likely due to perforation. The most appropriate step in the management of this patient is the removal of the IUCD by laparotomy. 

The tail of the IUCD is not visible when the IUCD is misplaced. The reasons for misplaced IUCD include:

  • Enlargement of the uterus due to pregnancy
  • Curling of the threads inside the uterus
  • Perforation of the uterus
  • IUCD buried in the myometrium
  • Spontaneous expulsion

A plain X-ray or pelvic ultrasound is used in the localization of the IUCD when the IUCD threads cannot be visualized. In this patient, the misplaced IUCD is seen laterally displaced in the pelvic cavity. An abnormal location or abnormal shape of IUCD indicates likely perforation of the uterus. 

Perforation can occur either at the time of insertion (immediate traumatic perforation) or due to gradual erosion of the myometrium (secondary perforation). The risk factors for uterine perforation include:

  • Insertion by less experienced clinicians
  • Post-partum insertion (<6 months since delivery)
  • A higher number of previous abortions
  • Lower parity
  • Lactation

Management:

If the location of the IUCD is inside the uterine cavity, it can be removed using Shirodkar's hook (Option A), a curette, or a hysteroscope (option B) and ultrasound guidance.

In perforation of the uterus, a laparotomy is done as copper-T gets adhered to the omentum or gut and will be difficult to be removed using a laparoscope.

Other options:

Option D- Spontaneous expulsion is one of the reasons for misplaced IUCD. It is not a management approach. The factors that are associated with increased risk of spontaneous expulsion of the IUCD are age <20 years and nulliparity. Expulsion tends to occur at the time of menstruation and is associated with cramping, bleeding, and vaginal discharge.

Here the IUCD has caused perforation of the uterus and is lodged outside the uterus, hence, spontaneous expulsion will not be possible.

questions.text: A young man presents with sudden onset nausea, vomiting, and four episodes of passing loose stools. He gives a history of having food from a nearby bakery three hours ago. Which of the following organisms is most likely implicated here?
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario is suggestive of acute food poisoning most likely caused by Staphylococcus aureus. 

Food poisoning by Staphylococcus aureus is caused due to ingestion of preformed enterotoxin. The preformed enterotoxin is heat-stable. Eight antigenic types of enterotoxin are currently known, of which, Type A toxin is responsible for most cases. It contaminates food products such as meat, fish, milk products, mayonnaise, cream pastries, etc. when left at room temperature for a long time.

Enterotoxin acts directly on the autonomic nervous system to cause food poisoning, rather than on the gastrointestinal mucosa. It stimulates the vagus nerve and vomiting center of the brain and also stimulates intestinal peristaltic activity.

Staphylococcal food poisoning has a very short incubation period of about 1 - 8 hours. Patients usually present with nausea, vomiting, and diarrhea 2-6 hrs after the consumption of contaminated food.

Other options:

Option A: Vibrio cholera leads to dysentery that presents with acute, profuse, watery stools (rice water stools) and vomiting which may lead to severe dehydration, hypokalemia, and shock. The incubation period is usually around 1-5 days. 

Option B: Salmonella typhi can present with diarrheal disease along with typical step-ladder patterns of fever, relative bradycardia, malaise, and abdominal discomfort. The incubation period is usually around 7-14 days.

Option C: Infection with Bacillus cereus causes food poisoning with a longer incubation period of 8-16 hours. But patients usually have a history of consumption of fried rice.

questions.text:
A 50-year-old male patient with type 2 diabetes mellitus and hypertension comes for a routine examination. He is on ramipril for hypertension and metformin for diabetes. On evaluation, he is found to have hyperkalemia and acidemia. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

RTA- Renal tubular acidosis
questions.solution:
The most likely diagnosis in this patient is RTA type IV.

The above clinical features of diabetes, angiotensin-converting enzyme inhibitor (ramipril), hyperkalemia, and acidemia are suggestive of type IV renal tubular acidosis. 

Type IV renal tubular acidosis (hyporeninemic hypoaldosteronism) occurs in type 1 or 2 diabetes mellitus. It is more commonly seen in diabetic nephropathy-induced destruction of juxtaglomerular apparatus, drugs like ACEI/ARBs, potassium-sparing diuretics, calcineurin inhibitors, NSAIDs, and heparin.

The clinical features seen in Type IV RTA are as follows:

  • Hyperkalemia: Hypoaldosteronism results in an increase in potassium concentration. 
  • Metabolic acidosis: The important buffers in urine are ammonia and phosphate. Hyperkalemia impairs ammonia production in the proximal tubule, which reduces the buffering of hydrogen ions. This results in decreased hydrogen ion excretion. 
  • Urinary pH<5.5: Due to the decreased production of ammonia in the proximal tubule, excess protons are excreted in the renal tubules, thus decreasing the urinary pH.

Other options:

Option A- RTA type I (distal RTA) is seen in autoimmune diseases like Sjogren's syndrome, systemic lupus erythematosus, systemic sclerosis, medullary sponge kidney disease, cirrhosis, drugs like amphotericin B, lithium, etc. The patients develop hypokalemia and metabolic acidosis with alkaline urine (urinary pH >5.5). 

Option B- RTA type II (proximal RTA) is seen in Fanconi syndrome, Wilson's disease, heavy metals ingestion, etc., The patients develop hypokalemia and metabolic acidosis with acidic urine (urinary pH <5.5). There is also the excretion of glucose, urate, and amino acids.

Option C- RTA type III (mixed RTA) is seen in inherited mutations of carbonic anhydrase II. A combined pathology of type I and type II RTA is seen in this type. It results in hypokalemia and metabolic acidosis.

questions.text: Windkessel effect is seen in:
questions.solution:
The windkessel effect is seen in the large elastic arteries like the aorta.

The elasticity or windkessel effect is the exclusive property of large and elastic vessels like the aorta. These vessels when stretched undergo elastic recoil.

Aorta is stretched during systole, this expansion causes temporary storage of blood so that more blood enters the aorta. This buffer stock of blood is released during diastole, to maintain organ perfusion even during diastole. 

The image given below shows the windkessel effect seen in the aorta.

Proteins responsible for aortic elasticity are elastin and fibrillin. If elastin undergoes mutation it results in supravalvular aortic stenosis as seen in William's syndrome. If fibrillin undergoes mutation it results in dilatation of the aortic root due to cystic medial necrosis as seen in Marfan syndrome.

Aorta has the highest blood flow velocity. Blood flow velocity is inversely proportional to the cross-sectional area of the blood vessel. Therefore, the aorta has the lowest cross-sectional area.

questions.text: A 36-year-old female patient was diagnosed with extensive AIDS-related Kaposi sarcoma and was started on an anticancer drug given intravenously. She had undergone radiotherapy for breast cancer two years back. She now presents with erythema, desquamation, and local skin reaction on the chest area. Identify the given anticancer drug that is responsible for this reaction.
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of radiation recall syndrome and the given anticancer drug is doxorubicin.

In the given clinical scenario, there is the development of local reaction in a previously irradiated area, after 2 years is suggestive of radiation recall syndrome. Intravenous liposomal doxorubicin is used in the treatment of AIDS-related Kaposi sarcoma.

Radiation recall syndrome is an acute inflammatory response confined to the areas that are previously irradiated, which can be triggered by the administration of chemotherapeutic agents. Studies show that the common drugs causing this phenomenon are:

  • Doxorubicin
  • Dactinomycin
  • Docetaxel and paclitaxel
  • Gemcitabine and capecitabine

Radiation sensitization - This is more common than radiation recall. This is a period of enhanced sensitivity in the days after irradiation when the reaction to systemically administered drugs and the time interval between the end of radiation and chemotherapy is <7 days. Such reactions can be considered radiation enhancement or sensitization. 

Radiation recall - This is less common than radiation sensitization. When the time interval between the end of radiation and chemotherapy is >7 days, months, or even years.

The major side effects of doxorubicin are: 

  • The dose-limiting complication is myelosuppression with maximal leukopenia.
  • Stomatitis, mucositis and alopecia.
  • The long-term toxicity is cardiomyopathy.

Note: Cyclophosphamide when given as a combination with 5-Fluorouracil and epirubicin can cause radiation recall syndrome.

A 62-year-old male patient has FBS of 200 mg/dl, PPBS of 432 mg/dl, and HbA1c of 10%. A diabetologist decides to add long-acting insulin into the usual insulin regimen of this patient. Identify the long-acting insulin among the following.

FBS- Fasting blood sugar

PPBS- Post-prandial blood sugar
questions.solution:
Insulin NPH is a long-acting insulin.

  • Long-acting
    • Insulin NPH: 10-16 hours

    • Insulin Glargine: 12-24 hours

questions.text: Transection at level 1 with the cutting of the vagal nerve leads to:
questions.solution:
If the vagal nerve is cut along with transection at level 1 i.e. above the level of the pons, then regular breathing with deep inspiration ensues.

Due to the stretching of the lungs during inspiration, impulses are generated in afferent pulmonary vagal fibres. These impulses inhibit inspiratory discharge. Hence, if vagi are cut, the depth of inspiration increases.

Apneusis will occur if the vagus is cut, along with damage to the pneumotaxic centre (Level 2).

questions.text: A male patient presents with episodic vertigo associated with vomiting, aural fullness, difficulty in hearing, and tinnitus. He does not notice any variation in symptoms with the position. If otoscopic findings are normal, what is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The likely diagnosis is Meniere's disease based on the clinical features given.

Meniere's disease arises due to the distension of the endolymphatic system. This occurs due to increased production or decreased drainage of endolymph. 

It usually affects males between the ages of 35 to 60. Clinical features include episodic vertigo, fluctuating hearing loss, tinnitus, and aural fullness. It is generally a unilateral condition. The symptoms appear in clusters with remission periods lasting from weeks to years. Nystagmus may also be seen during acute attacks. Tumarkin's otolithic crisis is a variant where affected individuals experience sudden drop attacks without loss of consciousness.

Rinne's test is positive and Weber's test shows lateralization to the better ear, suggestive of sensorineural hearing loss. Pure tone audiometry (PTA) also shows sensorineural hearing loss. Initially, the lower frequencies are affected resulting in a 'rising' curve. As the disease progresses, higher frequencies are affected leading to a 'flat' or 'falling' curve. 

General treatment measures include reassurance, smoking cessation, and dietary restriction of salt, coffee, tea, and alcohol. An excessive amount of water intake is also discouraged.

Acute attacks can be treated with bed rest and vestibular sedatives like dimenhydrinate, promethazine theoclate, or prochlorperazine. Chronic cases are managed with vasodilators (betahistine) and diuretics. Repeated intratympanic injection of gentamicin can help 60-80% of patients. 

Surgical procedures can be done if medical management fails. These include decompression of the endolymphatic sac, endolymphatic shunt operation, sacculotomy (Fick's operation), and intermittent low-pressure pulse therapy. Labyrinthectomy is done only when the cochlear function cannot be salvaged.

Other options: 

Option A: Vestibular neuronitis is characterized by sudden onset vertigo lasting from a few days to a few weeks. It is self-limiting and thought to be caused by a viral infection. There is no hearing loss. 

Option B: Suppurative labyrinthitis often occurs secondary to serous labyrinthitis, due to bacterial invasion of the inner ear. It presents with nausea, vomiting, spontaneous nystagmus, and total hearing loss. Affected individuals also suffer from vertigo which resolves in a few weeks.

Option C: Benign paroxysmal positional vertigo (BPPV) is characterized by vertigo when the patient places their head in a critical position. It occurs due to debris present in the semicircular canals. It is not associated with hearing loss and can be treated with Epley's maneuver.

questions.text: A young man met with a road traffic accident and sustains the following injury. Identify the injury in the image below.
questions.solution:
The given image shows an abrasion.

An abrasion is the most superficial of injuries and does not penetrate the full thickness of the epidermis. A pure abrasion does not bleed, as blood vessels are confined to the dermis. However, the dermal papillae are corrugated in nature. Thus, many abrasions enter the dermis and bleeding commonly occurs.

Types of abrasions: 

  • Linear abrasions/ scratches - caused by relative movement of a pointed object on the skin
    • Examples - abrasion caused by nails, thorns, or the point of a sword or knife
  • Grazed/ sliding/ scrapping/ grinding abrasion/ brush burns - caused by relative movement of a rough surface on a wide area of skin. They are the most common type of abrasions
    • Examples - abrasion caused by falls, a victim being dragged on the ground, road traffic accidents
  • Imprint/ patterned abrasions - caused by the impact of a rigid hard rough surface over a localized area of the skin without any movement
    • Examples - abrasion caused by tire, grills, bicycle chain, bite marks
  • Friction/ pressure abrasion - is caused by crushing of the superficial layers of the epidermis
    • Examples - abrasion caused by ligature marks around the neck in hanging

Option B: In laceration tearing of the skin, mucous membrane, muscles or internal organs occurs due to blunt force application. The tissues are crushed and stretched beyond their elasticity limit. 

Option C: A puncture wound is a type of stab wound. It is produced when force is delivered along the long axis of a narrow or pointed object such as a knife, dagger, or sword into the soft tissues of the body. 

Option D: A contusion is characterized by the infiltration of extravasated blood into the subcutaneous and/or subepithelial tissues. It results from the rupture of small blood vessels due to the application of blunt force.

questions.text: A couple comes to a gynecologist to seek a natural method of contraception. The doctor explains Billing’s method of contraception. This method of contraception refers to:
questions.solution:
Billing’s method for contraception refers to the cervical mucus method.

In the mucus method (Billings or ovulation method), the woman predicts the fertile period by feeling the consistency of cervical mucus. Under the influence of estrogen, there is an increased amount of mucus which becomes progressively more slippery and elastic until a peak is reached. Under the influence of progesterone, the mucus becomes scanty, thicker, and dry until the onset of menses.

The days considered safe for intercourse are the dry days, immediately after the menses until mucus is detected. The couple must abstain for four days after the peak day.

The image given below shows mucus secretion during a menstrual cycle:

Other options:

Option A: The symptothermal method employs the combined use of the temperature, cervical mucus, and calendar techniques for identifying the fertile period. The use of multiple methods makes it more effective.

Option C: Also known as the "calendar method", the rhythm method is based on calculating the fertile period of the female. The calculations are as follows :

  • First day of fertile period: Shortest cycle - 18 days
  • Last day of fertile period: Longest cycle - 10 days

Intercourse is then avoided during this fertile period.

Option D: In Coitus interruptus, no costs or appliances are required and is practiced by the withdrawal of the penis right before ejaculation. This prevents the deposition of semen in the vagina. This method of contraception has a high rate of failure (up to 25%) where the major drawbacks are that precoital secretions may contain sperm and that even a drop of semen might be adequate to cause conception. Poorly timed withdrawal might also lead to pregnancy.

questions.text: A 5-year-old boy comes to the emergency department after a fall. On physical examination, there is pain and swelling in the left wrist region. The X-ray of his wrist joint is given below. What is your diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario along with the X-ray showing compression on one side of the radius causing the other side to bend/ buckle suggests a torus fracture.

Torus fracture is also called a buckle fracture. It is caused due to an axial loading force acting along the long axis of a long bone. This results in compression on one side and bending of the other side of the trabecular part of the long bone.

It most commonly occurs at the transition between the metaphysis and diaphysis of the cortex. It is commonly seen occurring at the distal radius in young children. Management includes immobilization and splinting for 3-4 weeks.

The given image indicates the site of the torus fracture:

Greenstick fractures are commonly seen in children. These are incomplete fractures where one side of the cortex is broken but the other side remains intact.

The image given below shows a greenstick fracture:

Related Pearl: Named fractures of the upper limb

Colle's fracture: Extra-articular fracture of the distal radius with dorsal angulation of the distal bone fragment.

 

Galeazzi fracture-dislocation: Fracture of the lower third of the radius and subluxation of the distal radio-ulnar joint.

 

Monteggia fracture-dislocation: Fracture of the shaft of the ulna with dislocation of a proximal radio-ulnar joint.

 

Barton’s fracture: Intra-articular fracture of the distal radius. Barton's fracture can be dorsal or volar (reverse Barton's).

 

Rolando's fracture: Intra-articular comminuted fracture of the base of the first metacarpal with a T or Y configuration.

 

Smith's fracture: Reverse Colles' fracture. Extra-articular fracture of the distal one-third of the radius with palmar or ventral displacement (Image below).

Essex–Lopresti lesion: Fracture of the radial head with disruption of the interosseous membrane and distal radial ulnar joint ligaments.

Nightstick fracture: Isolated fracture of radial or ulnar bone.

questions.text: Which of the following incision is used for a patient undergoing elective cholecystectomy?
questions.solution:
Kocher’s incision is a right subcostal incision, which is commonly used in open cholecystectomy surgeries.

Option B: Chevron (rooftop) incision is a bilateral anterior subcostal incision joined in the midline. It can be used to access the organs of the upper abdomen and diaphragm.

Option C: Rutherford-Morrison’s incision is an oblique muscle-cutting incision, with its lower end over McBurney’s point and extending obliquely upwards and laterally, as necessary.

Option D: McBurney's incision (also called gridiron incision) is an oblique incision(superolateral to inferomedial) passing along McBurney's point. It is popularly used for open appendicectomy.

Below is the image of various abdominal incisions.

  • 1 is Kocher incision - a subcostal incision used to gain access for gall bladder and/or biliary tree pathology.
  • 2 is midline incision - the most common incision for laparotomy, a vertical incision that follows the linea alba which is particularly favored in diagnostic laparotomy, as they allow wide access to most of the abdominal cavity.
  • 3 is McBurney's incision (also called gridiron incision) is an oblique incision (superolateral to inferomedial) passing along McBurney's point. It is popularly used for open appendicectomy.
  • 4 is battle incision a lower right paramedian incision but placed more laterally than the standard paramedian incision. It is suitable for dealing with acute appendicitis and pathologies in the right lower quadrant of the abdomen.
  • 5 is Lanz incision, a transverse or skin crease incision for appendicitis, 2 cm below the umbilicus, centered on the midclavicular–mid-inguinal line. Due to its continuation with Langer’s lines, the Lanz incision produces much more aesthetically pleasing results with reduced scarring.
  • 6 is a paramedian incision - this incision runs 2-5 cm away from the midline used to access much of the lateral viscera, such as the kidneys, spleen, and adrenal glands.
  • 7 is transverse incision - A supraumbilical transverse incision offers excellent exposure to the upper abdomen. A transverse incision may be superior to a midline incision in terms of recovery and complications postoperatively.
  • 8 is Rutherford Morrison incision, an oblique muscle cutting incision used for access to the sigmoid colon and pelvis in patients where the midline is scarred due to previous surgery.
  • 9 is Pfannenstiel incision - an infraumbilical transverse incision in the lower abdomen, often used for gynecological and obstetric procedures.

questions.text: A male patient was posted for abscess drainage from the ischioanal fossa. While draining the abscess, the surgeon injures the nerve present in Alcock's canal. Which nerve is injured in the given scenario?
questions.solution:
The nerve that passes through Alcock's canal and is injured in the given scenario is the pudendal nerve.

Alcock's canal or pudendal canal is an enclosed fascia along the lateral wall of the ischioanal fossa. Its contents include:

  • Internal pudendal artery
  • Internal pudendal vein
  • Pudendal nerve

The pudendal nerve originates from the ventral rami of S2, S3, and S4 of the sacral plexus. It exits out of the pelvis by passing through the greater sciatic foramen. It then enters the perineum below the pelvic floor. 

In the pudendal canal, the pudendal nerve gives off the inferior rectal nerve, perineal nerve, and dorsal nerve of the penis or clitoris.

In females, the pudendal nerve supplies sensory branches to the lower of the vagina. Therefore, in vaginal surgeries, anesthesia can be infiltrated near the ischial spine by a needle passed through the vaginal wall and then guided by a finger.

The image given below shows the contents and boundaries of the ischioanal fossa.


Other options:

Option A: Obturator nerve is formed by ventral divisions of L2, L3, and L4 of the lumbar plexus. It descends within the psoas major and then on the lateral wall of the pelvis before entering the obturator foramen to enter the thigh. It has no branches in the abdomen or pelvis.

Option B: Genitofemoral nerve is formed by the ventral rami of L1, and L2 of the lumbar plexus. It pierces the psoas major and emerges out on the anterior surface. It descends and crosses obliquely behind the ureter and divides into genital and femoral branches.

Option D: Accessory obturator nerve is formed by the L2 and L3 of the lumbar plexus. It runs on the posterior surface of the superior pubic ramus. It supplies the pectineus and hip joint.

Related Pearl: Lumbar Plexus

Lumbar plexus is formed by the divisions of the first four lumbar nerves (L1-L4) and from contributions of the subcostal nerve (T12), which is the last thoracic nerve.

questions.text: A woman underwent transvaginal cerclage under general anesthesia. Propofol was used for induction and succinylcholine was used for anesthesia maintenance. Even after 6 hours after the procedure, there were no signs of neuromuscular function recovery. Later, her dibucaine number was found to be 20. Identify the enzyme defect for the given condition.
questions.solution:
In the given clinical scenario of delayed recovery from a neuromuscular blockade by succinylcholine with dibucaine number 20, the defect is in the butyrylcholinesterase (pseudocholinesterase) enzyme. Dibucaine number 20 is seen in people with homozygous atypical butyrylcholinesterase which prolongs the action of succinylcholine to 4-8 hours. 

Dibucaine number refers to the percentage of inhibition of pseudocholinesterase activity. Dibucaine is a local anesthetic that inhibits normal pseudocholinesterase activity by 80% but inhibits heterozygous atypical enzyme activity by 40-60% and homozygous atypical enzyme activity by only 20%. Accordingly, the patient with normal pseudocholinesterase has a dibucaine number of 80, and the patients with atypical pseudocholinesterase will have a lesser dibucaine number.

Succinylcholine and mivacurium are metabolized by the enzyme pseudocholinesterase. Some conditions like liver disease, pregnancy, advanced age, renal failure, major burns, and oral contraceptives might lead to the minimal prolongation of neuromuscular paralysis.

People with atypical pseudocholinesterase enzyme will have reduced clearance of succinylcholine and mivacurium over time, thus prolonging the recovery time. Patients with one normal and one abnormal pseudocholinesterase gene (heterozygous) will have blockade for 20-30 minutes whereas patients with two abnormal genes (homozygous) can have blockade for up to 4-8 hours. It is treated with continued mechanical ventilation and sedation until the muscle function comes back to normal.

Other options:

Option A- Acetylcholinesterase metabolizes acetylcholine in the synaptic space.

Options B and C- Monoamine oxidase and catechol-O-methyltransferases are the enzymes that metabolize norepinephrine.

Related Pearl: Dibucaine number

  • Low dibucaine number (<30) means the low quantity of normal and high quantity of atypical pseudocholinesterase: prolonged succinylcholine and mivacurium block.

questions.text: A 2-month-old infant is found to be hypotonic. On examination, there is a large anterior fontanelle and hepatomegaly. Further investigations confirmed a diagnosis of the cerebro-hepato-renal syndrome. Which of the following is not a biochemical finding in this case?

choices.text: Elevated levels of very long chain fatty acids

questions.solution:
Cerebrohepatorenal syndrome (Zellweger syndrome) shows a marked reduction of plasmalogens, not elevated plasmalogens.

Plasmalogens belong to a class of glycerophospholipids. They make up about 10 mol percent of total phospholipids. In humans, they are primarily found as membrane structure components. Their synthesis is impaired in Zellweger syndrome. 

Zellweger syndrome is also known as cerebrohepatorenal syndrome. It is caused by mutations in the PEX (Peroxins) family of genes. As a result of this, there is a defective transport of the proteins to the peroxisomes. This results in defective beta-oxidation of very long-chain fatty acids (VLCFA), defective alpha oxidation, and impaired synthesis of bile acids and plasmalogens.

Biochemical findings will show accumulation of very long-chain fatty acids (option A), phytanic acid (option B), abnormalities of the synthesis of bile acids (option C), and marked reduction of plasmalogens.

The child presents with dysmorphic facial features like large anterior fontanelles, hypoplastic supraorbital ridges, micrognathia, and redundant nucha skin folds. Profound developmental delay, profound hypotonia with depressed deep tendon reflexes, neonatal seizures, and impaired hearing are seen. Other observed abnormalities are calcific stippling of the epiphysis, renal cysts, and liver cirrhosis.

There is no appropriate treatment for Zellweger syndrome. It is very severe and infants rarely survive beyond six months of age.

questions.text: You are an intern at a hospital that has adopted Baby-friendly Hospital Initiative (BFHI). This global initiative aims to:
questions.solution:
The Baby-friendly Hospital Initiative (BFHI) is a global initiative that aims to promote breastfeeding. It is sponsored by the World Health Organization and the United Nations Children's Fund.

It recommends 10 steps to successful breastfeeding.

They are split into critical management procedures and key clinical practice. Integration of all these steps ensures good breastfeeding practices. The implementation guidance for BFHI emphasizes the strategies to promote universal coverage and ensure sustainability over time. The guidance focuses on the integration of the programme in the healthcare system and ensures the implementation of these steps in all levels of health facilities in the nation. 

Related Pearl: Baby-friendly hospital initiative (revised 2018)

Ten steps to successful breastfeeding (Revised 2018)

Critical management procedures

1  a. Comply fully with the International Code of Marketing of Breast-milk Substitutes and relevant World Health Assembly resolutions.

    b. Have a written infant feeding policy that is routinely communicated to staff and parents.

    c. Establish ongoing monitoring and data-management systems.

2. Ensure that staff has sufficient knowledge, competence, and skills to support breastfeeding.

Key clinical practices

3. Discuss the importance and management of breastfeeding with pregnant women and their families.

4. Facilitate immediate and uninterrupted skin-to-skin contact and support mothers to initiate breastfeeding as soon as possible after birth.

5. Support mothers to initiate and maintain breastfeeding and manage common difficulties.

6. Do not provide breastfed newborns any food or fluids other than breast milk, unless medically indicated.

7. Enable mothers and their infants to remain together and to practice rooming-in 24 hours a day.

8. Support mothers to recognize and respond to their infants’ cues for feeding.

9. Counsel mothers on the use and risks of feeding bottles, teats, and pacifiers.

10. Coordinate discharge so that parents and their infants have timely access to ongoing support and care.

questions.text: A middle-aged woman with schizoaffective disorder was recently prescribed a different antipsychotic drug instead of the one she was usually taking. She is also on sertraline. She presented a month later, complaining of breast engorgement, galactorrhea, and amenorrhea. Investigations revealed highly elevated prolactin levels. The drug most likely prescribed was?
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario is suggestive of hyperprolactinemia secondary to the use of risperidone, an atypical antipsychotic that can be used in schizoaffective disorder.

The clinical symptoms are indicative of hyperprolactinemia, most likely caused by the dopamine antagonist action of risperidone. Normally, prolactin secretion is inhibited by dopamine. Therefore, drugs that act as dopamine antagonists lead to loss of this inhibitory action and cause hyperprolactinemia. This results in symptoms like breast engorgement, galactorrhea, amenorrhea in women, and infertility in men. 

Risperidone is an atypical antipsychotic indicated in the management of schizophrenia, acute mania or mixed with bipolar disorder, aggressive episodes in autism spectrum disorder, etc. It is an antagonist of the serotonin 5-HT2A, dopamine D2, a1-adrenergic, a2-adrenergic, and histamine H1 receptors.

In schizoaffective disorder, symptoms of mania or depression develop concurrently with the major symptoms of schizophrenia. Thus, they are treated with mood stabilizers for manic episodes (like carbamazepine) or selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors (like sertraline) for depressive episodes. Antipsychotics are prescribed for psychotic symptoms.

In this patient, sertraline was administered along with risperidone. The combined use of risperidone and selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors (as in this patient) can result in a significant elevation of prolactin levels. This is due to the CYP2D6 enzyme inhibitory actions of SSRIs, thereby inhibiting the metabolism of other CYP2D6 substrates. 

This hyperprolactinemia can be rapidly reversed by discontinuing the drug or switching to other low potency/ prolactin sparing (eg. quetiapine) atypical antipsychotics. In case, risperidone needs to be continued, administering bromocriptine can alleviate the symptoms. 

Other options:

Brexpiprazole, clozapine, and aripiprazole are atypical antipsychotics. they do not have any effect on prolactin secretion.

questions.text: A middle-aged male patient presented with complaints of rectal bleeding, diarrhea, and abdominal pain. On examination, an ulcer as shown in the image is noted. Barium enema revealed a hose pipe appearance in the descending and transverse colon. What is the most likely diagnosis in this patient?
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario along with barium enema showing a hose pipe appearance (lead pipe appearance) in the descending and transverse colon, and the image showing pyoderma gangrenosum are suggestive of ulcerative colitis.

Ulcerative colitis is an inflammatory bowel disease resulting in superficial erosions confined to the mucosa and submucosa of the colon. It starts from the rectum and extends proximally in a continuous manner.

Clinically, patients present with abdominal pain, bloody diarrhea with mucus, and tenesmus. Other symptoms like anorexia, nausea, vomiting, fever, and weight loss are also present.

Extraintestinal manifestations associated with IBD include ocular features (episcleritis, and uveitis), dermatological manifestations (erythema nodosum, pyoderma gangrenosum), rheumatological (arthropathies, sacroiliitis, ankylosing spondylitis) and primary sclerosing cholangitis.

The diagnosis of ulcerative colitis is made by colonoscopy which pseudopolyps, granularity, friability, and ulceration involving the distal rectum, extending proximally in symmetric, continuous, and circumferential patterns called backwash ileitis.

Barium contrast enema shows a hose pipe appearance characterized by a smooth-walled and cylindrical colon with complete loss of haustrations. Fecal calprotectin and fecal lactoferrin levels will be elevated.

Severe attacks of ulcerative colitis may result in toxic megacolon, colonic perforation, and colon cancer.

Other options:

Option A: Crohn's disease is an inflammatory bowel disease that shows string sign of Kantor on barium enema as shown below:

 

Option C: Colon carcinoma typically arises in patients above the age group of 50 years. change in bowel habits or rectal bleeding in cases of left-sided colon tumors, and iron deficiency anemia or a mass in proximal lesions of the colon. Double-contrast barium enema shows Apple-core sign is typically seen in carcinoma colon as seen in the image below. It appears as short irregular stenosis with sharp shoulders at either end (yellow arrows):

 

Option D: Diverticulosis is seen in the age group of more than 50 years. The majority of the patients with diverticulosis are usually asymptomatic. However, some patients may present with abdominal cramps, altered bowel habits, and painless rectal bleeding.

Colonic diverticulosis gives a saw-tooth appearance on the barium enema as shown below:

questions.text: A female patient presents to you with complaints of itching, pain, and foul-smelling watery discharge from her right ear. Otoscopy shows a black filamentous growth. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The likely diagnosis based on the clinical scenario is otomycosis. 

Otomycosis is a fungal infection of the external ear caused commonly by Aspergillus niger, A.fumigatus, or Candida albicans. It is frequently seen in tropical areas and in individuals who use antibiotic drops to treat otitis media/ otitis externa.

Patients present with intense pruritus, discomfort, pain, blocked sensation in the ear, and foul-smelling watery discharge. Otoscopy will show a fungal mass whose appearance depends on the causative organism. Aspergillus niger can be seen as a black-headed, filamentous growth. Aspergillus fumigatus presents as a pale blue or green mass. Candida appears as a white, creamy mass in the ear.

Aural toileting and topical antifungal agents are the primary treatment. Nystatin, clotrimazole, and povidone-iodine are the commonly used antifungals. 2% salicylic acid in alcohol works as a keratolytic to remove the superficial layers of the epidermis along with the fungal mycelia.

Other options:

Option B: Diffuse otitis externa occurs due to bacterial infection of the external ear. It presents as severe pain worsening with jaw movement, discharge of purulent material, and conductive hearing loss. In the chronic phase, meatal skin can undergo scaling and fissuring. 

Option C: Otitis externa hemorrhagica is probably viral in origin. It presents with severe pain and blood-stained discharge due to rupture of hemorrhagic bullae on the tympanic membrane and meatus.

Option D: Malignant otitis externa occurs due to infection by pseudomonas commonly in diabetics and patients with immunosuppression. Symptoms are similar to otitis externa but examination will reveal granulations in the external auditory canal. It can cause facial nerve paralysis and has a high tendency to spread.

questions.text: A 19-year-old girl presents to the gynecology outpatient department with complaints of scanty episodes of bleeding but is regularly timed. This menstrual cycle irregularity is called _____.
questions.solution:
Hypomenorrhea refers to regularly timed but scanty episodes of bleeding.

Menstrual cycle irregularities definitions:

  • Menometrorrhagia refers to excessive, prolonged bleeding that occurs at irregularly timed and frequent intervals.
  • Metrorrhagia refers to irregularly timed episodes of bleeding superimposed on normal cyclical bleeding.
  • Oligomenorrhea denotes infrequent, irregularly timed episodes of bleeding usually occurring at intervals of more than 35 days.
  • Amenorrhea indicates the absence of menstruation. 
  • Polymenorrhea denotes frequent episodes of menstruation, usually occurring at intervals of 21 days or less. 
  • Menorrhagia denotes regularly timed episodes of bleeding that are excessive in amount (>80 mL) and/or duration of flow (>7 days). 
  • Intermenstrual bleeding refers to bleeding (usually not excessive) that occurs between otherwise normal menstrual cycles.
  • Precocious menstruation denotes the occurrence of menstruation before the age of 10 years.
  • Postcoital bleeding denotes vaginal bleeding after sexual intercourse.

questions.text: A patient who underwent parathyroidectomy developed hypocalcemia, hypophosphatemia, hypomagnesemia, and hyperkalemia in the postoperative period. What is the likely diagnosis of this patient?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of hungry bone syndrome i.e. hypocalcemia post parathyroidectomy. Acute symptomatic presentation of hypocalcemia is treated with IV calcium gluconate.

In patients with hyperparathyroidism, there is an increased bone breakdown. When a patient’s parathyroid hormone level drops acutely after surgery, a stimulus to break down bone is removed. The bones are now “hungry” for calcium, removing calcium from the plasma rapidly.

It usually occurs after parathyroidectomy; thyroidectomy for toxic thyroid; prostate cancer patients on estrogen therapy. Sudden cessation of existing increased bone breakdown makes bones to absorb calcium, magnesium, and phosphorus rapidly.  Hypocalcemia, hypophosphatemia, hypomagnesemia, and hyperkalemia are four typical features in these patients. Estimation and correction of all these four factors are essential. ECG changes can occur. Hyperkalaemia should be treated judicially. Magnesium infusion is needed.

There is an unusually high need for calcium, with a low calcium excretion in the urine. Supplementation of vitamin D and elemental calcium is needed during discharge for 6 months. Postoperatively they need calcitriol (gradually increased to 16 mg in 1 month, then gradually reduced) with 2 gm calcium supplement. Monitoring is done by evaluating serum calcium, albumin, magnesium, phosphorus, and bone-specific alkaline phosphatase.

Other options:

Persistent HPT (serum calcium does not normalize immediately after surgery leading to total failure) or recurrent HPT (serum calcium after surgery becomes normal but in 6-12 months, it again increases) are other rare complications of parathyroidectomy.

Hypoparathyroidism with severe hypocalcemia is a problem when all glands are removed with bilateral neck exploration.

questions.text: A 35-year-old man with suspected poisoning was brought to the casualty by his friends. On examination, the finding shown below is seen. Which of the following is the likely poisoning in this case?
questions.solution:
The above image shows a carpopedal spasm which is seen in hypocalcemia. Oxalic acid poisoning is associated with hypocalcemia.

In oxalic acid poisoning, those who survive for a few hours develop hypocalcemia, because oxalic acid readily combines with the calcium ion in the body tissues and forms calcium oxalate.

The features of oxalic acid poisoning include tenderness in the epigastrium, nausea, followed by coffee ground-colored vomitus, severe thirst, diarrhea, electrolyte imbalance, and death.

Acute features of oxalic acid poisoning are mainly due to hypocalcemia such as: 

  • Muscle irritability
  • Tenderness
  • Tetany
  • Convulsions
  • Tingling of extremities
  • Coma
  • Collapse and death

Delayed features of oxalic acid poisoning include uremia. Urine is scanty with traces of albumin, blood, and calcium oxalate crystals (seen microscopically as envelope-shaped crystals). Large doses of oxalic acid cause shock and lead to death. 

Antidotes: Lime water, calcium lactate, calcium gluconate, calcium chloride, and chalk suspension in water or milk may be given orally, and act as specific antidotes, which form insoluble calcium oxalate and are excreted easily.

Medicolegal importance: Oxalic acid is used to erase writing in attempts at forgery.

Oxalic acid Same as other strong acids, but also scavenges calcium ions, leading to hypocalcemia and Calcium oxalate renal stones.  Coagulation necrosis

questions.text: A target group is being tested by three screening tests for breast cancer as a part of a research program. The patient is considered diseased if she tests positive in all of the screening tests. Which of the following is false about this combination of screening tests?
questions.solution:
In the given scenario where the patient is considered diseased only if she is positive on all three tests, the combination of screening tests is said to be in series. The false statement is that it has high sensitivity. The net sensitivity is low for a screening test conducted in series.

The combination of two or more tests performed together can help to enhance the efficacy of detecting the presence or absence of disease. There are two principal forms of combination of tests:

Screening tests used in series:

  • If a patient is considered to have a disease when he is positive by every test conducted, then the tests are said to be in series.
  • If the patient tests negative in any one or more of the tests, they are classified as non-diseased.
  • It is thus difficult to classify a patient as diseased and easier to classify a patient as non-diseased.
  • With a decrease in sensitivity, there is an increase in the number of false negatives. This higher number of false negatives lowers the sensitivity.

Screening tests used in parallel:

  • If a patient is considered to have a disease when he is positive by any one or more tests, then the tests are said to be in parallel.  
  • Only if the patient tests negative on all the tests, they are classified as non-diseased.
  • Hence, some without disease are more likely to be wrongly classified into the diseased group, but many without disease are correctly excluded.

Sensitivity is the ability of the test to correctly identify all individuals with the disease. It corresponds to the true positive cases out of a total diseased population.

Specificity is the ability of a test to correctly identify all individuals without the disease. It corresponds to the true-negative cases out of a total disease-free population.

The predictive tests are indicative of the validity of the tests and reflect the diagnostic value. A positive predictive value refers to the cases truly positive for the disease out of the total positive cases. A negative predictive value refers to the cases truly negative for the disease out of the total negative cases. 

Related Pearl: Validity of a Screening Test

  • Validity/ accuracy of a screening test depends upon the sensitivity, specificity, and predictive accuracy of the test.
  • It represents the closeness to a true value/ actual value.
  • These are the inherent properties of a screening test.
  • PPV and NPV are dependent on the Prevalence of disease.
  • Sensitivity & Specificity are independent of prevalence of disease.

questions.text: A 55-year-old woman presented with gait disturbance. On examination, the Romberg test was positive, and pupillary reflex was absent. Past history is significant for untreated painless genital ulcer. Which of the following investigations would be the best in this case?

choices.text: FTA-ABS- fluorescent treponemal antibody absorption test

questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario is suggestive of tertiary syphilis/ neurosyphilis. Venereal disease research laboratory (VDRL) test of cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) would be the best investigation as the diagnosis is neurosyphilis.

Tertiary syphilis occurs months to years after infection with Treponema pallidum. Patients usually present with the following clinical findings:

  • Gummas: It is the most common manifestation. These are the granulomas involving the skin, bones (perforated nasal septum), liver, and spleen.
  • Cardiovascular manifestations occur due to end arteritis of the vasa vasorum supplying the aorta. This results in aortitis, aortic regurgitation, and aortic aneurysm.
  • Neurosyphilis
    • End arteritis of cerebral vessels results in meningovascular syphilis. Patients present with symptoms of cerebral infarcts like aphasia, hemiparesis, and visual loss.
    • The actual destruction of neurons by the treponemes results in:
      • Tabes dorsalis affect the dorsal column of the spinal cord. Bowel and bladder disturbances, foot slap, impotence, ataxia, loss of position, and vibration sense, resulting in a positive Romberg test.
      • Involvement of neurons of the cerebral cortex results in Argyll-Robertson pupil (reacts to accommodation but not to light), illusions, delusions, hallucinations, slurring of speech, and reduced memory.

The CSF VDRL test is considered diagnostic of neurosyphilis. It has high specificity.

Aqueous crystalline penicillin G or aqueous procaine penicillin G is used for the treatment of neurosyphilis.

Related Pearl: Stages of syphilis

Primary syphilis:

  • Chancre - Painless, indurated, usually single. The chancre self heals in 1-4 months.
  • Lymphadenopathy - Painless, unilateral or bilateral, shotty and rubbery inguinal nodes
  • Dory flop sign - As the chancre is too hard to fold, it will flip over once the prepuce is retracted back.

Secondary syphilis:

  • A & B: Generalized non-itchy rash with no vesicles present on the palm and sole. This is the most common lesion.
  • C & D: Condyloma lata.
  • E: Moth-eaten non-scarring alopecia
  • F: Mucous patches are flat erosions on the tongue that can coalesce to form snail track ulcers. These are the most infectious lesions.
  • G: Pigmentary plaques
  • H: Psoriasiform syphilitic lesions
  • Generalized diffuse non-tender lymphadenopathy

Tertiary syphilis:

  • Gummatous syphilis are deep punched-out ulcers, with gum-like secretions on the floor
  • Pseudo-chancre redux is a gumma occurring at the site of a previously healed ulcer  
  • CVS - Aortitis and aneurysm of the ascending aorta
  • CNS - General paresis of the insane and tabes dorsalis 

Latent syphilis is the period between secondary and tertiary syphilis. In this period the patient is asymptomatic clinically and only serological evidence of the infection is present. It is classified into:

  • Early latent syphilis - Within 1 year of infection
  • Late latent syphilis - After 1 year of infection

Related Pearl: Syphilis - Diagnostic Serology

Nontreponemal tests (VDRL, RPR)

VDRL- Venereal disease Research Laboratory test

RPR- Rapid Plasma Reagin test

  • Quantitative tests(titres)
  • Reagin antibody tests; based on cardiolipin antigen
  • VDRL can be used to test CSF whereas RPR cannot be used
  • RPR does not require preheating of serum unlike VDRL
  • VDRL requires light microscope for interpretation whereas RPR can be read macroscopically
  • Decrease in titers confirms treatment
  • Sensitivity of RPR(86%)>VDRL(76%) in primary syphilis

Treponemal Tests

FTA-ABS- Fluorescent Treponemal Antibody Absorption test

TPI-Treponema pallidum immobilization test

TPPA-Treponema pallidum particle agglutination assay

TPHA-Treponema pallidum haemagglutination test

EIA-Enzyme-linked ImmunoAssay

  • Detect antibody to treponemal antigens
  • Qualitative tests
  • Greater sensitivity in early infection
  • Positive even after treatment hence cannot be used to detect reinfection.
  • First test to be positive: FTA-ABS
  • Most specific: TPHA,TPPA, EIA

questions.solution:
Berger's disease (IgA nephropathy) is associated with focal mesangial proliferative glomerulonephritis (MPGN) on light microscopy.

IgA nephropathy is the most common type of glomerulonephritis in the world which is characterized by the deposition of IgA molecules in the mesangial regions.

On histological examination, there is glomerular mesangial widening and endocapillary proliferation (mesangioproliferative glomerulonephritis), or segmental proliferation localised to some glomeruli (focal proliferative glomerulonephritis). Crescentic glomerulonephritis may be rarely seen.

A light microscopy image of MPGN is shown below:

The below image is an immunofluorescence study of IgA nephropathy showing the characteristic IgA deposition in the mesangial regions.

Clinically, children and young adults present with symptoms of hematuria (gross or microscopic) with an antecedent history of upper respiratory tract infection and mild proteinuria. The progression of the disease is slow and variable. There may be heavy proteinuria, hypertension and chronic renal failure in severe cases. 

The systemic variant of IgA nephropathy is called Henoch–Schönlein purpura. It is a disorder of children which presents with similar renal manifestations with characteristic IgA deposits in the mesangium in about one-third of the patients. 

The disease is treated with ACE inhibitors and ARBs to control high blood pressure and proteinuria. If ineffective, corticosteroids and immunosuppressants may be added. Tonsillectomy is done as a part of management in some countries. However, it is not recommended to perform tonsillectomy in a case without significant tonsillitis and associated IgA nephropathy.

questions.text: Which of the following amino acids will have the maximum buffering capacity at physiological pH?
questions.solution:
Histidine has the maximum buffering capacity at physiological pH.

Histidine has a pKa value of 6.5-7.4 (due to the imidazole group), which is close to the physiological pH of the blood and is maintained in the range of 7.35 -7.45.

The maximum buffering capacity of an amino acid is when the pH=pKa. Therefore, at physiological pH, the buffering action in the blood is caused by histidine.

questions.text: A 1-year-old boy presents with shortness of breath and bluish discoloration of lips. Chest X-ray shows a boot-shaped heart due to an upturned cardiac apex. The finding seen on the chest X-ray is due to:
questions.solution:
The clinical description of shortness of breath and bluish discoloration of lips, along with boot-shaped heart on chest X-ray, suggests tetralogy of Fallot (TOF). The findings of a boot-shaped heart due to the upturned cardiac apex is due to right ventricular hypertrophy.

Tetralogy of Fallot (TOF) is a cyanotic congenital heart condition. The four cardinal features of the tetralogy of Fallot are as follows:

  • Ventricular septal defect (VSD)
  • Obstruction of the right ventricular outflow tract (subpulmonary stenosis)
  • An aorta that overrides the ventricular septum
  • Right ventricular hypertrophy

The image given below shows cardinal features seen in TOF:

 

Children with TOF usually present with dyspnea on exertion, they characteristically assume a squatting position for relief of dyspnea. During anoxic spells, children start crying, become dyspneic and cyanotic, and may eventually lose consciousness. 

A chest x-ray of a child with TOF typically shows a boot-shaped heart due to the upturned cardiac apex. This is mainly because of right ventricular hypertrophy. Other chest x-ray features in tetralogy of Fallot are:

  • Pulmonary oligaemia (due to pulmonary stenosis)
  • Normal size heart (heart failure is not a feature in TOF)
  • Right-sided aortic arch (25%)

Medical management with oral propranolol prevents cyanotic spells, surgical correction is the definitive treatment of choice. The intravenous administration of prostaglandin E1 can be tried to keep ductus arteriosus open while awaiting surgery.

Given below is a chest x-ray showing a boot-shaped heart (cœur en sabot in French).

questions.text: Which of the following structures is related to the area marked as A in the given image below?
questions.solution:
The cadaveric image shown is of the left lung. The arch of aorta is related to the area marked as A in the given image. 

The left lung is divided into superior and inferior lobes by the oblique fissure. The pulmonary root connects the medial surface of the lung to the heart and trachea. It is formed by structures that enter or leave the hilum. The left root is present inferior to the arch of the aorta.

The vertical sequence of structures at the left hilum from above to below is:

  • Pulmonary artery
  • Principal (hyparterial) bronchus, and
  • Inferior pulmonary vein

The arrangement of the lung hilar structures from the anterior to posterior in the order is:

  • Pulmonary vein
  • Pulmonary artery
  • Primary bronchus
  • Bronchial artery

The cadaveric image given below shows the structures related to the hilum of the left lung.

The cadaveric image given below shows the structures related to the hilum of the right lung.

  • Posterior to this groove-  azygous vein.
  • Behind the hilum and pulmonary ligament- oesophagus.
  • The cardiac impression - right auricle, right atrium and right ventricle
  • Posteroinferiorly - inferior vena cava

Left lung:

questions.text: A 12-year-old boy had persistent headaches,  gait disturbances and cognitive difficulties. CT scan revealed a cystic mass in the right cerebellar hemisphere which was resected. The biopsy of the specimen showed cells with long, hairlike processes that stained positive for glial fibrillary acidic protein (GFAP). What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical features and histopathological findings showing cells with long hair-like processes positive for GFAP are suggestive of pilocytic astrocytoma.

Pilocytic astrocytoma is a benign (grade I) astrocytoma that typi­cally occurs in children and young adults. It is usually located in the cerebellum, optic nerves, brainstem and occasionally in the cerebral hemispheres.

Clinically, any brain tumour can present with some general symptoms like headaches, gait disturbances, and cognitive and personality changes. These symptoms may be a result of increased intracranial pressure due to tumour enlargement or edema which may result in hydrocephalus. Seizures usually occur in cases of metastasis. 

The imaging method of choice is cranial MRI with gadolinium contrast administration. It reveals a cystic and well-demarcated mass. The tumour is composed of bipolar cells with long, thin hair-like processes that are glial fibrillary acidic protein (GFAP)-positive and form dense fibrillary meshwork. Rosenthal fibres (eosinophilic corkscrew-shaped inclusions) and eosinophilic granular bodies (mulberry-like inclusions) are characteristic findings. It has biphasic architecture, with both loose microcystic and compact fibrillary areas.

These tumours grow very slowly with limited brain invasion and can be treated by resection alone. The image below shows the histopathology of pilocytic astrocytoma, with characteristic bipolar cells with long hair-like processes.

 

Other options:

  • Option B: Hemangioblastoma is a fluid-filled cystic lesion that typically arises in the cerebellum and in the retina. It may be associated with polycythemia and von Hippel-Lindau disease.
  • Option C: Medulloblastoma is a malignant embryonal tumour occurring exclusively in the cerebellum. Rapid growth may occlude the flow of CSF, leading to hydrocephalus.
  • Option D: Ependymoma arises in proximity to the ependyma-lined ventricular system, typically on the floor of the fourth ventricle. 

Related Pearl: Histological Features of CNS Tumors

Pilocytic Astrocytomas:

  • Biphasic architecture - loose microcystic component and dense fibrillary areas
  • Bipolar cells (tumor cells): thin, long hairlike processes that are GFAP - positive. 
  • Rosenthal fibers: eosinophilic corkscrew - shaped inclusions
  • Eosinophilic granular bodies: mulberry - like inclusions 

 

Medulloblastoma:

  • Very densely cellular, with sheets of small primitive appearing small blue cells
  • Individual tumor cells have scant cytoplasm and hyperchromatic nuclei that are frequently elongated or crescent-shaped
  • Tumor cells form Homer - Wright rosettes (pseudorosettes) with a central neuropil

 

Ependymoma:

  • Ependymal rosettes: gland - like round or elongated structures that resemble the embryologic ependymal canal, with long, delicate processes extending into the lumen 
  • Perivascular pseudorosettes: perivascular nuclear - free zone consisting of thin ependymal processes radiating toward the central blood vessel

 

Oligodendroglioma:

  • Fried - egg appearance: sheets of regular cells with spherical nuclei containing finely granular chromatin (similar to normal oligodendrocytes) surrounded by a clear halo of vacuolated cytoplasm. 
  • Chicken - wire capillaries: a delicate network of anastomosing capillaries

 

Retinoblastoma: 

  • Composed of collections of small, round cells with hyperchromatic nuclei
  • Flexner - Wintersteiner rosettes: arrangements of a single layer of tumor cells around an apparent lumen
  • Homer - Wright rosettes: a ring of cells with an eosinophilic fibrillary center
  • Fleurettes: retinoblastoma cells that have undergone greater photoreceptor differentiation and group together as a bouquet. Fleurettes lack mitosis or necrosis.

Related Pearl: Most commons of Brain tumours

Most common tumor of the brain - Metastasis secondary to lungs > breast

Most common primary CNS tumor - glioma > meningioma

Most common primary CNS tumor in children - pilocytic astrocytoma

Most common primary CNS tumor in adults - astrocytoma

Most common primary malignant tumor of the brain in children - medulloblastoma

Most common primary malignant tumor of the brain in adults - glioblastoma

questions.text: A baby born to a mother with MEN 2 syndrome was found to have a high risk RET gene mutation. At what age should the child undergo prophylactic thyroidectomy?
questions.solution:
In patients with high-risk RET mutation (exon 918), prophylactic thyroidectomy is recommended at 1 year of age as there is a 100% chance of developing medullary thyroid carcinoma.

For any patients with MEN2 syndrome, 1st-degree relatives are screened for RET mutation.

  • Low risk (exon 768,790) - prophylactic thyroidectomy at 20 years of age
  • Medium risk (exon 618,634) - prophylactic thyroidectomy at 5-6 years of age
  • High risk (exon 918) - prophylactic thyroidectomy at 1 year of life
 

Related Pearl: MEN 2 Syndrome Features

MEN 2A

  • Known as Sipple’s syndrome
  • Chromosome 10 / RET gene
  • Associated conditions are:
    • Medullary Thyroid Carcinoma (90%)
    • Pheochromocytoma (>50%)
    • Parathyroid adenoma (10–25%)

MEN 2B

  • Known commonly as MEN 3
  • Chromosome 10/ RET gene
  • Associated conditions are:
    • Medullary Thyroid Carcinoma (>90%)
    • Pheochromocytoma (>50%)
    • Other associated abnormalities include: (40–50%)
      • Mucosal neuromas
      • Marfanoid habitus
      • Medullated corneal nerve fibers
      • Megacolon

questions.text: The arthropod shown in the image is a vector for all of the following except:
questions.solution:
The arthropod shown in the image is a rat flea which is the vector for all the above diseases except relapsing fever which is transmitted by soft ticks.

Rat fleas are vectors for:

  • Endemic typhus
  • Bubonic plague
  • Hymenolepis diminuta

Fleas transmit these diseases through the bite of a blocked flea, defecation, or direct mechanical transmission. Control of the disease is done by using insecticides such as 10% DDT, repellents like diethyltoluamide, and rodent control.

Bubonic plague is caused by Yersinia pestis through the bite of infected rat flea and presents as inguinal buboes. Other types of plague include pneumonic and septicemic plague which are less common than bubonic plague.

Related Pearl: Rat Fleas

  • Rat fleas (Xenopsylla cheopis) belong to the genus Xenopsylla.
  • Their morphology includes a conical head, absent neck, a thorax with 3 segments, and an abdomen with 10 segments. They have three pairs of legs and no wings.
  • The four stages in their life cycle are egg, larva, pupa, and adult.
  • They cannot fly but can leap up to 6 inches horizontally.
  • They transmit diseases by biting, mechanical transmission, and feces.
  • Flea indices that are used in flea surveys are the general flea index, specific flea index, percentage incidence of flea species, and rodent infestation rate.
  • Rat fleas are vectors for endemic typhus (murine typhus), chiggerosis, bubonic plague, and Hymenolepis diminuta.
  • Insecticidal control is mainly by 10% DDT.
  • Resistance to DDT, gamma-HCH, and dieldrin has been recorded.
  • Repellants like diethyltoluamide and benzyl benzoate are efficient.
  • Rodent control also aims to reduce flea infestation.

questions.text: A 30-year-old G3P2 woman was admitted to the labor room. You were asked to perform a vaginal examination and calculate the modified Bishop's score. Which among the following parameter is not used in this score?
questions.solution:
Cervical effacement % is not used in the calculation of the modified Bishop score. It has been replaced with cervical length.

The Bishop score is a cervical scoring system used to assess the induction of labor. The parameters calculated include:

  • Cervical length (effacement in the original score): The length of the cer­vical canal reflects the degree of cervical effacement
  • Cervical position: It refers to the relation­ship of the cervical os to the fetal head.
    • It can be posterior, mid-position, or anterior.
  • Cervical dilatation: It is determined by estimating the average diameter of the cervical opening. The cervix is said to be fully dilated at 10 cm.
  • Consistency of the cervix: Maybe soft, firm, or inter­mediate between these two.
  • Station of the head: It refers to the level of the presenting fetal part in the birth canal concerning the ischial spines. Each fifth represents 1 cm above or below the spines.
    • As the presenting fetal part descends from the inlet toward the ischial spines, the designation is -5,
      -4, -3, -2, -1, 0 stations till the ischial spines.
    • Past the ischial spines, it is +1, +2, +3, +4, and +5 sta­tions to delivery.
    • Station +5 cm indicates that the fetal head is visible at the introitus.

These parameters are noted while doing a vaginal examination. The maximum attainable score is 13. A Bishops score >=9 indicates a high likelihood for successful induction of labor. A score <=6 is considered unfavorable.

  • According to NICE guidelines, a score of 6-13 is favorable for induction of labour.
  • According to Williams Obstetrics (26th edition), a score of 9 or more indicates a high likelihood of successful induction.

questions.text: A 30-year-old diabetic man presented with the following lesions over his shins. The lesion had initially started off as small, firm brown papules which later enlarged to plaques and showed a positive Koebner's response. Which of the following is true about this condition?

choices.text: Lesions are highly pruritic and tender
Skin biopsy is indicated in all cases
Squamous cell carcinoma is a commonly seen complication

questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario is suggestive of necrobiosis lipoidica. Ulceration is a common complication associated with this.

Necrobiosis lipoidica diabeticorum (NLD), a rare, chronic, granulomatous skin disorder commonly associated with diabetes mellitus. It is more frequently seen in females and is thought to be related to microangiopathy, where small blood vessels are damaged, leading to skin changes.

NLD typically starts as red or brown papules that progressively enlarge into well-demarcated patches or plaques. These lesions often have an atrophic, yellowish-brown center with elevated borders and can be slightly depressed in the middle. Most lesions are found on the shins (over the tibiae), but they can also occur elsewhere on the body. The lesions are generally asymptomatic but can become painful if ulceration occurs(Option B). Lesions may either resolve spontaneously or become chronic and persistent, increasing the risk of complications like ulceration.

NLD can often be diagnosed based on its clinical appearance alone, and a skin biopsy is typically not necessary unless the presentation is atypical or there is concern about other conditions. (Option C)

Common complications include ulceration especially in long standing lesions. It usually occurs later in the disease course and is often triggered by trauma. Squamous Cell Carcinoma can occur in chronic non healing ulcer but it is a rare complication. (Option D)

Treatment is usually not required for most cases. However, if lesions are bothersome, treatment options include topical steroids, topical tacrolimus, or PUVA therapy (psoralen plus ultraviolet A), although the effectiveness of these treatments is variable.

questions.text: A young man presented with chronic cough and evening rise in body temperature. He has a history of decreased appetite and weight loss. On examination, a mass is found in the right iliac fossa. A barium meal follow-through image of the patient is given below. Which of the following radiological findings is not seen in this condition?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario and the barium meal follow-through study showing conical caecum, narrowing of the terminal ileum, and proximal ileal dilation are suggestive of ileocaecal tuberculosis. The radiological finding not seen in ileocecal tuberculosis is the apple-core sign. Apple-core or napkin-ring sign is typically seen in carcinoma colon as seen in the image below. It appears as short irregular stenosis with sharp shoulders at either end (yellow arrows).

 

Intestinal tuberculosis is an infection caused by Mycobacterium tuberculosis. Patients typically present with cough, evening rise in temperature, weight loss, malaise, abdominal pain with distension, and intermittent diarrhea. On palpation, the abdomen feels doughy and a mass may be palpated in the right iliac fossa. The ileocaecal junction is the most common site of tuberculosis in the gastrointestinal tract. Other sites involved in the abdomen are the proximal colon and peritoneum.

Barium meal follow-through study findings in ileocaecal tuberculosis include:

  • Fleischner sign- narrow ileum with the thickened ileocecal valve
  • The ileocaecal angle becomes obtuse
  • Caecum appears pulled up and hepatic flexure is pulled down
  • Contracted conical caecum
  • Gooseneck deformity - due to contracted, and pulled-up cecum as well as straightening of the terminal ileum
  • String sign - due to persistently narrowed intestinal segment due to inflammation

The image below shows the findings seen in ileocaecal tuberculosis:

  • Yellow arrow- shrunken conical caecum
  • Red arrow- strictures narrowing of the terminal ileum and ileocaecal junction
  • Blue arrow- proximal ileal dilation

Related Pearl: Barium studies in GI tuberculosis

  • Earliest feature is spasm and hypermotility, with edema of the valve.
  • Thickening of the valve lips, with narrowing of the terminal ileum: Fleischner or inverted umbrella sign is characteristic of TB.
  • In advance disease, the characteristic deformity includes symmetric, annular, napkin-ring stenosis and obstruction or shortening and pouch formation.
  • The cecum is shrunken and retracts out of the iliac fossa due to contraction of the mesocolon: Pulled-up cecum
  • Loss of ileocecal angle with dilated terminal ileum: Gooseneck deformity
  • Narrowing of the terminal ileum due to irritability, along with shortened rigid cecum: Sterlein sign
  • Persistent narrow stream of barium in the bowel indicates stenosis: String sign

questions.text: Tuberculous pleural effusion is characterized by all except:
questions.solution:
Tuberculous pleural effusion is characterized by all the above-mentioned features except for high mesothelial cell count. 

Mesothelial cells are the cells that line the pleural membranes. Their count is increased in pleural fluid usually in transudative effusions. Tuberculous effusion is exudative, mesothelial cells are not increased in this condition.

Tuberculous pleural effusion is an exudative pleural effusion. It is caused due to hypersensitivity to tuberculous proteins.

Pleural fluid in tuberculosis has a high protein concentration (>50 %), normal to low glucose concentration, pH ~7.3, and detectable white blood cells. It is usually straw-colored but can be hemorrhagic in some cases. Exudative effusions like the tuberculous effusion have a pleural fluid LDH/serum LDH ratio of >0.6.

Pleural fluid has increased levels of TB markers such as adenosine deaminase (> 40 IU/L) and interferon γ (> 140 pg/mL).

 

The illustration below shows the steps involved in the insertion of the chest drain which is used for the management of various pleural effusions.

questions.text: A patient firmly believes that his wife has been replaced by a body double with completely identical characteristics. What is the term used to describe this particular delusion?
questions.solution:
In the given scenario the patient firmly believes that his wife has been replaced by a body double with completely identical characteristics. The term used to describe this particular delusion is Capgras syndrome.

Capgras syndrome is a type of delusion of misidentification. In this syndrome, the patients believe that a familiar person or significant other has been replaced by an imposter.

Delusions are firm, false beliefs that persist despite the presence of objective evidence and clear demonstration of their falsity.

Other options:

Option A: Folie a deux is a mental illness where two individuals share a common delusion. They may be a spouse, a child, or any other household member. 

Option C: Persecution is a delusion wherein the patient believes that plans are being made to harm them by close relatives such as a spouse, children, or parents. This delusion may lead the person to harm themselves or the alleged family members.

Option D: Fregoli syndrome is a disorder in which a person holds a delusional belief that different people are in fact a single person who changes his or her appearance or is in disguise.

Related Pearl: Types of delusions

THE TYPES OF DELUSIONS

Delusion of control

False belief that a person’s will, thoughts, or feelings are being controlled by external forces.

Delusion of grandeur or Megalomania 

Exaggerated conception of one’s importance, power, or identity.

Delusion of infidelity or morbid jealousy or Othello syndrome

False belief that one’s lover is unfaithful. Sometimes called pathological jealousy.

Delusion of love or erotomania

False belief that another person is in love with them. In De Clerambault syndrome, the woman believes that a man, frequently older and of higher status, is in love with her.

Delusion of misidentification 

Capgras syndrome: Belief that a familiar person has been replaced by an exact double i.e. an impostor.

Fregoli syndrome: Person holds a delusional belief that different people are in fact a single person who changes his or her appearance or is in disguise.

Nihilistic delusion 

False belief that oneself, others or the world, is non-existent or about to end. When nihilistic delusion is accompanied by ideas concerning bodily function failure e.g. putrefaction of intestine etc, it is called Cotard syndrome.

Delusion of infestation 

False belief that one is infested with small but visible organisms. As a monosymptomatic delusional disorder, this is called Ekbom syndrome. 

Delusion of persecution

The most common delusion. False belief of being harassed or persecuted.

Delusion of poverty

The person strongly believes they are financially incapacitated.

Delusion of reference

False belief that the behavior of others has a particular and unusual significance, usually of a negative nature. The person may falsely feel that others are talking about them (e.g. the people on television are talking to or about the person).  

Delusion of self-accusation

False feeling of remorse and guilt. Seen in depression with psychotic features.

questions.text: A 45-year-old, chronic alcoholic male developed dyspnoea, fever, and hypotension after being administered 2 units of fresh frozen plasma. Oxygen saturation of 88% and bilateral lung infiltrates were seen in the chest x-ray. He was diagnosed to have a Transfusion Related Acute Lung Injury (TRALI). What is the duration within which TRALI occurs after a transfusion?
questions.solution:
Transfusion-related acute lung injury(TRALI) occurs during or within 6 hours of transfusion.

TRALI is a sudden onset of respiratory failure resulting from the transfusion of donor fresh frozen plasma and platelets that contain high-titer of anti-HLA antibodies. These antibodies bind recipient leukocytes and aggregate in the pulmonary vasculature, releasing mediators that increase capillary permeability. 

The pathogenesis involves a two-hit hypothesis:

  • Priming event - increased sequestration and sensitization of neutrophils in the microvasculature of the lung
  • Second hit - the aggravating factor (most commonly MHC class II  antibodies) present in the transfused blood product activates the primed neutrophils

TRALI is a severe fatal complication of blood transfusion. The implicated donors are frequently multiparous women. Recipients with a history of pre-existing lung diseases, smoking, chronic alcohol use, mechanical ventilation and cancer surgeries are at increased risk of developing TRALI. 

The recipient develops symptoms of hypotension, fever, hypoxia and signs of noncardiogenic pulmonary edema, including bilateral interstitial infiltrates visible on the chest X-ray.

Treatment is supportive, and patients usually recover without sequelae. The incidence of TRALI has been reduced by choosing males and nulliparous women as donors.

questions.text: A young man presents with diarrhea and abdominal pain. There is a rash around his neck as shown in the image below. He follows a maize-based diet. Which of the following is measured for the diagnosis of his condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario along with the image showing Casal’s necklace around the neck is suggestive of pellagra (niacin or vitamin B3 deficiency). 2-methyl nicotinamide is measured for the diagnosis of this condition. 

Niacin is a nutrient that is synthesized in the body from tryptophan. The term niacin represents two compounds nicotinic acid and nicotinamide. It acts as a precursor for the coenzymes NAD and NADP, which are important in various oxidation and reduction reactions.

Niacin deficiency causes pellagra. It is usually seen in individuals with a corn/ maize-based staple diet, a history of alcohol consumption, Hartnup disease, and carcinoid syndrome. 

The primary manifestations of pellagra are often referred to as the 4 Ds: diarrhea, dermatitis, dementia, leading to death. Other manifestations include: 

  • Abdominal pain, loss of appetite
  • Bright red glossitis
  • Generalized weakness, irritability
  • Casal’s necklace - pigmented scaly skin rash around the neck.

It is diagnosed by measuring urinary levels of 2-methyl nicotinamide and 2-pyridone. Treatment is oral supplementation of 100–200 mg of nicotinamide or nicotinic acid three times daily for 5 days.

Other options:

Options B and C: Red blood cell or urinary riboflavin concentrations and RBC glutathione reductase activity measurement are used in the laboratory diagnosis of riboflavin deficiency (vitamin B2 deficiency).

Option D: Functional enzymatic assay of transketolase activity measured before and after the addition of thiamine pyrophosphate is used to diagnose thiamine deficiency (vitamin B1 deficiency).
