questions.text: A patient underwent resection and anastomosis of the small bowel. Following this, he developed an enterocutaneous fistula.  All of the following conditions can prevent spontaneous closure of this fistula, except:

choices.text: Foreign body in the fistula tract

questions.solution:
High volume output fistulas of >500ml/day prevent the spontaneous closure of an enterocutaneous fistula.

An enterocutaneous fistula is an abnormal connection between the small bowel and the skin. It most often occurs due to an iatrogenic cause such as a laceration of the bowel by wire mesh or sutures, anastomotic leak, erosion by suction catheter, etc. 

The majority of these fistulae heal spontaneously, however, there are a few factors that can prevent spontaneous closure of them. 

Factors preventing spontaneous fistula closure:

  • High output fistula (>500 mL/24 hr)
  • Severe disruption of intestinal continuity (>50% of bowel circumference)
  • Active inflammatory bowel disease of bowel segment
  • Cancer
  • Radiation enteritis
  • Distal obstruction
  • Undrained abscess cavity
  • Foreign body in the fistula tract
  • Fistula tract <2.5 cm long
  • Epithelialization of the fistula tract

questions.text: A 35-year-old man has come with complaints of hair loss. On examination, findings as shown in the image below are seen. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Short, easily extractable broken hairs, known as exclamation mark hairs, are seen in the trichoscopy image above, and the scalp image below shows circumscribed, hairless, smooth patch. This is characteristic of alopecia areata.

Alopecia areata is a chronic inflammatory disease that causes non-scarring hair loss. It is a T-cell mediated inflammatory disease. It is associated with several autoimmune diseases including thyroiditis, lupus erythematosus, vitiligo, and psoriasis. It mainly affects the scalp, but can also affect the beard, eyebrows, and eyelashes. In some cases, this progresses to a total loss of scalp hair (alopecia totalis) or a loss of all hair on the body (alopecia universalis).

The lesions of alopecia areata are characterized by a smooth circumscribed patch of alopecia. It affects pigmented hair and spares white hair. It can cause fine stippled pitting of the nails and roughening of the nail bed, which is called trachyonychia. Histopathology will show perifollicular and intrafollicular T-lymphocyte infiltration.

Spontaneous remission occurs in a majority of the patients. Topical steroids like clobetasol can be useful in patchy alopecia areata. Intralesional steroids are the most effective treatment for patchy alopecia areata. A depot steroid-like triamcinolone administered by fine-needle injection into the upper subcutis can stimulate hair growth at the site. Multiple injections are usually required.

Severe and long-standing alopecia areata requires oral corticosteroids.

Other options - 

Option A: Tinea capitis is the ringworm of the scalp. The appearance may vary from a dull grey, broken‐off hairs with a little scaling to a severe, painful, inflammatory mass covering the entire scalp. Predominantly seen in children, however, adults can also be affected due to infection by T.tonsurans.

The image below shows tinea capitis.

 

Option B: Telogen effluvium can occur 2-3 months after systemic stress such as surgery or illness, but it causes diffuse hair loss, not patchy as in this patient.

The image below shows a patient with telogen effluvium.

 

Option D: Trichotillomania is a behavioral disorder characterized by compulsive pulling of hair. It presents as an area of patchy hair loss, often in a bizarre pattern. The hairs are often twisted and broken at various distances from the scalp or may be present as a uniform, coarse stubble. The scalp skin appears normal. Sites other than the scalp can also be affected, for example- eyelashes, eyebrows, beard, mons pubis, and perianal region.

The image below shows a patient with trichotillomania.

questions.text: A chi-square test contingency table has 5 rows and 4 columns. What would be the degree of freedom in this case?
questions.solution:
The degrees of freedom in this case would be 12.

A chi-square contingency table has one variable in rows and another in columns. In such cases, the degrees of freedom (df) = (r-1) (c-1), where r is the number of rows and c is the number of columns.

As the above contingency table has 5 rows and 4 columns, the degree of freedom in this case is given as:

df = (5 – 1) (4 – 1) = 12

The degree of freedom is an expression of sample size for t tables. df is given as n-1, where n refers to the sample size.

Related Pearl: Degrees of Freedom

  • In general, degrees of freedom (df) is equal to the number of values minus the numbers of parameters estimated on the way to the obtaining a particular estimate. For example, if we want to estimate the variance between the heights of two people A and B, we would use the values of 2 heights to estimate 1 parameter. Thus, the degrees of freedom in this case would be 2 – 1 = 1.
  • For a Chi-square contingency table, the df = (r-1) (c-1), where r is the number of rows and c is the number of columns.

questions.text: An elderly male came with complaints of severe pain over the metatarsophalangeal joint of the first toe. The pain begins at night following the consumption of alcohol. Synovial fluid aspirate showed the following crystals under polarised light microscopy as shown below. What does the image show?
questions.solution:
The given scenario of an elderly male with pain in the metatarsophalangeal joint of the first toe precipitated by alcohol intake and the image is highly suggestive of gout. The polarized light microscopy image shows negatively birefringent monosodium urate crystals.

Gout is a metabolic disease that is characterized by the deposition of monosodium urate crystals in joints and connective tissue.

It is more common in males. It is precipitated by alcohol intake, purine-rich food, diuretic therapy, trauma, and medical conditions such as heart failure and hypoxia.

It usually presents as monoarthritis that may be acute and episodic or chronic. Acute gout presents with a joint that is red, hot, swollen, and extremely tender on examination. The metatarsophalangeal joint of the great toe is the most frequently involved joint.

The image given below shows clinical findings seen in gout:

 

Synovial fluid analysis of joint aspirate is diagnostic and shows the following features:

  • Increased leukocyte count with a neutrophilic predominance
  • Negatively birefringent crystals on polarized light microscopy of the synovial fluid.

Radiographic features may be appreciable in advanced gout which includes Martel's sign also known as the G sign, or rat-bite erosion. It refers to the punched-out lytic lesion and overhanging margin of the new bone along the edge of erosion seen in chronic tophaceous gout.

Acute gout can be managed with non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs), colchicine, and corticosteroids while urate-lowering therapy is useful in chronic gout.

questions.text: An elderly patient was brought to the emergency room with a severe headache. On examination, his blood pressure was 180/100 mmHg. CT scan of the brain showed bleeding in the globus pallidus. Which of the following will be seen in this patient?

choices.text: Slow writhing movement involving distal joints
Unilateral violent movement of large proximal joints
Semi purposeful, rapid jerky movements of proximal muscles and face
Spasmodic jerky contraction of groups of muscles

questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario is suggestive of intracerebral bleed into globus pallidus secondary to hypertension. This results in damage to the globus pallidus resulting in athetosis, which is described as slow writhing movement involving distal joints.

The most common site of hypertensive bleed in the brain is basal ganglia and putamen. Patients typically present with severe headache. The most common cause of intracerebral hemorrhages is hypertension.

Following are the usual locations of ICH:

  •   Thalamic hemorrhage
  •   Pontine hemorrhage
  •   Cerebellar hemorrhage

questions.text: During a thyroidectomy, the surgeon accidentally damages the nerve marked in the image below. Which of the following is true about the postoperative course in this patient?

choices.text: Initial hoarseness in voice which may improve with time

questions.solution:
The structure marked in the above image is the left recurrent laryngeal nerve. Unilateral recurrent laryngeal nerve paralysis will lead to initial hoarseness of voice, which may improve with time.

Recurrent laryngeal nerve paralysis can be unilateral or bilateral. Unilateral palsy is more common on the left side because of the long course of the nerve. They are more commonly injured during thyroid surgeries, neck trauma, thyroid disease, and bronchogenic carcinoma.

The recurrent laryngeal nerve supplies all the muscles of the larynx except for the cricothyroid. Therefore, in unilateral recurrent laryngeal nerve palsy, these muscles are paralysed. The affected vocal cord lies in the paramedian position (option B).

Postoperatively, the injury can go unnoticed, or the patient may complain of mild hoarseness in the voice. This hoarseness is because the paralysed muscle cannot close the glottis during phonation.

Hoarseness might improve over time because the unaffected muscle compensates and closes the glottis by hyperadduction of the cord. The patient will not have difficulty in breathing or stridor (option C).

Generally, no treatment is required (option A). Laryngoplasty type I is needed if there is no compensation from the normal muscle.

In bilateral recurrent laryngeal nerve palsy, both the vocal cords are paralysed and assume the paramedian position. Because the vocal cords are close to the midline, the phonation can be normal. However, since these vocal cords cannot abduct, the patients will have stridor and breathing difficulty. This condition requires an emergency tracheostomy to maintain the patient's airway.

questions.text: A middle-aged chronic alcoholic man presents with complaints of swelling over the abdomen as seen in the image below. Ultrasound of the abdomen shows shrunken liver. The blood flow in these veins is away from the umbilicus. The cause of the distended veins seen in this patient is:
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of alcohol-associated cirrhosis of the liver. The clinical finding of dilated veins, as seen in the image is known as caput-medusae which occurs due to portal hypertension.

Caput medusae refer to the dilated superficial veins that are present around the umbilicus. It is one of the major sites of portocaval anastomoses in portal hypertension, where these anastomoses open up to form dilated veins radiating from the umbilicus.

Portal hypertension is characterized by an elevated hepatic venous pressure gradient. The usual complications of portal hypertension are esophageal varices with variceal bleeding, hypersplenism (splenomegaly), and ascites.

The most common cause of portal hypertension is liver cirrhosis. Liver cirrhosis causes increased resistance to blood flow within the liver resulting in elevated portal pressure.

Clinically, patients with alcoholic liver disease present with jaundice, ascites, palmar erythema, spider naevi, finger clubbing, asterixis, gynecomastia, and Dupuytren's contracture.

The illustrated image given below shows caput medusae around the umbilicus:

 

Other options:

Option B: Hypoalbuminemia in liver cirrhosis causes ascites due to reduced oncotic pressure and leukonychia (white discoloration of nails). The image given below shows leukonychia.

 

Option C: Inferior vena cava obstruction can occur secondary to deep venous thrombosis, malignancy, pregnancy, or infection. Patients usually present with symptoms of decreased venous return such as fatigue, dizziness, and shortness of breath.

questions.text:
The antiviral agent that is active against all herpes viruses and HIV is

HIV - Human immunodeficiency virus
questions.solution:
Foscarnet is the antiviral agent that is active against all herpes viruses and HIV.

Foscarnet is an inorganic pyrophosphate analog. It does not require activation by viral thymidine kinase for antiviral activity. It inhibits viral nucleic acid synthesis by directly inhibiting HSV DNA polymerase and HIV reverse transcriptase.

Foscarnet is used to treat acyclovir-resistant herpes simplex virus (genital herpes) and varicella-zoster virus infections and ganciclovir-resistant cytomegalovirus (CMV) infections. It is also used as an alternative agent in CMV retinitis in AIDS, and CMV viremia in bone marrow transplant recipients.

Common side effects of foscarnet include nephrotoxicity and hypocalcemia.

Foscarnet is mainly excreted by the kidneys. Therefore, dose reduction is necessary for renal impairment to avoid the accumulation of the drug and associated toxicity.

Other options:

Option B: Trifluridine is a pyrimidine antimetabolite antiviral drug. It acts against herpes simplex virus -1, 2, and CMV. It is approved for use in herpes simplex keratitis.

Option C: Acyclovir is active against herpes simplex virus -1, 2, varicella-zoster virus, Ebstein Barr virus, and partially against CMV. It is useful against a variety of herpes simplex infections like genital herpes, mucocutaneous herpes, herpes simplex encephalitis, keratitis, and chickenpox.

Option D: Famcyclovir is active against herpes simplex and herpes zoster virus. It is used as a second-line agent for genital or orolabial herpes.

questions.text: A researcher is studying the relationship between the occurrence of cancer and pollution levels in their environment. He chose a district with a large number of factories and collected data on cancer in the native population from the district hospitals and the local health centers. What is this type of study known as?
questions.solution:
The study described in the given scenario considers the district population as the unit of study. Therefore, it is an ecological study.

The ecological study is a type of analytical study which analyzes the health status and its relation with other variables. It is also called correlational study and it uses population as a unit of study.

Other options:

Case-control and cohort studies are also types of analytical studies, but they use individuals as the unit of study. In a case-control study, the study begins from the outcome and goes retrospectively to find out the exposure among the cases and controls. A cohort study involves a follow-up of a cohort (a group of people) with risk factors to check if they develop an outcome or disease. 

Experimental studies or interventional studies try to change the determinant or progress of the disease and use the people as the study unit. It includes randomized controlled trials and field and community trials.

Related Pearl: Types of Epidemiological Study Designs

Types of Epidemiological Study Designs

The flow chart below gives a glance into the types of epidemiological study designs and where they are generally used.

Note: Descripitve study is used to formulate aetiological hypothesis of a disease. Whereas analytical study is used to test the hypothesis (i.e to accept or reject the hypothesis).

Related Pearl: Case Control Study

In a case-control study, progression is from effect (disease) to cause (exposure) as the outcome or disease has already occurred. It is also called a retrospective study.

Design of case-control study:

 

  • Steps of case control study:
    • Selection of cases and controls
    • Matching
    • Measurement of exposure
    • Analysis in the form of exposure rates, risk ratio, and odds ratio
  • Advantages of case control study:
    • Easy to carry out, rapid and inexpensive
    • Requires few subjects, no risk to subjects
    • Used to investigate rare diseases
    • Different etiological factors can be studied and risk factors can be identified
    • No attrition problems, minimal ethical problems
  • Disadvantages of case control study:
    • Relies on memory or past records giving rise to bias
    • Selection of appropriate control groups is difficult
    • Incidence cannot be measured
    • Does not distinguish between causes and associated factors
    • Not suited for evaluation of therapy or prophylaxis
    • Representativeness of the cases and controls is often inadequate

Related Pearl: Cohort Study

  • A cohort study progresses from cause (exposure) to effect (disease).
  • It is also known as forward-looking study, incidence study, prospective study, and longitudinal study.
  • Design of a cohort study:
    • Types of cohort study:
      • Prospective (concurrent) cohort studies
      • Retrospective (historical) cohort studies
      • Combination cohort studies
    • Steps of cohort study:
      • Selection of study subjects
      • Obtaining data on exposure
      • Selection of comparison groups
      • Follow-up
      • Analysis in terms of incidence rates and estimation of risk
    • Advantages of cohort study:
      • Incidence can be calculated
      • Several possible outcomes related to exposure can be studied at the same time
      • Provides direct estimate of relative risk
      • Calculation of dose-response ratio
      • Minimization of certain biases
    • Disadvantages of cohort study:
      • Cannot use for uncommon diseases
      • Expensive, requires a large population and longer time
      • Many common administrative and ethical problems
      • High attrition and selection of subjects is difficult
      • Dynamism of diagnostics is difficult to incorporate
      • Tends to alter the behaviour of subjects known as Hawthorne effect.

questions.text: A 58-year-old woman presented with complaints of abdominal discomfort and dark-coloured stools for the past 2 months. Investigations revealed microcytic hypochromic anemia. A barium swallow radiograph revealed a leather bottle appearance on the stomach. Histopathological examination showed diffuse infiltration of the stomach wall and cells with a signet ring appearance. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
In this clinical scenario with leather bottle appearance of the stomach in barium swallow and the signet ring cells in histopathology, the most likely diagnosis is diffuse gastric adenocarcinoma.

Gastric adenocarcinoma is an epithelial tumour and comprises more than 90% of all stomach malignancies.

Patients with gastric cancer present with unexplained weight loss, abdominal discomfort, upper GI bleeding (hematemesis and melena), anemia, early satiety and anorexia. Based on the gross appearance, it is classified into two types:

  • Diffuse: characterized by gastric wall thickening due to infiltrates
  • Intestinal: associated with malignant masses composed of glandular structures

Diffuse adenocarcinoma is characterised by a diffuse infiltrative growth pattern leading to the thickened stomach wall with diffuse rugal flattening. Barium studies reveal a leather bottle appearance as shown in the image below, also known as linitis plastica.

Most gastric cancers do not follow any pattern of hereditary inheritance. However, loss-of-function mutation of the CDH-1 gene results in the loss of E-cadherin which plays a vital role in the pathogenesis of diffuse gastric cancer. Mutation of TP53 is found in a majority of sporadic gastric cancers of both diffuse and intestinal types.

Histopathology shows diffuse infiltration of the gastric wall with signet ring-shaped cells. The cells are so named because intracellular mucin displaces the nuclei to the periphery of the tumour cells. 

The below H&E-stained image shows normal gastric mucosa (red arrow) and the characteristic signet cells (green arrows) in a patient with diffuse gastric adenocarcinoma.

The most effective predictors of the prognosis of gastric cancer are the depth of tumour invasion and metastasis.

Surgical resection and lymph node clearance is the mainstay treatment in early gastric cancers. When there is local invasion into the duodenum, pancreas, and retroperitoneum, treatment is focused on chemotherapy, radiotherapy and palliative care.

Other options:

Menetrier's disease is a hypertrophic gastropathy characterized by massive overgrowth of mucous cells (foveolar cells) lining the stomach, resulting in large gastric folds with antral sparing. It is associated with hypoproteinemia, weight loss and diarrhoea and an increased risk of gastric adenocarcinoma.

Gastric leiomyosarcoma is a type of mesenchymal tumour commonly grouped under GIST(gastrointestinal stromal tumour) and is named according to its resemblance with smooth muscle tumours and usually positive for CD117(c-kit) in immunohistochemistry. The patients present with mucosal bleeding, anaemia and mass effects.

Gastric lymphomas are extranodal B cell lymphomas arising in cases of chronic gastritis and are positive for CD19, CD20 and CD43. Patients present with upper GI bleeding and dyspepsia due to H.pylori infection.

questions.text: Which of the following would you prescribe for a patient with tropical sprue?
questions.solution:
The treatment of tropical sprue is tetracycline + folic acid.

Because of marked folate deficiency, folic acid is most often given together with broad spectrum antibiotics for up to 6 months.

questions.text: A hypertensive patient with congestive cardiac failure develops sudden onset skin rashes, tongue swelling, and stridor. He had taken a newly prescribed tablet today morning. Which medication is most likely to have caused this?
questions.solution:
The given clinical vignette points to a diagnosis of drug-induced angioedema. The drug most likely to have caused this is an angiotensin-converting enzyme (ACE) inhibitor like captopril. 

ACE inhibitors can cause angioedema in a small group which presents as swelling of the throat, mouth, tongue, and glottis. It is usually self-limiting once the drug is discontinued. Glucocorticoids, antihistamines, or epinephrine can be given if required. 

Other adverse effects include hypotension, dry cough, hyperkalemia, and skin rashes. In patients with bilateral renal artery stenosis, it can precipitate acute renal failure.  A rarer complication is visceral angioedema marked by vomiting, diarrhea, and abdominal pain. It is a known teratogen and needs to be replaced with other drugs during pregnancy/ birth control measures should be advised.

These drugs are inhibitors of the renin-angiotensin system and are commonly used in hypertension, left ventricular systolic dysfunction, and acute myocardial infarction. 

Other options:

Option A: Propranolol is a nonselective beta-receptor antagonist. Side effects include bronchospasm, depression, and insomnia. It is not recommended for diabetics as it can mask hypoglycemic symptoms.

Option C: Hydrochlorothiazide, a thiazide diuretic can cause hypotension, hypokalemia, and hyponatremia.

Option D: Clonidine is an alpha-2 adrenergic agonist which can cause dry mouth, sedation, and sexual dysfunction.

questions.text: Which is the most abundant form of collagen in the dermis?
questions.solution:
Type-I collagen is the predominant type of collagen present in the dermis accounting for approximately 80% of the collagen in the dermis.

Dermis forms the major part of human skin and extends from lamina densa above to the subcutis below. It is highly vascular, largely acellular, and primarily consists of the extracellular matrix of connective tissue.

The four main classes of extracellular components present in the dermis are as follows:

  • Collagen fibers to provide tensile strength (most abundant)
  • Elastic structures to provide resilience like elastin
  • Non-collagenous glycoproteins like fibrillins that facilitate cell-matrix interactions
  • Proteoglycan molecules like hyaluronic acid, dermatan sulfate, and chondroitin sulfate

questions.text: A patient who underwent septoplasty, complains of pressure over the nose and difficulty in breathing on postoperative day 1. Local examination revealed smooth, round, soft, and fluctuant swellings on either side of the septum. What is the next best step in the management of this patient?
questions.solution:
The next best step in the management of this patient with clinical features suggestive of septal hematoma is incision and drainage. 

Septal hematoma refers to a collection of blood under the perichondrium or periosteum of the nasal septum. It may be caused due to trauma, septal surgery (as in this patient), or spontaneously in bleeding disorders.

Patients usually present with bilateral nasal obstruction, pressure over the nasal bridge, or a frontal headache. On examination, smooth, round swellings, soft and fluctuant on palpation, can be seen on either side of the septum.

All septal hematomas must be drained to prevent the formation of septal abscess or fibrosis leading to a permanently thickened septum. A small anteroposterior incision is made parallel to the nasal floor. It must be followed by nasal packing. Smaller hematomas can be aspirated using a wide gauge needle. Patients should thereafter be started on systemic antibiotics to prevent abscess formation.

Related Pearl: Septal Haematoma

  • Septal hematoma is a collection of blood under the perichondrium or periosteum of the nasal septum
  • Causes: Trauma, septal surgery and bleeding disorders
  • Clinical features: Bilateral nasal obstruction (most common presenting feature), frontal headache
  • Treatment:
    • Aspiration of small hematomas
    • Incision and drainage of large hematomas followed by nasal packing
    • Systemic antibiotics to prevent abscess formation
  • Complications: Septal abscess, depression of dorsum, permanently thickened septum

questions.text: A middle-aged woman comes to your clinic due to recurrent episodes of cough productive of large amounts of sputum for 2 years. She is a non-smoker. Lung examination reveals wheezes with crackles bilaterally. A transverse section of the CT lung is given in the image below. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario of repeated chest infections with the presence of large amounts of sputum in a non-smoker point to the diagnosis of bronchiectasis. The CT scan showing the signet ring sign is specific for bronchiectasis.

Bronchiectasis refers to the irreversible dilatation of bronchi due to recurrent cycles of infection, inflammation, and tissue damage. Development of the disease requires an infectious insult in combination with impaired bacterial clearance (eg, impaired immune defenses, structural airway defect).

Bronchiectasis is commonly associated with Kartagener syndrome, cystic fibrosis, and allergic bronchopulmonary aspergillosis.

Clinically, patients present with persistent productive cough and production of thick tenacious sputum. On examination, there will be clubbing, wheeze, and crackles.

A chest X-ray shows tram track appearance due to the dilated airways. Chest CT is the best method for the diagnosis of bronchiectasis. CT findings include:

  • Tram track appearance
  • Signet ring sign
  • Lack of bronchial tapering
  • Tree-in-bud pattern - It occurs due to the thickening of the dilated airways along with the inspissated secretions.
  • Cysts originating from the bronchial wall (pronounced in cystic bronchiectasis)

The image given below shows the signet ring sign (arrows) seen in bronchiectasis:

 

Other options:

Option A: Pulmonary tuberculosis is an infection caused by Mycobacterium tuberculosis. Patients often present with chronic cough and hemoptysis along with low-grade fever, and weight loss. On CT, Ghon focus, Ranke complex, nodal calcifications, cavities, and hilar/paratracheal lymphadenopathy can be seen.

The image given below shows cavities in pulmonary tuberculosis:

 

Option C: Patients with chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) typically will be smokers with exertional dyspnea, and cough with productive sputum. Lung hyperinflation (emphysema) and airflow obstruction are characteristic of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease on imaging. 

Option D: Patients with bronchial asthma present with symptoms such as wheezing, shortness of breath, chest tightness, and cough usually on exposure to triggering agents. On CT, bronchial wall thickening, mucus plugging, decreased lung attenuation, and gas trapping is seen.

Related Pearl: Tram Track Appearance in Various Conditions

Tram tracks or tram track signs are medical signs that bear some resemblance to tramway tracks (Railway Track).

1. Pulmonology

  • When found in the lungs, tram tracks are radiologic signs that are usually accompanied by pulmonary edema in cases of congestive heart failure and bronchiectasis.
  • Tram tracks are caused by bronchial wall thickening, and can be detected on a lateral chest X-ray.

2. Nephrology

  • The term "tram tracks" is also used to describe the basement membrane duplication found on light microscopy that is characteristic of membranoproliferative glomerulonephritis (MPGN) type I.
  • It is less commonly associated with types II and III.

3. Neurology

  • The term has also been used to describe findings associated with optic nerve sheath meningioma.
  • Tram track-shaped calcifications in the cerebral cortex indicate Sturge-Weber syndrome.

4. Mammary glands:

  • Tram track appearance in mammography/USG indicates Duct Ectasia.

questions.text: A traveller who was lost in a desert during his travel could not drink water for one day. He started to have symptoms of dehydration. Which change would you expect to find in this person?

choices.text: Increased water permeability of the ascending loop of Henle
Increased water permeability of the collecting duct

questions.solution:
Increased water permeability of the collecting duct will be expected in a dehydrated person deprived of water for 24 hours.

Dehydration due to water deprivation causes an increase in extracellular osmolality. This in turn signals the osmoreceptors and stimulates the increase in the plasma levels of anti-diuretic hormone (ADH). This leads to increased permeability of water in the late distal tubules, and cortical and medullary collecting ducts. This further results in the formation of a small volume of concentrated urine, thereby correcting the extracellular fluid osmolality. 

The increased ADH increases the water permeability in the collecting ducts but the ascending loop of Henle is relatively impermeable to water. This low permeability is not altered by water deprivation or increased levels of ADH.

questions.text: A 62-year-old male presented with multiple slow-growing nodules on the scalp.  A biopsy was taken and the histopathological examination revealed a jigsaw puzzle architecture as shown below. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The patient with multiple slow-growing nodules in the scalp and with a 'jigsaw puzzle' appearance on histopathology points toward the diagnosis of cylindromas.

Cylindroma is an appendage tumour with ductal (apocrine or eccrine) differentiation inherited in an autosomal dominant pattern due to mutation of the CYLD gene. 

Patients present with multiple smooth, firm, pink to red coloured nodules on the forehead and scalp which may or may not be pedunculated. Nodules can coalesce and produce a hatlike growth which gives the name, turban tumour.

Histopathology shows lobules of epithelial cells arranged in a jigsaw or mosaic pattern. Each lobule is composed of islands of basaloid cells in the periphery and a paler zone of cells in the centre.

It is treated with wide excision and replacement of the area by a graft.

Other options:

Basal cell carcinoma is a locally aggressive skin malignancy occurring in sun-exposed areas in elderly individuals. Histology shows peripheral palisading of tumour cells which resemble normal cells of the basal cell layer of the epidermis.

Spiradenoma is a benign tumour of the sweat gland presenting as a solitary, painful bluish dermal nodule. Histology shows lobules containing larger pale cells around the lumina and smaller darker cells at the periphery, with intervening cystic spaces and vascular channels.

Merkel cell carcinoma is a highly aggressive neuroendocrine tumour of the skin which presents as a smooth reddish round tumour. Histology shows cell nests and trabecular patterns and is often referred to as trabecular carcinoma of the skin.

questions.text: An elderly woman presented with frequent episodes of dysphagia and chest pain. The chest pain is aggravated by having a meal and is relieved by a loud belch. A chest X-Ray showed the following finding. What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and X-ray findings showing a retrocardiac gas bubble are consistent with the diagnosis of a hiatus hernia.

It is herniation of the stomach fundus or rarely other abdominal contents colon/spleen through a hiatus, usually towards the left side. Hiatus hernia is the protrusion of any abdominal structure other than the esophagus into the thoracic cavity through a widening of the hiatus of the diaphragm.

Types of hiatus hernia:

Type 1 or sliding hernia - gastroesophageal junction or cardia migrates into the thoracic cavity. The length of intra abdominal esophagus is reduced leading to GERD. Most of the patients are asymptomatic. The treatment of choice in symptomatic patients is fundoplication.

Type 2 or rolling hiatus hernia - gastroesophageal junction or cardia is normal but a portion of the stomach migrates into the thoracic cavity. The length of the intraabdominal esophagus remains the same in a true rolling hiatus hernia. Clinical features include - 

  • Chest pain or fullness relieved on belching
  • Dysphagia
  • Longitudinal ulcers (Cameron’s ulcer) that bleed lead to anemia.

Surgical reduction of hernia and tightening of diaphragmatic crura is the best treatment modality even in asymptomatic patients to avoid life-threatening complications like volvulus.

Type 3 or mixed hiatus hernia - a combination of sliding and rolling hiatus hernia. Treatment is the same as rolling hiatus hernia.

Type 4 hiatus hernia - other contents of GIT herniates into the thoracic cavity. Eg: Colon.

CT with oral contrast is the best method of diagnosis of hiatus hernia. It highlights gastric anatomy and also helps to identify other structures involved. Chest X-ray shows an intrathoracic gas bubble.

Related Pearl: Barium swallow

Diffuse esophageal spasm: Corkscrew appearance

Feline esophagus: Transient transverse bands seen in the mid and lower esophagus on a double-contrast barium swallow. It is seen in active gastroesophageal reflux, hiatus hernia, and eosinophilic esophagitis.

Achalasia: Dilated esophagus with a retained column of barium and bird beak sign.

Zenker's diverticulum: Posterior outpouching of the hypopharynx through a weakness in the muscle layer called Killian dehiscence.

Esophageal carcinoma: Irregular narrowing, mucosal destruction, and shouldered margins.

Schatzki's ring: Thin submucosal circumferential ring in the lower esophagus at the squamocolumnar junction.

Esophageal web in a patient with Plummer Vinson syndrome. Esophageal webs are thin membranes of normal esophageal tissue consisting of mucosa and submucosa. Translucent part denotes esophageal web.

Esophageal leiomyoma is the most common benign tumor of the esophagus. On barium swallow, it is seen as a discrete ovoid mass that is well outlined by barium (smooth submucosal mass). Its borders form slightly obtuse angles with the esophagal wall.

The image below depicts a barium study showing the classic semilunar filling defect. 

Related Pearl: Achalasia Cardia

Achalasia cardia is a rare disease caused by the loss of ganglion cells within the esophageal myenteric plexus. Their absence leads to increased tone of the lower esophageal sphincter, impaired relaxation of the lower esophageal sphincter (LES), and absent peristalsis.

Achalasia is the only true motility disorder of the esophagus.

  • Primary achalasia is due to ganglion cell degeneration and is thought to be due to an autoimmune process attributable to latent infection with human herpes simplex virus 1 (HSV1) combined with genetic susceptibility.
  • Secondary achalasia may arise in Chaga's disease.

Clinical features:

  • Dysphagia (solid and liquid food)
  • Regurgitation
  • Chest pain
  • Weight loss
  • Bronchitis, pneumonia, or lung abscess from aspiration

Differential diagnosis: Diffuse esophageal spasm, pseudoachalasia

On barium swallow: Bird beak-appearance

Investigation of choice: Manometry (most sensitive)

Treatment: Pneumatic dilatation, Heller myotomy

Related Pearl: Zenker’s Diverticulum

Zenker's diverticulum occurs due to herniation of mucosa and submucosa through the Killian's triangle, which is a weak area between two parts of the inferior constrictor - (thyropharyngeus and cricopharyngeus) in the posterior pharyngeal wall. It is usually seen in elderly patients (>60 years).

Characteristics of Zenker's diverticulum:

  • Hypopharyngeal
  • False diverticula - doesn't have a muscle coat
  • Acquired 
  • Pulsion diverticulum 

Pathophysiology: Impaired relaxation and spasm of the cricopharyngeus muscle after swallowing can result in increased pressure within the distal pharynx, and cause the diverticulum.Clinical features:

  • Dysphagia
  • Regurgitation
  • Halitosis
  • Aspiration
  • Gurgling sound during swallowing

The investigation of choice is barium swallow (lateral X-ray).

It is treated with:

  • Cricopharyngeal myotomy
  • Surgical diverticulectomy
  • Marsupialization
  • Dohlman’s procedure

questions.text: A patient was treated with an intravenous antimalarial drug following which he developed tinnitus, headache, nausea, and visual disturbances. Examination revealed hypotension and lab reports revealed hypoglycemia. Which of the following drugs is most likely to cause these adverse effects?
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario is suggestive of the adverse effects of quinine. It is an antimalarial used to treat severe malaria.

Quinine is used in the treatment of drug-resistant and severe P. falciparum malaria. It acts against asexual erythrocytic forms of malarial parasites. 

Quinine is most commonly associated with a triad of adverse effects which includes:

  • Cinchonism - headache, tinnitus, high-tone deafness, visual disturbances, vomiting, and postural hypotension.
  • Hypoglycemia - results due to hyperinsulinemia secondary to stimulation of pancreatic beta cells by quinine.
  • Hypotension.

Other adverse effects of quinine include gastrointestinal disturbance, skin manifestations (sweating, flushing, rash, and angioedema), QTc prolongation, and blackwater fever.

Blackwater fever is a hypersensitivity reaction associated with the use of quinine. It presents with a triad of severe hemolysis, hemoglobinemia, and hemoglobinuria.

Other options:

Options A and B: Artemether and artesunate cause gastrointestinal disturbances, itching, drug fever, and hypersensitivity reactions. Minor adverse effects include headache, dizziness, and dark urine.

Option D: Atovaquone can cause gastrointestinal side effects like abdominal pain, vomiting, and diarrhea. It can also cause transient elevation of serum amylase or transaminase.

questions.text: An adolescent boy was given iron supplements for microcytic hypochromic anemia, however, he did not show clinical improvement. Investigations revealed hemoglobin of 9 g/dL, Mentzer index <13, and elevated levels of HbA2 and HbF. Which of the following is the curative treatment for this patient?
questions.solution:
The given findings of Mentzer index < 13 and elevated levels of HbF and HbA2 in a patient with microcytic hypochromic anemia are suggestive of β-thalassemia major. The curative treatment for β-thalassemia major is hematopoietic stem cell transplant.

MCV/RBC count also known as the Mentzer index. It can be used to distinguish thalassemia from iron-deficiency anemia (IDA), both of which have low MCV (mean corpuscular volume) and MCH (mean corpuscular hemoglobin). 

Mentzer index is

  • More than 13 in iron deficiency anemia- because of lower RBC count
  • Less than 13 in thalassemia- because RBC count is usually normal

Thalassemias are inherited disorders of hemoglobin. There is reduced production of alpha-globin or beta-globin chains. This leads to precipitation of the excess (unpaired) chains, interfering with red blood cell (RBC) production and survival. It primarily affects people of Mediterranean origin.

Clinical features in thalassemia include anemia, jaundice, skeletal deformities including facial deformities, changes in body habitus, growth impairment, and hepatosplenomegaly leading to abdominal distension. Due to frequent blood transfusions, iron overload is also seen. 

Peripheral smear is likely to show microcytic hypochromic anemia with target cells, teardrop cells, and some coarse basophilic stippling in certain cases. Elevated HbA2 levels are seen on hemoglobin electrophoresis.

The image given below shows peripheral smear findings in thalassemia:


An X-ray of the skull shows a crewcut appearance due to expansion of hematopoetically active marrow.

Thalassemia is usually managed by blood transfusions every 2-4 weeks and chelation therapy with deferoxamine, deferasirox, and deferiprone for iron chelation. Splenectomy is indicated when the transfusion requirement to maintain ideal hemoglobin increases. Hematopoietic stem cell transplantation (HSCT) is the only known curative treatment for thalassemia.

Other options:

Option A: Iron chelation therapy (oral/parenteral) to prevent organ damage from iron overload. The drugs used are deferoxamine, deferasirox, and deferiprone. It is not a curative therapy.

Option B: Blood transfusion should be started at an early age to promote growth and prevent deformities. This provides symptomatic improvement, but it is not a curative treatment.

Option D: Splenectomy is performed in patients with hypersplenism. Patients who have undergone splenectomy are susceptible to infections from capsulated organisms and should receive appropriate vaccinations. It is less preferred due to serious adverse effects.

questions.text: A 50-year old man, who is a known case of HIV, presented with features suggestive of tuberculosis. According to the recent NTEP guidelines, which is the next best line of management?

choices.text: Do 2 sputum smears and chest X-Ray
Wait until TB culture results to start ATT

questions.solution:
In a patient with HIV, who is suspected to have tuberculosis, CBNAAT is ordered upfront.

For people living with HIV (PLHIV), CBNAAT has to be done from the sputum specimen or specimen from the appropriate extrapulmonary site. If CBNAAT linkage is unavailable, then microscopy and chest-X ray is done on the same day.

Two sputum samples are sent for cartridge-based nucleic acid amplification (CBNAAT) which, within 2 hours, detects the presence of Mycobacterium DNA along with resistance against rifampicin. It analyses sputum or any other biological specimen (except blood and blood-contaminated specimens) using real-time PCR technology. CBNAAT is also ordered upfront in case of children or extrapulmonary tuberculosis. 

In PLHIV, there are increased chances of sputum negative TB and fewer chances of cavitation in a chest x-ray. Hence, CBNAAT is preferred.

Line probe assays (LPA) are ordered to look for drug resistance. First-line LPA detects resistance to rifampicin and isoniazid while second-line LPA detects resistance to fluoroquinolones and injectable second-line drugs.

In a patient with HIV and TB, start ATT first and then start ART as soon as ATT is tolerated by the patient (between 2 weeks and 2 months). This is done in order to avoid immune reconstitution inflammatory syndrome (IRIS). 

Related Pearl: Diagnostic algorithm for Pulmonary TB – National Tuberculosis Elimination Programme (NTEP) 2020 Guidelines

Any case of presumptive pulmonary TB should undergo sputum examination + chest X-ray + CB-NAAT

  • If sputum and chest X-ray normal: rule out TB and refer
  • If sputum is positive and CB NAAT is positive: microbiologically confirmed case of TB

  • Poly-Drug Resistant (PDR): A TB patient, who is resistant to more than one 1st line anti-TB drug, other than Rifampicin and isoniazid.

  • Extensively Drug-Resistant (XDR): A MDR TB patient who is additionally resistant to a fluoroquinolone (ofloxacin, levofloxacin, or moxifloxacin) and at least one additional group A drug (as of 2021, these are bedaquiline and linezolid)

questions.text: The spinal injuries are immediately fatal if the fracture occurs above the level of which cervical vertebrae?
questions.solution:
The spinal injuries are immediately fatal if the fracture occurs above the level of the C4 cervical vertebra. 

The origin of the phrenic nerve or the spinal respiratory centre is mainly formed by the C4 spinal cord segment, with minor contributions from C3 and C5 segments. Thus injury to the spinal cord above C4 vertebral level can be rapidly fatal from disruption of cardiorespiratory regulation centres.

The most common part of the spine injured is the upper cervical vertebrae (C1–C4). It accounts for 2/3rd of adult spine injuries. 

The order of frequency of injury to the spinal cord is cervical > thoracolumbar > lumbar > thoracic > sacral level.

questions.text: A 57-year-old male patient presented with anasarca, nephrotic range proteinuria and mild hepatomegaly. Suspecting amyloidosis, a renal biopsy was taken, which seen under polarised light shows the following appearance. What is the most likely stain used here?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of renal amyloidosis in which the biopsy specimen shows apple-green birefringence under polarized light with congo-red staining.

Amyloidosis is a condition caused due to the deposition of abnormal fibrillar proteins in extracellular spaces. Abnormal fibrils are produced by the aggregation of misfolded proteins. The fibrillar deposits bind a wide variety of proteoglycans and glycosaminoglycans, including heparan sulfate and dermatan sulfate, and plasma proteins, notably serum amyloid P component (SAP). Amyloid appears as an amorphous, eosinophilic, hyaline, extracellular substance.

Based on the involvement of organ systems it may be classified as systemic or localized. Hereditary amyloidosis is a separate group of heterogeneous disorders with many distinctive patterns of organ involvement. 

Microscopically, all types of amyloid deposits are made up of continuous, nonbranching fibrils. A characteristic cross-β-pleated sheet conformation is visualized on X-ray crystallography and infrared spectroscopy. 

On light microscopy (with hematoxylin and eosin stain): Amyloid appears as an amorphous, eosinophilic, hyaline substance in extracellular space.

Congo red stain, which is used to observe amyloid deposits is shown in the image below: 

  1. Under ordinary light, it imparts a pink or red color to amorphous extracellular material, as seen by the focal positive staining.
  2. Under the polarizing microscope, it imparts apple-green birefringence to amyloid deposits.
 The next best step is to determine the type of precursor protein by immunohistochemistry, immunoelectron microscopy, or extraction and biochemical analysis employing mass spectrometry.

Other options: 

Perl's Prussian blue stain is used in Hemochromatosis to stain liver tissue which shows hepatocellular iron, which is stained blue with this stain.


Amyloid deposits and Paget cells observed in Paget disease are stained by Alcian blue. 


The given slide shows the GI mucosa, which has been stained with Warthin-Starry silver stain, demonstrating the bacilli Helicobacter pylori.

questions.text: Which of the following clinical presentations is most consistent with the diagnosis of chancroid?

choices.text: Cluster of vesicles on erythematous base
Single painless ulcer with a clean base and a firm raised border
Painless papule or nodule erodes into beefy red granulomatous ulcer with rolled edges
Multiple painful non-indurated ulcers and painful inguinal lymphadenopathy

questions.solution:
The clinical presentation of single or multiple painful non-indurated ulcers and painful inguinal lymphadenopathy points towards the diagnosis of chancroid (soft chancre).

Autoinoculation from the primary ulcer can result in kissing ulcers on opposing skin surfaces. Painful genital ulcers are caused by Haemophilus ducreyi and are known as chancroid. The regional lymph nodes are enlarged and painful. The microscopic appearance seen in H. ducreyi is called the school of fish appearance or railroad appearance and is shown in the image below.

  • The ulcers are painful.

  • It usually causes beefy red genital ulcers that may bleed on touch.
  • The ulcers are usually painless.
  • Lymphadenopathy is usually absent but subcutaneous granulomas cause pseudo buboes.

  • It usually causes tender unilateral inguinal buboes.

  • The secondary stage presents with tender inguinal buboes.
  • Groove sign is seen when the lymph nodes above and below the inguinal ligament are enlarged leading to the appearance of a groove.

The given images show the ulcer and the groove sign seen in LGV:

 

Gonorrhea- caused by Neisseria gonorrhoeae.

  • It leads to purulent inflammation of the genital mucous membranes.
  • It may present as urethritis, cervicitis, epididymo‐orchitis, or pelvic inflammatory disease.
  • The usual presentation is acute urethritis with complaints of burning dysuria and purulent discharge.

questions.text: A patient with sepsis was transferred to another hospital. Airing and sunning of his room and furniture were done by the hospital staff after the patient left. Which of the following methods was used in this scenario?
questions.solution:
In the given scenario, terminal cleaning is used as a cleaning method.

Terminal cleaning is the process of airing and sunning the rooms, furniture, and bedding of a patient who has died or has been shifted to another hospital or after cessation of isolation. The room is cleaned with a detergent or enzyme cleaner by the hospital staff so that a new patient can be admitted to that room. Currently, this method is used in place of terminal disinfection and is considered adequate. 

Routine cleaning is the cleaning of inpatient areas while the patient is staying in the hospital. This aims to provide a visibly clean environment and reduce microbial contamination.

Types of disinfection are:

  • Terminal disinfection is the application of disinfection measures after the patient has died or has been shifted to another hospital or after cessation of isolation. It is rarely done now and has been replaced by terminal cleaning.
  • Concurrent disinfection is the application of disinfection methods after the discharge of infectious material from the body of an infected person or soiling.
  • Precurrent/prophylactic disinfection is the application of preventive measures like pasteurization of milk, chlorination of water, and handwashing.

Disinfection refers to the thermal or chemical destruction of the most recognized pathogenic microorganisms, but not necessarily all microbial forms like bacterial spores.

Cleaning refers to the removal of adherent visible debris from the surfaces, instruments and equipment by a manual or mechanical process to render it safe from further decontamination.

Sodium hypochlorite(0.5-5%) is the best disinfectant for surface blood spills. Hydrogen peroxide can be used for disinfection or sterilization which has largely replaced fumigation. It is also used in plasma sterilization.

questions.text: A 60-year-old obese woman presents with upper right abdominal pain. The pain is dull and associated with fatty food ingestion. A CT scan was done which is shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and CT scan showing calcification in the gall bladder wall is suggestive of a porcelain gallbladder.

Porcelain gallbladder refers to dystrophic calcification of the gallbladder wall. The mechanism behind its pathophysiology is thought to be the same as that of gallstone formation.

It has a 5:1 preponderance in women when compared to men. Age > 60 years and obesity are risk factors for this condition. Symptoms are similar to chronic cholecystitis. 

Diagnosis can be made by X-ray or CT scan. Abdominal ultrasound and MRI can also help in the diagnosis. 

It is considered a premalignant lesion for gallbladder carcinoma. Hence, treatment is advised in all cases with laparoscopic cholecystectomy. 

Option A: On USG, a gallbladder polyp is fixed, and does not cast any acoustic shadow. A polyp is more of an incidental finding and is often asymptomatic

Option D: In cholelithiasis, the gallstones appear as echogenic foci, which cast an acoustic shadow on USG. Stone mobility may be demonstrated if it is not impacted.

Option C: In emphysematous cholecystitis, intraluminal gas appears as a bright curvilinear echogenic band with ‘dirty’ shadowing. CT scan shows gas within the wall of the gallbladder (shown below).

questions.text: In a pregnant woman, on performing Leopold's 1st grip, you are able to palpate a freely mobile, hard and globular mass. Which of the following fetal parts is the denominator in this case?
questions.solution:
If a freely mobile, hard and globular mass is found on the 1st Leopold's grip, the fetus is in a longitudinal lie, in podalic/ breech presentation, and hence will have sacrum as the denominator.

The fetal denominator refers to the bony fixed point of reference on the presenting part with respect to different quadrants of the pelvis. The denominators for various presentations are as follows:

Presentation Denominator
Breech Sacrum
Vertex Occiput
Face Mentum (chin)
Brow Frontal eminence
Shoulder Acromion

 Note: The question refers to a breech pregnancy hence the part felt on the 1st Leopold's grip would be a smooth, hard globular mass indicative of head. The image provided is that of a fetus in a normal longitudinal lie, vertex presentation.

Fetal pole, lie, presenting part, engagement, and attitude of fetal head are assessed by Leopold's maneuvers:

To know the presenting fetal part in respect to the true pelvis

To determine the degree of descent.

If the head has already descended into the pelvis, the anterior shoulder or the space created by neck may be differentiated readily from the head

 

Interpretation of various fetal parts felt in Leopold's grips:

  • Large, soft, nodular mass - indicates breech 
  • Hard, round, mobile mass - indicates head  
  • Uniform curved hard resistance- indicates back
  • Small, irregular, mobile parts- indicate fetal extremities 

Definitions of various terminologies used for the fetus in utero:

  • Lie: Relationship of the long axis of the fetus to the long axis of the maternal spine.
  • Presentation: Part of the fetus occupying the lower pole of the pelvis.
  • Presenting part: Part of the presentation which overlies the internal os.
  • Attitude: The relation of the different parts of the fetus to one another.
  • Position: Relation of the denominator to the different quadrants of the pelvis.

questions.text: The echocardiography report of a 35-year-old woman hailing from China indicates dilated cardiomyopathy. Which of the following conditions can explain her diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The patient is probably suffering from Keshan's disease, which is due to selenium deficiency.

Keshan disease is endemic cardiomyopathy found in children and young women residing in regions of China where dietary intake of selenium is low. Mainly dilated cardiomyopathy is characteristic, and may also result in cardiomegaly, congestive cardiac failure and fulminant cardiogenic shock.

Selenium is an important trace element that is a part of the 21st amino acid selenocysteine. There are many selenium-containing enzymes such as:

  • Glutathione peroxidase
  • De-iodinase
  • Thioredoxin reductase

Selenium is also an intracellular antioxidant that complements the role of vitamin E. Dietary sources of selenium include seafood, muscle meat, and some cereals.

questions.text: A 56-year-old woman is diagnosed with an atrioventricular (AV) heart block. Name the vein which accompanies the artery supplying the AV node.
questions.solution:
The middle cardiac vein accompanies the posterior interventricular artery which provides arterial supply to the AV node.

The middle cardiac vein begins at the cardiac apex and runs in the posterior interventricular groove and merges with the coronary sinus near its atrial end. Thus it accompanies the posterior interventricular artery in the groove.

Other options:

Option B: Great cardiac vein originates at the cardiac apex. It runs anteriorly in the anterior interventricular groove and ends in the coronary sinus at its origin. It accompanies anterior interventricular and circumflex arteries. 

Option C: Oblique vein of left atrium descends obliquely on the posterior aspect of the left atrium and joins the coronary sinus.

Option D: Inferior vein of left ventricle lies on the diaphragmatic surface of the left ventricle, a little left of the middle cardiac vein. It ends by joining the coronary sinus or occasionally the great cardiac vein.

questions.text: A young man presents to an emergency room with sudden onset of the chest and epigastric pain. An ECG done reveals no abnormality. On palpation, you hear a crunchy sound of the chest and rigidity in the epigastric region. An X-ray chest of the patient is given below. Which among the following contrasts is contraindicated in confirming the diagnosis using fluoroscopy?
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario with crunchy sound on chest palpation and an x-ray showing pneumothorax (white arrow) and pleural effusion (black arrowhead) in the chest points towards a diagnosis of esophageal perforation. Water-insoluble contrast media like barium sulphate is contraindicated to confirm the diagnosis using fluoroscopy. 

Esophageal perforation most commonly occurs due to iatrogenic instrumentation. Spontaneous perforation occurs due to vomiting against a closed glottis—Boerhaave syndrome. Clinically, patients typically will have pain in the chest and epigastric region. On examination, abdominal rigidity and a crunchy sound on chest palpation (Hamman's sign) due to subcutaneous emphysema from leakage of air into subcutaneous space are seen. 

The classic chest radiographic findings include pneumomediastinum, left pleural effusion, and left pneumothorax.

Low-osmolar water-soluble contrast medium like iopamidol is used for the diagnostic workup for a suspected case of esophageal perforation instead of barium contrast to prevent barium-related inflammation of the mediastinum. However, if water-soluble contrast media is not available, diluted barium can be used.

Barium sulfate is not normally absorbed during its passage through the digestive tract. However when the integrity of the gut wall is compromised or when there is abnormal communication between the esophagus and trachea, it can overflow into the lungs, mediastinum, intraperitoneal cavity, and tissue around the rectum and cause inflammation. Hence, it is contraindicated in these cases.

Contraindications to use of barium:

  • Esophageal perforation: Iodinated contrast media like iopamidol and iohexol are used; gastrograffin can also be used but is not preferred due to risk of aspiration pneumonitis.
  • Tracheoesophageal fistula: dianosil, the water-soluble non-ionic agent is used.
  • Duodenal perforation: iohexol or gastrograffin is used.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man presented with tingling and weakness in his right hand and left foot for the past 4 days. He is also a known case of asthma and is on treatment.  On examination, you notice that the patient has a purpura over his body. Laboratory investigations reveal marked eosinophilia. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario with a triad of skin lesions, asymmetric mono neuritis multiplex, and eosinophilia in an asthmatic patient is suggestive of Churg-Strauss syndrome.

Churg-Strauss syndrome (eosinophilic granulomatosis with polyangiitis) is a necrotizing vasculitis of the small-to-medium-sized vessels and is characterized by asthma, peripheral and tissue eosinophilia, granuloma formation, and vasculitis.

Common presenting symptoms of this condition are

  • Initial non-specific symptoms like fever, malaise, anorexia, and weight loss
  • Severe attacks of asthma, allergic rhinitis, sinusitis
  • Mononeuritis multiplex- It is a type of peripheral neuropathy affecting at least two nerve areas. Patients complain of pain, tingling, numbness, or weakness in the affected areas.
  • Skin lesions like palpable purpura and subcutaneous nodules

Laboratory investigations will show eosinophilia. They also show elevated erythrocyte sedimentation rate (ESR), fibrinogen, or α2-globulins. Some patients may be positive for antineutrophil cytoplasmic antibodies (ANCA). Histopathology shows the presence of necrotizing vasculitis, tissue eosinophilia, and extravascular granulomas.

Daily cyclophosphamide and prednisolone, followed by azathioprine or methotrexate, can be used for the treatment. Mepolizumab, a monoclonal antibody against IL-5, is the drug recently approved by the FDA for Churg-Strauss syndrome.

Note: A rare side effect following the use of montelukast and zafirlukast is the development of Churg-Strauss syndrome.

Other options:

Option A: Patients with microscopic polyangiitis can have symptoms of mononeuritis multiplex and cutaneous purpura. However, features of asthma and eosinophilia make microscopic polyangiitis less likely as the diagnosis.

Option B: Polyarteritis nodosa can also present with mononeuritis multiplex and skin lesions, but patients do not have eosinophilia. In addition to this, it does not affect bronchial or pulmonary arteries.

Option D: Granulomatosis with polyangiitis (Wegener's) also has symptoms of upper respiratory tract infection (sinusitis, septal perforation, otitis media), lower respiratory tract involvement (hemoptysis, dyspnea, and chest discomfort), and glomerulonephritis. However, eosinophilia is not a feature of this disease.

Related Pearl: Microscopic polyangiitis v/s granulomatosis with polyangiitis

questions.text: A 3-week-old baby presented with 2 episodes of fits. On examination, repetitive movements as if the baby was boxing and bicycling were noticed. His urine had a sweetish odor and was positive for the dinitrophenylhydrazine test. Blood concentrations of which of the following amino acids is relatively higher in the baby?
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario with a positive urine dinitrophenylhydrazine test is suggestive of maple syrup urine disease (MSUD). The levels of leucine are higher than the other three amino acids.

MSUD is an autosomal recessive disorder which occurs due to deficiency of branched-chain ketoacid dehydrogenase complex. This impairs the metabolism of branched-chain amino acids valine, leucine, isoleucine and alloisoleucine. These amino acids, particularly leucine and its metabolite accumulate in the blood, causing toxic effects on the brain.

The affected child develops poor feeding and vomiting a few days after birth. There is a period of hypertonicity with a period of flaccidity in between. These appear as repetitive boxing and bicycling movements. The babies may also have hypoglycemia, but this is not corrected by the administration of glucose. The urine, sweat, and cerumen of the baby have a sweetish maple syrup-like odor.

Laboratory investigations will show increased levels of branched-chain amino acids in the plasma and urine. Leucine levels are usually higher than isoleucine, valine, and alloisoleucine. Since the patient excretes ketoacids in the urine, the urine will be positive for the dinitrophenylhydrazine test.

Treatment involves controlled intake of branched-chain amino acids using commercially available formulas and judicious supplementation of isoleucine and valine. Very high levels of leucine are removed by hemodialysis.

questions.text: A young man presented with hypertensive episodes, bloody stools and cutaneous nodules. He has a past history of hepatitis B infection. Vasculitis was suspected and a biopsy of the vessel was done. The histopathology of the tissue from the vessel is shown below. Identify the type of necrosis.
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of polyarteritis nodosa and the above image depicts fibrinoid necrosis. It is seen in vasculitis like polyarteritis nodosa (PAN) in which the small and medium-sized blood vessels are affected as a result of immune complex deposition.

Polyarteritis nodosa is a medium and small-sized vessel vasculitis typically affecting the renal and visceral arteries, sparing pulmonary vessels. Patients present with variable symptoms including accelerated hypertension, abdominal pain, gastrointestinal bleeding, myalgias and cutaneous nodules. It is often associated with chronic hepatitis B infection, which causes the HBsAg-HbsAb complexes to deposit in affected vessels. Clinical manifestations are a result of ischemia and infarction of organs and tissues that are affected.

The diagnosis is based on the histopathological findings seen on a biopsy of the involved organs. Diagnosis can also be made by the demonstration of aneurysms of small and medium-sized arteries in the renal, hepatic, and visceral vasculature. 

Fibrinoid necrosis occurs in blood vessels in which the antigen-antibody complexes get deposited in the blood vessel walls. These complexes elicit an immune reaction leading to cell injury and leakage of fibrin and plasma proteins around the blood vessel and giving a circumferential pinkish appearance of necrosis. 

It is treated with immunosuppressive agents and has a high risk of mortality if left untreated.

The image below shows fibrinoid necrosis with intraluminal thrombosis in an artery of a patient with polyarteritis nodosa. 

Necrosis refers to irreversible cell death caused by the denaturation of proteins and enzymatic digestion of the injured cells. 

Gangrenous necrosis commonly occurs in the lower limbs due to decreased blood supply. This type of necrosis is usually coagulative necrosis and is called dry gangrene.

When this becomes superimposed with bacterial infection the harmful enzymes from the bacteria and inflammatory cells result in liquefactive necrosis which is called wet gangrene.

Caseous necrosis (cheese like) refers to a friable yellow white area of necrosis as seen in this image

  • On microscopic examination, the necrotic focus appears as a collection of fragmented or lysed cells with an amorphous granular pink appearance surrounded by inflammatory cells called as granuloma and is classical of tuberculosis as shown below.

Fat necrosis refers to the localised destruction of fat by pancreatic enzymes. The commonest cause of this type of necrosis is acute pancreatitis. In acute pancreatitis, these enzymes are released within or around the pancreas breaking down the triglycerides into fatty acids. When calcium binds to fatty acid it results in fat saponification giving a chalky white appearance.

Polyarteritis nodosa is a medium and small-sized vessel vasculitis typically affecting the renal and visceral arteries. Patients present with variable symptoms including accelerated hypertension, abdominal pain, gastrointestinal bleeding, myalgias and cutaneous nodules. It is often associated with chronic hepatitis B infection. Histology shows characteristic fibrinoid necrosis of the vessel wall with intraluminal thrombosis. This condition is treated with immunosuppressive agents and has a high risk of mortality.

questions.text: A girl presented with itching and oozing from an earlobe lesion after wearing nickel earrings. What test will you do to confirm the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This is a case of allergic contact dermatitis and the diagnosis is made by a patch test.

Allergic contact dermatitis is a reaction to a substance (allergen) that causes an eruption only in those individuals previously sensitized by the same molecule. It is a delayed-type of hypersensitivity (Type IV) reaction. It presents as pruritis and an eczematous eruption in sites where contact has taken place with the etiological agent/allergen.

Nickel is the most frequent contact allergen. Most of its salts, for example, nickel chloride and nickel sulfate, are readily soluble in water and sweat and have strong sensitizing properties. Jewelry and metal components of clothing are the usual sources of nickel in prolonged contact with the skin. 

Patch tests are used to identify the etiologic agent(s) of allergic contact dermatitis. Patches are usually applied to the back and removed 48 hours after application. The skin where the patch was applied is examined with readings taken 1 hour after removal and again 48 hours later.

The image below shows a picture of a skin patch allergy test:

 

Treatment of includes

  • Avoidance of the allergen (for example, further use of nickel‐plated objects should be avoided in this case)
  • A topical clioquinol–steroid combination can be considered as a treatment (clioquinol is known to chelate nickel)

questions.text: A 15-year-old boy presents with steatorrhea, hemolytic anemia, and ataxia. The peripheral blood smear picture is given below. Which vitamin can particularly prevent early death in this condition?
questions.solution:
The clinical vignette mentioning steatorrhea, hemolytic anemia, and ataxia along with acanthocytes seen in the peripheral blood smear is suggestive of abetalipoproteinemia. Administration of large doses of particularly Vitamin E can prevent early death in this condition.

Abetalipoproteinemia is an autosomal recessive disorder occurring due to loss of function mutation in the gene encoding microsomal triglyceride transfer protein (MTP). MTP transfers lipids to nascent chylomicrons in the intestine and VLDLs in the liver. Therefore, when the MTP gene is mutated, chylomicrons, VLDL, and LDL are not produced.

Vitamin E and retinyl esters are normally transported from enterocytes to the liver by chylomicrons. Vitamin E is also dependent on VLDL for transport out of the liver and into circulation. Because of the inability of these patients to secrete apoB-containing particles, patients with abetalipoproteinemia are markedly deficient in vitamin E. 

Features of abetalipoproteinemia include diarrhea, failure to thrive, neurological features like loss of deep tendon reflexes, dysmetria, ataxia, spastic gait, etc, hypolipidemia, and progressive pigmented retinopathy which may progress to near-blindness.

Treatment of this condition includes the administration of large doses of Vitamin E. They are also mild to moderately deficient in vitamins A and K, those vitamins need to be administrated as well.

Note: It is necessary to initiate Vitamin E therapy as early as possible to prevent the development of neurologic sequelae which may warrant even higher doses of vitamin E.

questions.text: A 24-year-old primigravida delivers a preterm baby at 33 weeks of gestation with a birth weight of 2 kg. She is advised to hold her child as shown below.  Which of the following statements about this method is false?

choices.text: Safety and thermal protection is equivalent to incubators
Reduces severe morbidity in the newborns
Should be performed only by the mother

questions.solution:
Kangaroo Mother Care (KMC) can be carried out by the mother or any other caregiver.

KMC was introduced for the prevention of neonatal hypothermia in low birth weight/ premature newborns. It has 4 components—

  • Skin-to-skin positioning of the newborn on the mother’s chest.
  • Adequate nutrition through breastfeeding.
  • Early discharge and ambulatory care.
  • Support for mother and family for child care.

Evidence shows that-

  • It is as good as incubators, in terms of safety and thermal protection (measured by mortality)
  • Reduces severe morbidity by way of facilitating breastfeeding
  • Humanization of neonatal care
  • Promoted bonding between mother and child

Eligibility criteria for KMC:

It is indicated for all hemodynamically stable low birth weight babies. Short sessions of KMC can be initiated in babies on medical treatment like IV fluids or oxygen therapy. Initiation of KMC can vary with the birth weight of the baby.

  • Birth weight <1200 g - It may take days to weeks for initiation of KMC
  • Birth weight =1200-1800 g - Only a few days may be taken before KMC initiation
  • Birth weight >1800 g - KMC can be initiated immediately after birth

All mothers without any serious illness can provide KMC.

Positioning for KMC: The baby is placed between the mother's breast in an upright position. The hips are abducted and flexed in the frog position and the arms are also flexed. The abdomen of the baby should be at the level of the mother's epigastrium. In this position, the mother's breathing would stimulate the baby and prevent the development of apnea.

The duration of KMC should be gradually increased from short sessions of more than one hour to 24 hours a day.

KMC is not necessary once the baby attains 2500 g of weight or 37 weeks of gestation.

Note: 

Incubatory care, feeding via nasal catheter, and prevention of infection are part of intensive care for low birthweight babies.

World Kangaroo Care Awareness Day is a global healthcare awareness event observed annually on 15th of May with an intention of spreading the benefits. Studies show that infants who underwent KMC had a low death count during the first-year follow-up. In addition, they also had lower rates of school absenteeism, hyperactivity, aggression, and socio-deviant behaviour among young adults than the control group after 20 years of follow-up.

questions.text: A patient was diagnosed with pseudohemoptysis. He was informed that the color of the sputum is due to a pigment produced by a microorganism. What is the most probable microorganism discussed here?
questions.solution:
Pseudohemoptysis is most commonly caused by Serratia marcescens.

Serratia marcescens is a pleomorphic coccobacilli. It may grow in sputum after collection. They may mimic hemoptysis (pseudohemoptysis) because they produce a red pigment called prodigiosin.

S. marcescens contaminate intravenous fluids, surgical instruments, and antiseptic solutions. Therefore, they are one of the important causes of healthcare-associated infections.

questions.text: A chronic alcoholic man wanted to overcome his alcohol addiction and abstained from alcohol for 3 days. On the third day, he developed tremors and hallucinations. He was brought to the emergency and was found to be disoriented. His heart rate and blood pressure were increased. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The most likely diagnosis based on the clinical features is delirium tremens.

Delirium tremens is the most severe form of alcohol withdrawal syndrome. The patients present with confusion, agitation, and fluctuating levels of consciousness. Visual or tactile hallucinations along with features of autonomic hyperactivity like tremors, tachycardia, diaphoresis, fever, insomnia, and increased blood pressure are also seen. 

It usually occurs within 72 hours of abstinence, however, may occur within a week of alcohol withdrawal. Acute infection, hepatitis, and pancreatitis predispose delirium tremens.

Delirium tremens is treated with benzodiazepines such as chlordiazepoxide. It is also recommended to administer thiamine in patients with alcohol-related disorders to prevent Wernicke-Korsakoff syndrome.

Other options:

Option A: Alcohol withdrawal-related hallucinations- These are usually auditory hallucinations occurring during alcohol withdrawal. In this condition, the patient has a clear sensorium, which differentiates it from delirium tremens.

Option B: Korsakoff's psychosis is an amnestic syndrome that occurs due to thiamine deficiency. The clinical features include impairment of memory, confabulations, and disordered temporal sequencing. Thiamine supplementation and nutritional support are given to these patients. However, the patients show only a little improvement because of irreversible damage to the medial thalamic nuclei and mammillary bodies caused by thiamine deficiency.

Option D: Marchiafava-Bignami disease is a syndrome characterized by dementia and seizures, associated with degeneration of the corpus callosum. It has been observed in male Italian red wine drinkers.
