questions.text:
A per rectal examination of a patient revealed an enlarged nodular prostate with adherent rectal mucosa. PSA was found to be 25 ng/ml. A biopsy was done which showed adenocarcinoma of the prostate. Which of the following zones of the prostate is likely to be involved in this pathology?

PSA: Prostate specific antigen
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and findings are suggestive of a case of prostatic carcinoma. Prostatic carcinoma arises from the peripheral zone (marked 2) of the gland.

The prostate has three distinct zones as follows:

ZONE STRUCTURES ENCLOSED CLINICAL SIGNIFICANCE
Transitional zone Urethra  The common site for BPH (benign prostatic hyperplasia)
Central zone Ejaculatory ducts Rarely diseased
Peripheral zone

Central transitional zone

Pre-prostatic urethra

 The common site for prostatic carcinoma

Benign prostatic hyperplasia (BPH) arises from the transitional zone.

Carcinoma of the prostate is the most common malignant tumor in men over the age of 65 years  They may range from indolent lesions that cause no harm to aggressive metastatic tumors. Most cancers are clinically silent and are detected on routine rectal examination or PSA measurements.

Grossly, malignant tissue is gritty and firm in consistency (in contrast to the spongy appearance of benign tissue) and thus more readily palpable on digital rectal examination. 

Only advanced disease gives rise to symptoms:

  • Bladder outlet obstruction
  • Pelvic pain and haematuria
  • Bone pain, arthritis
  • Anemia or pancytopenia
  • Renal failure

PSA (prostate specific antigen) is a glycoprotein peptidase that facilitates the liquefaction of semen. It is useful for screening and for monitoring response to therapy but is neither specific nor sensitive to the condition as it can be elevated due to old age and benign conditions such as prostatitis and BPH. A PSA >10ng/ mL is suggestive of cancer and >35 ng/ml is almost diagnostic of advanced prostate cancer. Following radical prostatectomy, the serum PSA should fall to undetectable levels

A prostate biopsy using an automated gun is used to confirm the diagnosis. Around 12 systematic biopsy cores are obtained. This procedure can be done by transrectal or transperineal approach.

Gleason grading may be used after the biopsy to evaluate the stage of the histopathological specimen. Gleason scores range from 6 to 10 where 6 is a low risk for prostate cancer while 10 is a high risk.

Staging of prostate carcinoma
Tx Primary tumor cannot be assessed
T0 No evidence of primary tumor
T1 Clinically inapparent tumor. Neither palpable nor visible on imaging
T1a Incidental histologic findings in 5% or less of tissue resected
T1b Incidental histologic findings in more than 5% of tissue resected
T1c Tumors identified by needle biopsy (for example, because of elevated PSA)
T2

Tumor confined within the prostate
T2a

A tumor involves one-half of one lobe or less
T2b

Tumor involves more than one-half of one lobe but not both lobes
T2c

Tumor involves both lobes
T3

Tumors extend through the prostate capsule
T3a The extracapsular extension (unilateral or bilateral)
T3b

Tumor invades seminal vesicle(s)
T4 Tumor is fixed or invades adjacent structures other than seminal vesicles, such as the external sphincter, rectum, bladder, levator muscles, and/or pelvic wall

Management of prostatic carcinoma:

Management of prostatic carcinoma   
Stage of cancer Age>70 or Gleason score=6  Age<70 or Gleason score>6    
Early prostate cancer: T1, T2A Active surveillance Radical prostatectomy   
Locally advanced prostate cancer: T2B, T2C, T3, T4, N1 Brachytherapy + Androgen deprivation therapy Brachytherapy + Radical prostatectomy
Metastatic prostate cancer   

Androgen deprivation therapy

Chemotherapy and radiotherapy (hormone-resistant  tumor)

Radiopharmaceutical therapy (hormone-resistant bony metastasis) 

Active surveillance is done when there is:

  • Gleason's score of 6
  • Early-stage disease (T1c)
  • Small volume disease on biopsy
  • Low PSA (< 10 ng/ml)

Active surveillance protocols include a digital rectal examination and PSA monitoring every 3 to 6 months, with TRUS-guided prostate biopsies every 1 to 3 years.

questions.text: A 2-day-old neonate was brought with complaints of one episode of seizure, vomiting, and poor feeding. Investigations revealed increased levels of lactate in blood and cerebrospinal fluid. The deficiency of which of the following enzymes leads to the above condition?
questions.solution:
The clinical vignette along with elevated levels of lactate in blood and cerebrospinal fluid suggestive of congenital lactic acidosis. The deficiency of the pyruvate dehydrogenase enzyme complex leads to this condition.

Congenital lactic acidosis is an inborn error of metabolism that often presents in infancy with lethargy, vomiting, tachypnea, and poor feeding. Other severe symptoms include hypotonia and seizures. Investigations show a high level of lactate in blood, cerebrospinal fluid, and urine (lactic acidosis).

Causes of lactic acidosis include mitochondrial disorders, deficiency of PDH enzyme/vitamin B12, mercury, and arsenite poisoning.

The pyruvate dehydrogenase (PDH) complex is a multienzyme complex that is associated with the inner mitochondrial membrane which catalyzes the oxidative decarboxylation of pyruvate to acetyl-CoA. It has three enzyme components that include:

  • Pyruvate dehydrogenase
  • Dihydrolipoyl transacetylase
  • Dihydrolipoyl dehydrogenase

The cofactors for PDH complex are:

  • Thiamine diphosphate
  • Lipoic acid
  • Coenzyme A
  • Flavin adenine dinucleotide (FAD)
  • Nicotinamide adenine dinucleotide (NAD+)

The overall reaction is : Pyruvate + NAD+ + CoA → Acetyl-CoA + NADH + H+ + CO2

Pyruvate Dehydrogenase is regulated by end-product inhibition & covalent modification

  • PDH is inhibited by its products, acetyl-CoA, and NADH.
  • Phosphorylation of the multienzyme complex by a kinase results in decreased activity.
    • The kinase is activated by increases in the [ATP]/[ADP], [acetyl-CoA]/[CoA], and [NADH]/[NAD+] ratios.
  • Dephosphorylation, catalyzed by a phosphatase, causes an increase in the activity of PDH.

Thus, pyruvate dehydrogenase, and therefore glycolysis, is inhibited when there is adequate ATP available and when fatty acids are being oxidized. In adipose tissue, the enzyme is activated in response to insulin.

Clinical aspects:

  • Arsenite and mercuric ions react with the -SH groups of lipoic acid and inhibit pyruvate dehydrogenase.
  • Dietary thiamine deficiency inhibits PDH. Therefore, chronic alcoholics may develop potentially fatal pyruvic and lactic acidosis.
  • Patients with inherited pyruvate dehydrogenase deficiency present with lactic acidosis, particularly after a glucose load, and present with neurological disturbances.

Other options:

Options B and C: Inherited aldolase A deficiency and pyruvate kinase deficiency in erythrocytes cause hemolytic anemia.

Option D: Aldolase B cleaves fructose-1-phosphate. In the deficiency of aldolase B, hereditary fructose intolerance develops which is characterized by profound hypoglycemia and vomiting after consumption of sucrose, which yields fructose in digestion. This can lead to fructose-induced hypoglycemia.

Related Pearl: Pyruvate metabolism

  Enzyme involved

Fate of pyruvate
1 Cahill cycle (Alanine aminotransferase)

Carries amino group from muscle to liver.

Converts alanine to pyruvate and vise-versa.
2 Pyruvate carboxylase Formation of oxaloacetate from pyruvate to be used in the TCA cycle
3 Pyruvate dehydrogenase Pyruvate to acetyl Co-A to be used in the TCA cycle
4 Lactic acid dehydrogenase Pyruvate to lactate(Anaerobic glycolysis)

questions.text: A married couple has a child with thalassemia major. What preventive method would you use to prevent giving birth to another thalassemia-positive baby in this couple?
questions.solution:
The preventive method to be used to prevent giving birth to another thalassemia-positive baby in this couple is retrospective genetic counselling.

Retrospective genetic counselling is the most common approach of counselling done presently for hereditary disorders that have already occurred within the family. Under this type of counselling, the couples are suggested contraception, termination of pregnancy, or sterilization, depending on individual considerations.

It is recommended by the WHO to establish sufficient genetic counselling centers in places where infectious diseases and nutritional disorders have been brought under good control. These centers should also be set up in areas where genetic diseases like sickle cell anemia and thalassemia are a major public health concern.

Other options:

Option A - Prospective genetic counselling is an approach used where heterozygous individuals for any particular defect are identified by screening procedures prospectively. The risk of giving birth to affected children if they marry another heterozygous individual with the same defect is been explained to them. This approach is used to reduce the number of heterozygous marriages. This method is applied in diseases like sickle cell anemia and thalassemia.

Option C - Positive eugenics aims at improving the genetic constitution of the population by encouraging people who carry desirable genotypes to bear the burden of becoming parents.

Option D - Euthenics is an approach in which people are given access to a suitable environment to improve their genotype. This is a more practical approach to prevent genetic diseases as it involves the mutual interaction of heredity and environmental factors.

questions.text: A 6-year-old boy presents with recurrent chest infections. He passes frequent bulky greasy stools. He has also failed to gain weight despite a large appetite. On evaluation, the chloride concentration in his sweat is >60 mEq/L. Which of the following is most likely to be seen in this patient?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of cystic fibrosis. In this condition, hyponatremic hypochloremic alkalosis is seen.

Excessive loss of salt in the sweat predisposes young children to salt-depletion episodes. Therefore, these children present with hypochloremic alkalosis, resulting in increased serum bicarbonate levels. 

Cystic fibrosis or mucoviscidosis is an autosomal recessive disorder with a mutation in the cystic fibrosis transmembrane regulator (CFTR) gene on chromosome 7q. The most common CFTR mutation is F508 deletion.

CFTR gene encodes for ATP-gated chloride channels in the apical membranes of epithelial cells. It regulates the flow of ions across epithelial membranes of sweat glands, respiratory airways, pancreatic ducts, etc. The defect leads to high salt concentrations in sweat and viscous luminal secretions in the respiratory and gastrointestinal tracts.

Clinical manifestations/ complications of cystic fibrosis include:
  • Sinusitis and nasal polyps
  • Respiratory - copious hyper-viscous and adherent pulmonary secretions with abnormal mucociliary clearance obstruct small and medium-sized airways leading to respiratory compromise. The disease can be further complicated by bronchiectasis and allergic bronchopulmonary aspergillosis (ABPA).
  • Gastrointestinal - 
    • Thick and adherent exocrine secretions obstruct pancreatic ducts and impair the production and flow of digestive enzymes
    • Tissue destruction of the exocrine pancreas, with fibrotic scarring, cyst proliferation, and loss of acinar tissue - fat malabsorption, steatorrhea, fat-soluble vitamin deficiencies
    • Obstruction of intrahepatic bile ducts and parenchymal fibrosis leading to hepatic insufficiency and focal biliary cirrhosis
    • Distal intestinal obstructive syndrome in adults and meconium ileus in neonates
  • Reproductive - males have infertility due to the congenital absence of bilateral vas deferens and defective sperm transport, resulting in obstructive azoospermia. Females have infertility due to abnormalities of the reproductive tract secretions.

 The diagnosis is confirmed if both of the following criteria are met:

  • Presence of
    • Clinical symptoms affecting at least one organ system (respiratory, gastrointestinal, or genitourinary) or
    • Positive newborn screening or
    • A sibling with cystic fibrosis
  • Evidence of dysfunction of the CFTR gene by
    • Two positive sweat chloride test results were obtained on separate days or
    • Identification of two CFTR mutations by genetic testing or
    • An abnormal measurement of nasal potential difference

Cystic fibrosis requires a multidisciplinary approach to management. The correction of the defect can be via:

  • Lumacaftor, an FDA-approved drug that corrects the misfolding and reverts the Phe508del mutation defect
  • Ivacaftor potentiates CFTR channel opening and stimulates ion transport

End-stage pulmonary failure requires lung transplantation.

questions.text: Which of the following statement best describes a partial agonist?

choices.text: High affinity and high intrinsic activity
High affinity and low intrinsic activity
Low affinity and high intrinsic activity
High affinity and zero intrinsic activity

questions.solution:
Partial agonists have high affinity and low intrinsic activity.

According to the receptor occupation theory, the ability of a drug to bind to a receptor is its affinity, and the ability to induce functional change in the receptor is designated as the intrinsic activity (IA) of the drug. These 2 properties are independent of each other.

  • Full agonists: These agents have both affinity and maximum intrinsic activity. Examples are histamine, adrenaline, etc.
  • Partial agonists: They have affinity but submaximal intrinsic activity. e.g pentazocine on µ opiod receptors.
  • Inverse agonists are drugs that have an affinity for a receptor but the intrinsic activity is opposite to that of an agonist. Eg: chlorpheniramine on H1 receptors.
  • Competitive antagonists: These agents have affinity and no intrinsic activity. Eg:propanolol, atropine etc.

The intrinsic activities of the above groups of drugs are given below:

Type of drugs

Intrinsic activity

Agonists

1

Partial agonists

>0 to <1

Competitive antagonists

0

Inverse agonists

<0 to -1

questions.text: A 26-year-old pregnant woman in her 30th week of gestation was found to have an amniotic fluid index (AFI) of 4 cm. Which among the following options could be a cause of this presentation?
questions.solution:
Amniotic fluid index (AFI) less than 5 cm suggests oligohydramnios, among the given options amnion nodosum is a cause of oligohydramnios, the other options are causes of polyhydramnios.

Oligohydramnios is defined as:

  • Amniotic fluid volume less than 200 ml
  • AFI less than 5 cm
  • The maximum vertical pocket of liquor is less than 2 cm

Causes of oligohydramnios are amnion nodosum (failure of secretion by the cells of the amnion covering the placenta), postmaturity, renal agenesis, obstructive uropathy, maternal usage of prostaglandin inhibitors, angiotensin-converting enzyme inhibitors, etc.

Polyhydramnios is defined as:

  • Amniotic fluid volume of more than 2L
  • AFI more than 25 cm
  • A deepest vertical pocket is more than 8 cm 

Causes of polyhydramnios are anencephaly, cleft palate, facial clefts, hydrops fetalis, maternal diabetes, esophageal or duodenal atresia, open spina bifida, aneuploidy, chorioangioma of the placenta, infections like cytomegalovirus, toxoplasmosis, etc.

questions.text: The following muscle is marked in the anatomy practical exam, the examiner asks you to provide the origin, insertion, and nerve supply of it. What would your answer be?

choices.text: Origin:  Radius, Insertion: Ulna, Nerve supply: Median nerve
Origin:  Radius, Insertion: Ulna, Nerve supply: Radial nerve
Origin: Ulna, Insertion: Radius, Nerve supply: Median nerve
Origin: Ulna, Insertion: Radius, Nerve supply: Radial nerve

questions.solution:
The marked structure in the image is the pronator quadratus muscle. The answer is origin: Ulna, insertion: Radius, nerve supply: Median nerve. 

The pronator quadratus is a flat quadrilateral-shaped muscle, that extends across the front of the distal ends of the radius and ulna. It arises from the anterior surface of the shaft of the ulna and inserts into the shaft of the radius and the ulnar notch of the radius.

The pronator quadratus is innervated by the median nerve (C7 and 8). It is supplied by the anterior interosseus artery. It causes the pronation of the forearm at the radioulnar joint.

questions.text:
A 61-year-old man presented with weight loss, easy fatiguability, and bone pain for 6 months duration. A bone marrow aspirate is shown in the image below. Immunohistochemistry was negative for tDt but was positive for MPO. Cytogenetic studies revealed the presence of t(15:17). What is the likely diagnosis in this case?

MPO: Myeloperoxidase

TDT : Terminal deoxynucleotidyl transferase 

Hb- 9g/dl

RBC-1million/cumm

WBC-50,000/cumm

Platelet-30,000/microliter
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario of an elderly man presenting with anemia, thrombocytopenia, positive MPO in immunohistochemistry, characteristic translocation(15;17), and peripheral smear showing faggot cells is suggestive of acute myeloid leukemia (AML).

AML is a hematopoietic progenitor malignancy that causes immature myeloblast accumulation in the bone marrow.  Incidence increases with age and peaks after 60 years of age. Occupational exposure to benzene leads to epoxide formation which in turn predisposes to the development of AML. Clinically, the patients present with symptoms resulting due to pancytopenia (anemia, neutropenia, thrombocytopenia). There is generalised fatigue, bone pain, bleeding tendencies and an increased risk of recurrent infections. Hemorrhagic complications such as disseminated intravascular coagulation may be seen more commonly in a subtype of AML, acute promyelocytic leukemia.

Other distinctive features of AML include

  • Bone marrow/peripheral smear shows a large, uniform population of cells (myeloblasts) with prominent nucleoli (yellow arrow). It shows the presence of primary cytoplasmic granules
  • Auer rods: needle-shaped azurophilic intracytoplasmic inclusion bodies formed by the fusion of lysosomes. (black arrow)
  • Multiple Auer rods clustered together within a single cell resembling a bundle of sticks known as faggot cells (seen in peripheral smear).
  • This is characteristic of acute promyelocytic leukemia (AML M3) or AML associated with PML-RARɑ fusion gene or t(15;17). Other cytogenetic abnormalities, seen in AML are t(8;21) and inversion 16. 

For acute myeloblastic leukemia (AML) diagnosis, the blast cell count should be ≥20% in the peripheral blood or bone marrow

The treatment of choice for AML-M3 with t(15;17) is all-trans-retinoic acid (ATRA).

Other options:

Option A- Acute lymphoblastic leukemia (ALL) arises from immature B (pre-B) or T (pre-T) cells called lymphoblasts. Immunohistochemistry for terminal deoxynucleotidyl transferase (TdT) is positive in pre-B and pre-T lymphoblasts. Peripheral smear shows lymphoblasts that have condensed chromatin, less conspicuous nucleoli, and smaller amounts of cytoplasm which lacks granules as shown below.

Option B- Chronic lymphocytic leukaemia is associated with the deletions of 13q, 11q, 17q, and trisomy 12q. Lymph nodes are diffusely effaced by small lymphocytes with proliferation centres. The image shows small round lymphocytes and smudge cells seen in CLL.

Option D- Chronic myeloid leukemia is characterised by the presence of a Philadelphia chromosome resulting from reciprocal translocation t(9;22) forming the BCR-ABL fusion gene. They have a hypercellular marrow due to a massively increased number of maturing granulocytic precursors. The image below shows peripheral smear findings of CML with neutrophils, myelocytes, metamyelocytes, and band cells.

Related Pearl: WHO classification of Acute Myeloid Leukemia (AML)

The 5th edition of WHO (2022) classification classifies acute myeloid leukemia (AML) as follows:

  • AML with RUNX1::RUNX1T1 fusion
  • AML with CBFB::MYH11 fusion

  • AML with RBM15::MRTFA fusion
  • AML with BCR::ABL1 fusion
  • AML with KMT2A rearrangement*
  • AML with MECOM rearrangement
  • AML with NUP98 rearrangement
  • AML with NPM1 mutation
  • AML with CEBPA mutation
  • AML, myelodysplasia-related#
  • AML with other defined genetic alterations

  • AML with minimal differentiation
  • AML without maturation
  • AML with maturation
  • Acute basophilic leukaemia
  • Acute myelomonocytic leukaemia
  • Acute monocytic leukaemia
  • Acute erythroid leukaemia
  • Acute megakaryoblastic leukemia

Most AML with defining genetic abnormalities are diagnosed with < 20% blasts except AML with BCR: ABL1 and AML with CEBPA mutation that require at least 20% blasts for diagnosis.

*AML with KMT2A rearrangement is the new term that replaces “AML with t(9;11)(p22;q23); KMT2A-MLLT3

#AML with myelodysplasia-related changes has been renamed as AML, myelodysplasia-related (AML-MR).

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman with 8 weeks of amenorrhea and a positive urinary pregnancy test presented with mild pain abdomen and slight bleeding per vaginum for 5 days. She was diagnosed with cervical pregnancy. Which of the following criteria is used for the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Cervical pregnancy can be diagnosed using Rubin's criteria.

Cervical pregnancy is a type of ectopic pregnancy where the implantation occurs in the cervical canal at the level of or below the internal os.

Rubin's criteria for pathological diagnosis of cervical pregnancies:

  • Soft, enlarged cervix equal to or larger than the fundus.
  • Uterine bleeding following amenorrhea, without cramping pain.
  • Products of conception are entirely confined within and firmly attached to the endocervix.
  • A closed internal cervical os and a partially opened external os.

Transvaginal sonographic findings of cervical pregnancy include:

  • An hourglass uterine shape and ballooned cervical canal
  • Gestational tissue at the level of the cervix 
  • Absent intrauterine gestational tissue
  • A portion of the endocervical canal is interposed between the gestation and the endometrial canal.

Treatment: Medical management with methotrexate if vitals are stable and it is diagnosed in the first trimester. Surgical management with suction curettage or hysterectomy is done if vitals are unstable, bleeding uncontrolled, or if the gestation is advanced.

Prior to any procedure, uterine artery embolization, local methotrexate injection into the amnionic sac, ligation of the uterine arteries, or cerclage at the internal os to compress feeding vessels may be done to control bleeding.

The image below shows an ultrasonogram of cervical pregnancy.

Other options:

Option A: Spiegelberg’s criteria is used in the diagnosis of ovarian pregnancy.

  • The tube on the affected side must be intact
  • The gestational sac must occupy the position of the ovary
  • Gestational sac connected to the uterus by ovarian ligament
  • Definite ovarian tissue must be found in the sac wall

Option B: Godin's sonographic criteria is for the diagnosis of a cesarean scar pregnancy

  • Empty uterine cavity
  • Empty cervical canal
  • A gestational sac in the anterior part of the uterine isthmus
  • Absence of healthy myometrium between the bladder and gestational sac

Option D: Studdiford criteria is used in the diagnosis of primary abdominal pregnancy. It includes:

  • Presence of normal tubes and ovaries with no evidence of recent or past injury/pregnancy.
  • Absence of uteroperitoneal fistula.
  • Presence of a pregnancy-related exclusively to the peritoneal surface and early enough to eliminate the possibility of secondary implantation after primary tubal nidation.

questions.text: A young myopic male presents with intermittent haloes.  Gonioscopy reveals an open angle and hyperpigmented trabecular meshwork. Slit-lamp examination is shown below. This finding is called as
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and the slit lamp findings are suggestive of pigmentary glaucoma. The slit lamp image shows a pattern of pigment deposition on the back of the cornea called Krukenberg spindles. 

Pigmentary glaucoma is a type of secondary glaucoma more common in young myopic males and they usually have hyperpigmented trabecular meshwork and an open-angle on gonioscopy. It occurs due to the blockage of the trabecular meshwork by the pigment particles that are released from rubbing the iris pigment epithelium.

The patients are asymptomatic and usually presents for a routine ophthalmic check-up or may present with intermittent haloes at times. It has the following features:

  • The pigment particles are deposited on the corneal endothelium in a vertical spindle shape called Krukenberg spindles as seen in slit lamp examination. 
  • Radial transillumination defect on the illumination of the iris is a pathognomonic feature.
  • Gonioscopy shows pigment accumulation along the Schwalbe line inferiorly called the Sampaolesi line.
  • Pigment granules may be deposited on the anterior surface of the lens. There may be a Scheie line or Zentmayer ring of pigment on the peripheral/equatorial surface around the zonular insertions.
  • Some patients may exhibit higher levels of IOP(Intraocular pressure) than in POAG. Over time the control of IOP may become easier as pigment liberation decreases and occasionally the IOP may revert to normal. So, it is not always high. 
 

The image shows iris transillumination in the slit-lamp examination, clearly showing a pigmentary defect in the areas of chronic rubbing due to iridolenticular and intraocular lens haptic contact with the posterior face of the iris.

 

Other options:

Option A: Polychromatic lustre or breadcrumb appearance is characteristic of a complicated/secondary cataract which develops secondary to inflammatory and degenerative conditions of the lens of the eye. The given image shows a complicated cataract in a patient with uveitis. 

 

Option B: Aqueous flares occur due to the breakdown in the blood-aqueous barrier, and protein exudates escape into the anterior chamber. It seen in anterior uveitis. The below-given image shows the presence of cells and aqueous flare in a case of anterior uveitis.

 

Option C: Old healing keratic precipitates are seen in the healing stages of uveitis. The earliest sign of anterior uveitis is aqueous flare and the pathognomonic sign is keratic precipitate. The image below shows the slit-lamp photograph showing large old keratic precipitates.

questions.text: A 22-year-old G2P1, at 8 weeks of gestation, comes to you to know the mode of delivery that will be used for her present pregnancy. In her previous pregnancy, she had undergone a Cesarean section with a classical incision for unknown indication. Which of the following is the correct response?
questions.solution:
Vaginal birth is contraindicated in a patient who has undergone a previous classical cesarean section.

Women who have undergone classical cesarean section, are at a high risk of scar dehiscence and uterine rupture and have lesser chances of successful vaginal birth in subsequent pregnancies. Importantly, in some women, a classical scar will rupture before labor onset, and this can happen several weeks before term.

In these patients, any form of a trial of labor is contraindicated. Vaginal birth is contraindicated, forceps/vacuum-assisted, or otherwise (option B and C).

Women who have undergone an LSCS (lower segment cesarean section) are allowed a trial of labor due to a lower risk of uterine rupture.

Risk factors for a vaginal birth after cesarean section (VBAC) :

Low risk High risk

● Transverse incision

● Prior vaginal delivery

● Sufficient personnel and equipment

● Classical or T incision in prior cesarean

● Prior rupture

● Obstetrical contraindication such as placenta previa

● Inadequate facilities (most consider these high-risk factors as contraindications)

Classical Cesarean Indications:

Maternal:

  • Densely adhered bladder from previous surgery
  • Leiomyoma occupies the lower uterine segment
  • Cervical cancer
  • Massive maternal obesity
  • Placenta previa with anterior implantation

Fetal:

  • A transverse lie of a large fetus
  • Impacted shoulder
  • Multiple fetuses

questions.text: A 14-year-old boy presents with pain in the right leg accompanied by symptoms of fever and fatigue. His X-ray of the leg is given below. Which of the following is false regarding this condition?
questions.solution:
The above clinical features and X-ray point to the diagnosis of Ewing's sarcoma. It is a highly radio-sensitive tumor. 

Ewing sarcoma is the 2nd most common bone sarcoma in children. The majority of the patients affected are usually <20 years of age. It has a slight male predominance. The majority of Ewing sarcomas have a balanced translocation between the EWSR1 gene on chromosome 22 and the FLI1 gene on chromosome 11. 

It commonly involves the diaphysis of the long bones like the femur, tibia, fibula, humerus, and flat bones of the pelvis. Patients present with painful enlarging mass, fever, and anemia. The affected area is usually tender, swollen, and warm.

Laboratory findings may show an elevated WBC count, LDH levels (lactate dehydrogenase) and erythrocyte sedimentation rate (ESR). The common diagnostic test used for Ewing’s sarcoma is the detection of translocation t(11;22) (q24;q12). An onion peel appearance is characteristic on imaging.

A histopathological examination of Ewing sarcoma shows sheets of uniform, round blue cells arranged in Homer-Wright rosettes. Immunohistochemistry is usually positive for synaptophysin and mic-2. The tumor cells contain glycogen and are hence PAS positive and they are reticulin negative.

Preoperative chemotherapy with vincristine, ifosfamide, doxorubicin and etoposide results in extensive tumor necrosis and shrinkage. Wide excision may be combined with adjuvant radiotherapy if surgical margins are poor. Definitive radiotherapy rather than surgical excision may be advocated if it is non-resectable or metastasis has occurred. It is a radio-sensitive tumor.

Indicators of poor prognosis in patients with Ewing's sarcoma:

  • Presence of distant metastasis - worst prognostic factor
  • Size and location of the primary lesion
  • Presence of fever, anemia
  • Leukocytosis, raised ESR. 

Related Pearl: Important radiosenstive and radioresistant bone tumours

Radiosensitive tumors:

  1. Metastasis (except metastasis from renal cell carcinoma which is radioresistant)
  2. Ewing's sarcoma
  3. Multiple myeloma
  4. Lymphoma

Radioresistant tumors:

  1. Osteosarcoma
  2. Chondrosarcoma

questions.text: A 62-year-old man presents with abdominal pain and melena. UGI endoscopy reveals a smooth, round tumor with central ulceration in the stomach. Microscopy is as below. Which of the following is correct regarding this tumor?

choices.text: Wedge resection with lymphadenectomy is primary treatment

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario, endoscopic findings, and the histological image showing spindle-shaped tumor cells are suggestive of gastrointestinal stromal tumor (GIST). It is a radioresistant tumor and does not respond to conventional chemotherapy. 

GIST are the most common mesenchymal tumor of the abdomen, the stomach being the most common site. They arise from the interstitial cells of Cajal, the pacemaker cells of the GIT. GIST is seen in the 5th to 6th decade of life and has an equal preponderance among males and females. Most patients present with haematemesis, melena, or vague abdominal pain. The most common indications for surgery include bleeding and obstruction.

The GIST may occur in a sporadic form or as part of familial syndromes. In sporadic GIST, the most common mutations seen are gain-of-function mutation in KIT (75-80%) and PDGFRA mutation (8%). Microscopically, GIST has elongated spindle cells or plumper epithelioid cells, or a mixed pattern.

The below image shows the microscopy of GIST composed of bundles, or fascicles, of spindle-shaped tumor cells.

Succinate dehydrogenase (SDH)-deficient GIST is a subset of wild-type GIST seen with Carney triad or Carney-Stratakis syndrome. It is c-KIT & PDGFRA negative. 

The management of GIST is as follows,

Gastrointestinal Stromal Tumor (GIST) Treatment of choice
Low risk of malignancy Complete surgical resection + Surveillance
Intermediate to high risk of malignancy Complete surgical resection + adjuvant Imatinib for 3 years
Unresectable Neoadjuvant Imatinib
Metastatic Imatinib

Imatinib can be used to treat GIST with mutations in KIT or PDGFRA. Succinate dehydrogenase (SDH) - deficient GIST is imatinib-resistant, so sunitinib, sorafenib, or regorafenib can be used instead.

During surgical resection of GIST, care must be taken to prevent capsule rupture, which causes seeding of nearby tissues leading to relapse in 100% of the cases. If capsule rupture occurs, adjuvant therapy with imatinib is indicated regardless of tumor extent.

Other options:

Option A: GIST does not respond to conventional chemotherapy. They respond to targeted chemotherapy (tyrosine kinase inhibitors) such as imatinib.

Option C: Lymphadenectomy is not done in GIST as it usually does not show lymph node metastasis.

Option D: Gastrointestinal stromal tumours (GIST), which are succinate dehydrogenase deficient (SDH) do not respond to treatment with imatinib.

Related Pearl: Gastrointestinal Stromal Tumor (GIST)

M/C mesenchymal tumor of GIT arising from interstitial cells of Cajal (pacemaker cells of GIT). Stomach is the m/c site.

GISTs express:

  • c-KIT (CD117)
  • PDGF receptor A
  • CD34
  • SDH

Clinical Features:

  • Peaks at 60 years of age.
  • M/C symptom: Upper GI bleeding
  • Other symptoms: Pain, lump, perforation, incidental finding
  • Carney's Triad: Sporadic GIST, Paraganglioma, Pulmonary chondroma

Management:

  • IOC for primary GIST: CECT abdomen
  • IOC for recurrent GIST: PET-CT
  • IHC markers: CD117/C-KIT (M/C), DOG 1 (most specific), CD 34
  • Route of metastasis: Hematogenous

The following image shows microscopy of GIST composed of spindle-shaped tumor cells:

  • Fletcher's classification (Tumor size & No. of mitotic figures) is used to classify the tumors according to their malignancy risk.
  • Prognosis is determined by: Mitotic index, tumor size & location of tumor (Stomach GISTs are less aggressive).
  • Complete surgical resection is the mainstay treatment. For unresectable, recurrent, or metastatic GISTs, imatinib, a tyrosine kinase inhibitor, can be used.

questions.text: A researcher conducts a study among smokers. He finds that 80% of the cases of lung cancer are due to cigarette smoking. This is indicative of:
questions.solution:
The study where the researcher finds that 80% of lung cancer cases are due to cigarette smoking is indicative of attributable risk.

Attributable risk (AR) is the difference in incidence rates of disease between an exposed group and an unexposed group.

It is indicative of the extent of the disease attributed to the exposure. It also refers to the amount of disease that could be eliminated if the exposure is controlled or eliminated. It reflects the impact of public health programs in the prevention of the disease.

Other options:

Option A: Incidence of a disease refers to the number of new cases occurring in a population in a given period of time.

Option B: Relative risk refers to the ratio of incidence of the disease among the exposed and the incidence of disease among the unexposed population. It establishes the strength of association between the disease and the suspected causative factor.

Option D: Population attributable risk refers to the incidence of the disease in the total population minus the incidence of disease among the population unexposed to the causative factor. It indicates the incidence of disease that could be prevented in the total population if the suspected causative factor was eliminated. 

Related Pearl: Relative and Attributable Risk

Relative Risk:

  • Ratio of incidence of disease or death among exposed to that among the non-exposed is called relative risk (RR).
  • It is also called risk ratio.
  • It is the direct measure of the strength of association between suspected cause and effect in cohort studies.
  • RR < 1 indicates inverse association(protective effect)
  • RR = 1 indicates no association.
  • RR > 1 indicates positive association.
  • RR of 2 indicates a 100% increase in risk.
  • Relative risk calculation (RR) = [ a/(a+b) ]/ [ c/(c+d) ] where,

Attributable Risk:

  • Attributable risk (AR) is the difference in incidence rates or proportions of disease or death between an exposed and non-exposed group.
  • It is expressed in percentage and gives the extent to which the disease can be attributed to the exposure in a cohort study.

questions.text: You are visiting a rural area for a vaccination drive conducted under the Intensified Mission Indradhanush scheme. Which of the following vaccines is not included in the scheme?
questions.solution:
The typhoid vaccine is not included in the Intensified Mission Indradhanush scheme. 

The Intensified Mission Indradhanush has been introduced to ensure full immunization (more than 90%) by December 2018. It now includes 12 vaccine-preventable diseases (updated from the 7 VPDs that Mission Indradhanush focussed on). 4 rounds of immunisation are proposed to be held for 7 days each month. The diseases are:

  • Tuberculosis
  • Polio
  • Hepatitis B
  • Diphtheria
  • Pertussis
  • Tetanus
  • Measles 

The diseases included recently in Intensified Mission Indradhanush are:

  • Rotavirus diarrhoea
  • Rubella (as MR vaccine)
  • H. influenzae B diseases (as part of the pentavalent vaccine)
  • Pneumococcal meningitis
  • Japanese Encephalitis

 

 

The purpose of Intensified Mission Indradhanush is to reach each and every child under 2 years of age and all those pregnant women who have been left uncovered under the routine immunization coverage. It has been launched by the Government of India in October 2017.

In february 2020, the government launched Intensified Mission Indradhanush (IMI). The aim is to reach out to partially vaccinated and unvaccinated children with all the available vaccines under Universal Immunization Program (UIP) across 381 districts in 29 States/UTs.

questions.text: An elderly male patient was found to have hallucinations and vivid dreams following induction with an intravenous anesthetic agent. Which among the following is the most effective drug to reduce the incidence and severity of these post-operative reactions?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of emergence reaction or delirium most commonly associated with ketamine. Benzodiazepines are the most effective in reducing the incidence and severity of these postoperative reactions.

Emergence reactions seen with ketamine during emergence from anesthesia are vivid dreaming, hallucinations, extracorporeal experiences, and delusions associated with confusion, euphoria, and fear. These reactions occur in individuals with psychological susceptibility and when large doses of ketamine are rapidly administered. 

Benzodiazepines (BZD) act by facilitating the action of GABA receptors. It acts by increasing the frequency of opening of GABA-mediated chloride channels, thereby hyperpolarizing the neurons and inhibiting their activity.

Uses of Benzodiazepines include

  • Antiepileptics: Lorazepam is the drug of choice for status epilepticus, delirium tremens, catatonia, and patients with liver dysfunction
  • Generalized anxiety disorders, panic disorders
  • Intravenous induction agent - Lorazepam
  • Sedative premedication in children - Midazolam
  • Muscle relaxant 

Other options: 

Phenobarbitone is a barbiturate primarily used in the treatment of generalised tonic-clonic and focal seizures.

Flumazenil is the benzodiazepine antagonist and is used in BZD overdose.

Carbamazepine is an anti-epileptic used in the management of generalised tonic-clonic and focal seizures. It is also used in bipolar disorder and in trigeminal neuralgias.

questions.text: An infant was brought to OPD with complaints of copious nasal discharge. On examination, there was a clouding of the cornea and hepatomegaly. The developmental assessment showed significant delay. An x-ray of the chest was taken and is given below. Which of the following enzyme is defective in this child?
questions.solution:
In the given clinical scenario presence of corneal clouding with hepatomegaly with developmental delay and the X-ray showing oar-shaped ribs is suggestive of Hurler's syndrome and the enzyme deficient in this condition is α-L-Iduronidase.

Hurler's syndrome is a severe type of mucopolysaccharidoses (MPS) - I. It is caused due to deficiency of α-L-iduronidase. This enzyme is required for the breakdown of dermatan and heparan sulfate. The deficiency of the enzyme leads to the accumulation of these mucopolysaccharides. 

Affected children usually present between 6-24 months of age. Clinical features include hepatosplenomegaly, coarse facial features, corneal clouding, large tongue, enlarged head circumference, joint stiffness, short stature, skeletal dysplasia, recurrent upper respiratory tract and ear infections, noisy breathing, and persistent copious nasal discharge. Children with Hurler's syndrome have impaired language function because of intellectual disability which occurs due to the accumulation of heparan sulfate and combined conductive and sensorineural hearing loss.

Skeletal dysplasia, called dysostosis multiplex includes oar-shaped ribs(widening of anterior ribs), ovoid vertebral bodies, enlarged diaphyses of the long bones, macrocephaly, and enlarged J-shaped sella.

The image below shows coarse facial features and the radiograph shows enlarged diaphyses of the metacarpal and phalanges.

Other options:  

Option A: Hunter syndrome is a type II MPS. It occurs due to the deficiency of iduronate 2-sulfatase. It shares the same features of type I MPS like coarse facial features, short stature, and dysostosis multiplex. However, there is no corneal clouding. It is the only MPS which X-linked recessive inheritance. So if a female baby is affected in the family, it is less likely to be Hunter syndrome. 

Option B: Sanfilippo syndrome A or MPS type III-A occurs due to the deficiency of heparan sulfate-N-sulfatase enzyme, leading to the accumulation of heparan sulfate. The affected children usually have delayed milestones and motor dysfunction.

Option C: Sanfilippo syndrome B or MPS type III-B occurs due to the deficiency of α-N-Acetylglucosaminidase enzyme, leading to the accumulation of heparan sulfate. The affected children usually have delayed milestones and motor dysfunction.

questions.text: A mother brings her 9-year-old child with complaints of polyuria. On examination, he has growth failure and bitemporal hemianopia. Laboratory evaluation reveals low urine osmolality and high plasma osmolality. Findings on the MRI brain are given below. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario along with MRI showing intracranial mass with foci of calcification at sella turcica and the laboratory findings suggestive of diabetes insipidus point to a diagnosis of craniopharyngioma.

Craniopharyngiomas are tumors that arise from the remnants of Rathke’s pouch. It is an intracranial space-occupying lesion. It has bimodal age of presentation. Children usually present with frequent headaches, short stature, bitemporal hemianopsia (due to optic chiasm compression), and polyuria.

These tumors are usually large and heterogeneous, displaying both solid and cystic components, and occur within the suprasellar area. The cysts contain a cholesterol-rich, thick brownish-yellow fluid and are compared to machine oil. They also show radiologically demonstrable calcification.

Treatment of central diabetes insipidus caused by craniopharyngioma includes supplementation with vasopressin analogs desmopressin (DDAVP) and resection of the tumor.

Other options:

Option B: Germinomas of the pituitary stalk also cause central diabetes insipidus. However, they are often missed in routine neuroimaging. 

Option C: Pituitary microadenomas usually present incidentally or with endocrine effects. They are <10mm in size and the tumor is confined to the sella. Visual field deficits are usually caused by pituitary macroadenomas. 

Option D: Langerhans cell histiocytosis is a rare cause of central diabetes insipidus. Symptoms include dermatological manifestations such as red, scaly papules, pain, and swelling in the limbs, characteristic bony lesions, and disseminated lymph node enlargement.

questions.text:
An elderly patient presented with tremors, rigidity, bradykinesia, and visual hallucinations. On examination, mild cognitive impairment was noted. CSF analysis showed alpha-synuclein oligomers. What is the most likely diagnosis?

CSF- Cerebrospinal fluid
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario, along with the findings of alpha-synuclein in CSF, is suggestive of Lewy body dementia.

Lewy body dementia is the second most common type of dementia after Alzheimer's disease and vascular dementia. It is characterized by the protein deposition of Lewy bodies in the substantia nigra, limbic system, and cerebral cortex, comprising α-synuclein and ubiquitin. Thus, they are classified under synucleinopathies.

The image given below shows immunohistochemistry showing positive staining (brown) for alpha-synuclein of an intraneural Lewy-body:

 

The core clinical features are (the first three typically occur early and may persist throughout the course):

  • Fluctuating cognition with pronounced variations in attention and alertness.
  • Recurrent visual hallucinations are typically well-formed and detailed.
  • REM sleep behavior disorder may precede cognitive decline.
  • One or more spontaneous cardinal features of Parkinsonism (bradykinesia, rest tremor, rigidity).
  • Sensitivity to neuroleptics - severe adverse reactions if treated with antipsychotics

Other features are mood disorders like depression, anxiety, and autonomic disturbances like orthostatic hypotension, and constipation.

The mainstay of treatment here is symptomatic management which includes cholinesterase inhibitors (rivastigmine, galantamine, or donepezil), atypical antipsychotics, and SSRIs. Highly potent typical antipsychotics like haloperidol are contraindicated in this condition due to extreme neuroleptic sensitivity.

Related Pearl: Revised criteria for the clinical diagnosis of probable and possible dementia with Lewy bodies (DLB)

  • Essential for a diagnosis of DLB is dementia, defined as a progressive cognitive decline of sufficient magnitude to interfere with normal social or occupational functions, or with usual daily activities.
  • Prominent or persistent memory impairment may not necessarily occur in the early stages but is usually evident with progression.
  • Deficits on tests of attention, executive function, and visuoperceptual ability may be especially prominent and occur early.

Core clinical features (The first 3 typically occur early and may persist throughout the course.)

  • Fluctuating cognition with pronounced variations in attention and alertness.
  • Recurrent visual hallucinations that are typically well formed and detailed.
  • REM sleep behavior disorder, which may precede cognitive decline.
  • One or more spontaneous cardinal features of Parkinsonism: these are bradykinesia (defined as slowness of movement and decrement in amplitude or speed), rest tremor, or rigidity.

Supportive clinical features:

  • Severe sensitivity to antipsychotic agents; postural instability; repeated falls; syncope or other transient episodes of unresponsiveness; severe autonomic dysfunction, e.g., constipation, orthostatic hypotension, urinary incontinence; hypersomnia; hyposmia; hallucinations in other modalities; systematized delusions; apathy, anxiety, and depression.

Indicative biomarkers

  • Reduced dopamine transporter uptake in basal ganglia demonstrated by SPECT or PET.
  • Abnormal (low uptake) 123iodine-MIBG myocardial scintigraphy.
  • Polysomnographic confirmation of REM sleep without atonia.

  • Relative preservation of medial temporal lobe structures on CT/MRI scan.
  • Generalized low uptake on SPECT/PET perfusion/metabolism scan with reduced occipital activity ± the cingulate island sign on FDG-PET imaging.
  • Prominent posterior slow-wave activity on EEG with periodic fluctuations in the pre-alpha/ theta range.

A. Probable DLB can be diagnosed if:

  • Two or more core clinical features of DLB are present, with or without the presence of indicative biomarkers, or
  • Only one core clinical feature is present, but with one or more indicative biomarkers

Note: Probable DLB should not be diagnosed on the basis of biomarkers alone

B. Possible DLB can be diagnosed if:

  • Only one core clinical feature of DLB is present, with no indicative biomarker evidence, or
  • One or more indicative biomarkers is present but there are no core clinical features.

questions.text: An elderly female patient presented with spontaneous gingival bleeding. After a detailed lab workup, she was diagnosed to have an acquired Von Willebrand disease. All of the following conditions are associated with acquired Von Willebrand disease except?
questions.solution:
Acquired von Willebrand disease (VWD) is caused by all of the above conditions except for immune thrombocytopenic purpura.

Acquired VWD is an acquired bleeding disorder. It occurs due to autoantibodies directed against von Willebrand factor (vWF) resulting in rapid clearance of vWF from the circulation and/or inactivation of plasma vWF.

Causes of acquired VWD include:

  • Multiple myeloma, Waldenstrom's macroglobulinemia, monoclonal gammopathy of unknown significance
  • Chronic myeloid leukemia
  • Polycythemia Vera
  • Solid tumors
  • Systemic lupus erythematosus
  • Aortic stenosis (Heyde's syndrome)

Treatment of acquired VWD includes treating the underlying condition, infusion of vWF-rich concentrates, or desmopressin (DDAVP).

questions.text: Three days after being initiated on a certain enzyme inhibiting drug, a patient developed sharply demarcated skin lesions with necrosis and slow-healing eschar formation, as shown in the image given below. Which of the following drugs was likely started for this patient?
questions.solution:
A patient developing skin necrosis a few days after starting a new drug is likely to be suffering from warfarin-induced skin necrosis.

Warfarin is an anti-coagulant which acts by competitive inhibition of the enzyme vitamin K epoxide reductase thereby preventing the activation of coagulation factors II, VII, IX, X and proteins C and S. Adverse effects of warfarin are bleeding, skin necrosis, purple toe syndrome, and fetal warfarin syndrome (hypoplasia of the nose, eye socket, hand bones, and growth retardation). Skin necrosis is a rare, potentially life-threatening side-effect of warfarin use that usually begins 2-5 days after initiation of therapy.

Individuals with Protein C & S deficiency are, particularly at risk for developing warfarin-induced skin necrosis. This is because these proteins, which are anti-thrombotic, have a shorter half-life as compared to the clotting factors inhibited by warfarin. Initiation of warfarin caused a sudden drop in the levels of protein C and S before they inhibit the clotting factors, due to which there is hypercoagulability and consequent thrombosis of microvasculature which leads to necrosis. The toes, thighs, buttocks and breasts are commonly involved.

This adverse effect can be prevented by co-administration of warfarin with a parenteral anticoagulant such as heparin in the initial few days, until the therapeutic INR range is achieved, before continuing with warfarin alone.

Treatment of this condition is by immediately discontinuing warfarin. Vitamin K can be administered for reversal of the drug effect. Patients are started on an alternative anticoagulant such as heparin or LMWH.

Other Options:

Option B: Aspirin acts by irreversibly inhibiting the enzymes cyclo-oxygenase and thromboxane. It is an antiplatelet drug and the most important side effects include bleeding tendencies. 

Option C: Atorvastatin is a statin drug which inhibits the enzyme HMG CoA reductase. Important side effects inclue myositis and hepatotoxicity.

Option D: Levofloxacin is a fluoroquinolone which inhibits the enzyme DNA gyrase. Important side effects include cartilage damage in children and Achilles tendon rupture in adults.

  • Warfarin: vitamin K

questions.text: A woman from rural South America presents with shortness of breath and palpitations. Examination of the eye is shown in the image given below. Echocardiography reveals biventricular dilatation with massive cardiac enlargement. Which vector is most likely responsible for transmitting this patient's disease?
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario, along with an image showing Romana’s sign and echo findings of dilated cardiomyopathy, are suggestive of Chagas disease. It is caused by Trypanosoma cruzi, transmitted by the reduviid bug.

Chagas disease is a zoonotic disease caused by the protozoa Trypanosoma cruzi. It is endemic to north, central, and south America. It is transmitted by the bite of a reduviid bug/ kissing bug.

Trypanosoma cruzi exists in three forms:

  • Epimastigotes- in the reduviid bug
  • Trypomastigotes- in the bloodstream
  • Amastigotes- intracellular replicating form

Clinically, the infection course of Chagas disease is divided into acute and chronic phases.

In the acute phase, the majority of the patients will be asymptomatic. Fever, regional lymphadenitis, chagoma (localised subcutaneous nodule at the bite site), and the Romaña's sign (unilateral swelling of the eyelids) may be seen in the acute phase. 

The chronic phase is characterised by the following findings:

  • Chagasic dilated cardiomyopathy with marked bilateral ventricular enlargement. This leads to leading to congestive heart failure, presenting as shortness of breath. Endomyocardial biopsy shows fibrosis and the presence of intracellular parasites.
  • Megaesophagus and megacolon. 

Diagnosis is confirmed by demonstrating trypomastigotes on microscopy of blood smears or polymerase chain reactions during the acute phase. In the chronic phase, detection of anti-T. cruzi IgG or endomyocardial biopsy is helpful.

Treatment of Chagas disease is most effective when administered early in the course of infection and has a lesser efficacy in chronic Chagas. Benznidazole and nifurtimox can be used for the treatment.

The image given below shows a reduviid bug.

Other options:

Option A: Dermacentor tick is a type of hard tick responsible for transmitting rocky mountain spotted fever.

Option B: Soft ticks are known to transmit relapsing fever.

Option D: Tsetse fly is responsible for transmitting Trypanosoma brucei rhodesiense and Trypanosoma brucei gambiense that cause African sleeping sickness.

questions.text: A middle-aged man has been recently diagnosed with hypertension. He wants to try lifestyle changes before starting with pharmacological therapy. According to the rule of halves, where is he represented in the diagram, if A represents the whole population?
questions.solution:
According to the rule of halves, the person is represented in category C which represents people diagnosed with hypertension but not treated. This is because the patient has not yet started lifestyle management or pharmacotherapy.

Hypertension is a non-communicable chronic condition that is a risk factor for coronary heart disease, stroke, and other vascular complications. It is known to be an iceberg disease and the rule of halves is applied. The rule depicts the disease burden of hypertension in the community.

It states that only about half of the hypertensive subjects in the general population are aware of the condition. Only half of those aware are being treated and only half of those being treated are considered to be adequately treated.

Pictorial representation of the rule of halves in hypertension is shown below:

Hypertension can be prevented by primary and secondary prevention strategies. Primary prevention includes non-pharmacological measures such as lifestyle changes that are taken to reduce the incidence of the disease. It includes:

  • Population strategy approach aimed to reduce the incidence of the disease at the whole population level
  • High-risk strategy approach is done to identify high-risk individuals 

Secondary prevention includes pharmacological measures such as the usage of antihypertensives in affected individuals. It aims at early detection, adequate treatment, and follow-up of the patients to ensure proper compliance.

questions.text: A 1-month-old infant diagnosed with primary adrenal insufficiency presented with failure to thrive, recurrent emesis, and hepatosplenomegaly. Bilateral adrenal calcification was noted radiologically. Which of the following enzyme is deficient in this condition?
questions.solution:
The given scenario is suggestive of Wolman disease. It is due to a deficiency of the lysosomal acid lipase enzyme. It is an autosomal recessive disease.

It leads to the accumulation of cholesterol esters and triglycerides. It presents in the first few weeks of life with:

  • Failure to thrive
  • Vomiting
  • Abdominal distention
  • Steatorrhea
  • Hepatosplenomegaly
  • Hyperlipidemia
  • Extensive bilateral calcifications of the adrenal glands

No specific therapy is available and death usually occurs within 6 months of life.

questions.text: A patient presents with weight loss, fever, and nocturnal cough. On examination, hepatosplenomegaly and lymphadenopathy are noted. Serology revealed elevated levels of IgE and is positive for anti-filarial antibodies. All of the following are true regarding this condition except:

choices.text: Restrictive changes in pulmonary function tests
Micro filaria seen in peripheral blood

questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario with serology showing high levels of IgE and anti-filarial antibodies is suggestive of tropical pulmonary eosinophilia. All are true regarding this condition except the presence of microfilaria in the blood. 

Tropical pulmonary eosinophilia is a syndrome due to filarial infection. It occurs when the microfilaria released from the lymphatics get trapped in the lungs. These parasites then elicit inflammatory response in the pulmonary tissue. This syndrome is characterized by nocturnal paroxysmal wheeze and cough (option B), weight loss, low-grade fever, and lymphadenopathy.

The microfilariae are not usually found in the peripheral blood as they get rapidly sequestrated in the lungs and are cleared from the bloodstream.

Investigations show eosinophilia >3000/μL, chest radiographs show mottled opacities and increased broncho vascular markings, and pulmonary function tests show restrictive changes in most cases and obstructive changes in a few cases.(option C).

Diethylcarbamazine (DEC) for 14 days is useful in treating the condition (option A).

questions.text: Baclofen is a:
questions.solution:
Baclofen is a GABAB receptor agonist.

Baclofen is a centrally acting muscle relaxant. It is an analog of the inhibitory transmitter GABA and acts as a selective GABAB receptor agonist. It also acts at the spinal cord where it decreases excitatory transmitter release of excitatory neurotransmitter release.

Baclofen is used for the treatment of spasticity in multiple sclerosis, amyotrophic lateral sclerosis, spinal injuries, and flexor spasm. In these conditions, baclofen is the preferred drug for symptomatic relief.

It can also be administered intrathecally around the spinal cord through a catheter placed surgically.

Side effects of baclofen include drowsiness, mental confusion, weakness, and ataxia.

Other options:

Option A: Nm receptor antagonism is the mechanism of action of the curare group of muscle relaxants. The drugs in this class include pancuronium, vecuronium, rocuronium, atracurium, mivacurium, etc.

Option B: D2 receptor agonist is the mechanism of action of bromocriptine. It is used for the treatment of prolactinoma and Parkinson's disease.

Option D: α2 adrenergic receptor agonist is the mechanism of action of clonidine. It is used for the treatment of hypertension.

questions.text: A girl presents with intractable bleeding from the nose. She had tried the technique shown below on her family doctor's advice, but the bleeding did not stop. Which of the following is correct regarding the next best step?

choices.text: Topical antibiotics are indicated if the pack is not removed in 24 hours
Intermittent oxygen may be required in patients with either left or right sided nasal pack
Merocel is used as a first-line agent for nasal packing
Patients requiring postnasal pack do not require hospitalization

questions.solution:
Merocel is used as a first-line agent for nasal packing, which is the next best step after trying Trotter’s method which is shown in the image.

Here, the patient leans forward in the sitting position, over a basin, and spits any blood oozing into the mouth while breathing through it. Merocel is a non-absorbable nasal packing material that increases in size on rehydration with normal saline. This compresses the bleeding vessel.

Epistaxis is bleeding from inside the nose and is commonly seen in all age groups. It can be due to trauma, infections, foreign bodies, or local neoplasms. Some systemic conditions like thrombocytopenia, liver diseases, and hemophilia can result in the condition.

Management of Epistaxis:

  1. Pinching of the nose with thumb and index finger for about 5 minutes compresses the vessels of the Little’s area.
  2. Cauterisation of the bleeding point with silver nitrate or electrocautery. This is done under topical anesthesia.
  3. Anterior nasal packing.
  4. Posterior nasal packing for which patients should be hospitalized.
  5. Endoscopic cauterization of the bleeding point. 
  6. Elevation of the mucoperichondrial flap and submucosal resection operation- for persistent and recurrent bleeds from the septum.
  7. Ligation of vessels.
  8. Transnasal endoscopic sphenopalatine artery ligation (TESPAL) is done under topical anesthesia with sedation or under general anesthesia. It is effective in controlling refractory posterior bleeds.
  9. Embolization of the internal maxillary artery by an interventional radiologist, via femoral artery catheterization. 

The image below depicts nasal packing.

Other options:

Option A: Systemic and not topical antibiotics are indicated if the nasal pack is planned to stay for 2-3 days. It prevents sinus infections and toxic shock syndrome.

Option B: Intermittent oxygen may be required in patients with bilateral nasal packs and not unilateral because of increased pulmonary resistance from naso-pulmonary reflex.

Option D: Patients requiring postnasal packs should always be hospitalized. It is important to evaluate the cause of epistaxis.

questions.text: A 15-year-old boy was brought with complaints of involuntary picking movement of his fingers. He had a blank look on his face and was unresponsive during this episode. He had nausea and epigastric discomfort before this episode. MRI findings are given in the image below. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario along with MRI showing hippocampal sclerosis is most likely suggestive of mesial temporal lobe epilepsy syndrome (MTLE).

It is the most common epilepsy syndrome characterized by the early onset of focal seizures with impairment of consciousness. The seizure is usually preceded by an aura which may include epigastric sensation, nausea, deja-vu, fear/anger, or olfactory/gustatory hallucinations. The seizure may present as picking movements of fingers, blank staring appearance, difficulty in speaking, automatism such as lip-smacking, chewing, etc. Patients usually experience post-ictal confusion.

The electroencephalogram shows unilateral or bilateral anterior temporal spikes. MRI typically shows hippocampal sclerosis, as seen in the image below: 

 

The condition is refractory to anticonvulsant therapy but responds well to surgical intervention.

Other options:

Option A: Juvenile myoclonic epilepsy is seen in early adolescence and features include bilateral myoclonic single or repetitive jerks with intact consciousness. The condition responds well to antiepileptics.

Option B: Lennox- Gastaut syndrome is an epileptic syndrome seen in children. It is characterized by generalized tonic-clonic, atonic, and absence seizures in children. EEG changes and cognitive impairment may be present in most cases. 

Option C: Gelastic epilepsy is seen in childhood. It is characterized by laughter that feels empty or unpleasant, sometimes followed by features of focal seizures, such as automatism. They might also have tonic-clonic and atonic seizures. The condition is associated with hypothalamic hamartoma.

Related Pearl: Mesial Temporal Lobe Epilepsy

Mesial temporal lobe epilepsy shows a familial inheritance and begins in childhood. It presents as focal seizures with a remitting and relapsing course. It is associated with:

  • Aura
  • Complex automatism
  • Post-ictal confusion
  • Anterograde amnesia

EEG findings include temporal spikes, and MRI shows hippocampal sclerosis. Management includes anteromedial resection of the temporal lobe.

questions.text: A young animal rescue worker complained of an itchy rash on his abdomen. On examination, multiple creeping lesions are seen as shown in the image below. What is the drug of choice for this condition?
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario along with an image showing red, raised serpiginous lesions are suggestive of cutaneous larva migrans. The drug of choice for this condition is ivermectin.

Cutaneous larva migrans is caused by non-human hookworms like Ancylostoma braziliense and Ancylostoma caninum. It is acquired via direct skin contact with soil contaminated by dog or cat feces. The larvae remain confined to the outer layers of skin, as they cannot penetrate the basement membrane of the human skin.

It presents as erythematous, pruritic papules at the site of entry. This is followed by the appearance of erythematous serpiginous tracks of lesions on skin. This is due to the migration of larva through the dermo-epidermal junction. The lesion shifts correspond to the movement of the larva. Hence these lesions are also called creeping eruptions.

Diagnosis is based mainly on clinical features.

The treatment includes topical application of thiabendazole and oral albendazole or ivermectin.

The differences between cutaneous larva migrans and visceral larva migrans are:

Serodiagnosis Not developed Well developed
Treatment Thiabendazole/ Albendazole/ Ivermectin

Albendazole/ Diethylcarbamazine (DEC) and Prednisolone. 

DEC has greater side effects than Albendazole so it is rarely used 


Note: A rapidly moving lesion (10cm/hr) produced by Strongyloides stercoralis is known as larva currens (running larva). It occurs as an otherwise asymptomatic lesion in immunocompetent individuals.

Other options:

Option B: Praziquantel is used for the treatment of all human tapeworms, neurocysticercosis, schistosomes, and Fasciola hepatica infection.

Option C: Diethylcarbamazine is used for the treatment of filariasis, visceral larva migrans, and tropical pulmonary eosinophilia.

Option D: Prednisolone is used as an immunosuppressant for the treatment of a variety of infections like neurocysticercosis, visceral larva migrans, etc.

questions.text: A couple comes to a hospital for genetic counselling and upon further evaluation, the husband is found to have Marfan syndrome. The inheritance pattern and mutation associated with this condition are:

choices.text: Autosomal dominant, mutation in FBN-1 gene
Autosomal recessive, mutation in FBN-1 gene
Autosomal dominant, mutation in FBN-2 gene
Autosomal recessive, mutation in FBN-2 gene

questions.solution:
The inheritance pattern in Marfan syndrome is autosomal dominant and is associated with a mutation in FBN-1 gene.

Marfan syndrome is an autosomal dominant disorder affecting connective tissues associated chiefly with cardiovascular, ocular, and musculoskeletal abnormalities, although involvement of other organ systems like the central nervous system, respiratory system and skin has also been observed. It results from an inherited defect in an extracellular glycoprotein called fibrillin-1.

Fibrillin occurs in two homologous forms, fibrillin-1 and fibrillin-2, encoded by two separate genes, FBN-1 and FBN-2, located on the long arms of chromosomes 15 and 5, respectively. Mutations of FBN-1 give rise to marfan syndrome while mutations of the related FBN-2 gene give rise to congenital contractural arachnodactyly, characterized by skeletal abnormalities, which is less common. 

Fibrillin-1 is a regulator of TGF-β which is responsible for inflammation, fibrosis, and activation of specific matrix metalloproteinases (MMPs), particularly MMP-2 and MMP-9, which result in the loss of extracellular matrix.

Patients with Marfan syndrome are tall and have a decreased upper to lower segment ratio with long arms, hands, and fingers. Deformities of the chest wall, vertebral column, and foot arches may be present.

Associated cardiovascular abnormalities include mitral valve prolapse leading to mitral regurgitation and dilatation of aortic root/sinuses of Valsalva leading to aortic regurgitation, aortic dissection, and rupture.

Ocular features include ectopia lentis, retinal detachment, cataracts and refractive errors like myopia due to increased axial length.

questions.text: A 40-year-old farmer presented to the clinic with fever, malaise, and headache. On examination, a lesion is seen over his right arm as shown in the below image. Later the patient developed sepsis. On Gram staining from cultures, bamboo stick appearance was seen. Which of the following reactions is characteristic of this bacilli?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and the image showing a necrotic ulcer with a characteristic black eschar are suggestive of cutaneous anthrax with septicemia signs caused by Bacillus anthracis. The characteristic reaction shown by these bacilli is M'Fadyean’s reaction.

When blood films containing anthrax bacilli are stained with polychrome methylene blue for a few seconds and examined under the microscope, amorphous purplish material is noticed around the bacilli which shows the capsular material. This is called M'Fadyean’s reaction.

Cutaneous anthrax is usually acquired by the entry of spores through injured skin. The lesion starts as a papule and becomes vesicular. Several satellite lesions are seen around a central necrotic lesion which is covered by a black eschar. This lesion is called a malignant pustule. Cutaneous anthrax generally resolves spontaneously.

On microscopy, they appear as gram-positive rods. Bacilli are arranged end to end in long chains. The ends of the bacilli are truncated or often concave and somewhat swollen so that a chain of bacilli presents a bamboo stick appearance.

The organisms produce nonhemolytic grey-to-white, tenacious colonies with a rough texture and a ground-glass appearance in blood agar. Comma-shaped outgrowths (Medusa head, curled hair) may project from the colony.

Other options:

Option A - Naegler's reaction is a useful test for the rapid detection of Clostridium perfringens.

Option B - The reverse CAMP test is used to identify Clostridium perfringens.

Option D - Splendore-Hoeppli phenomenon is demonstrated by sporotrichosis, pityrosporum folliculitis, zygomycosis, candidiasis, aspergillosis, and blastomycosis. It is also seen in bacterial infections such as botryomycosis, nocardiosis, and actinomycosis, and parasitic conditions include orbital pythiosis, strongyloidiasis, schistosomiasis, and cutaneous larva migrans.

questions.text: A young girl after a school camp develops fever with rashes involving her palms and soles, without eschar. On probing further, she remembers suffering a tick bite during the camp. A blood test reveals antibodies that react with Proteus antigens. Which of the following is the causative organism of the condition?
questions.solution:
Fever and rash involving the palms and soles after a tick bite, with a positive Weil-Felix reaction is suggestive of rocky mountain spotted fever (RMSF). RMSF is caused by Rickettsia rickettsii.

RMSF occurs secondary to the bite of a dermacentor tick (hard tick). Patients present with fever, headache, myalgia, and centripetally distributed rashes over palms and soles.  The most common serologic test for the diagnosis is the indirect immunofluorescence assay. Weil-Felix reaction is usually positive in RMSF because the antibodies against Rickettsia react with Proteus antigens. The drug of choice for the treatment of both children and adults with RMSF is doxycycline. 

The following 3 diseases typically present with rash on palms and soles:

  1. Rocky mountain spotted fever
  2. Secondary syphilis
  3. Hand, foot and mouth disease.

Other options: 

Option A: Rickettsia akari causes rickettsial pox. Clinical features are fever, headache, lymphadenopathy, and eschar. Weil-Felix reaction is negative. 

Option C: Treponema pallidum causes syphilis. It is a sexually transmitted disease. Clinical features are hard chancre, condyloma latum, scaly papular eruptions, and constitutional symptoms.

Option D: Coxiella burnetti causes Q fever. Symptoms are fever, headache, photophobia, etc. Weil-Felix reaction is negative.

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman was found to have a liver tumor during an abdominal CT scan as shown in the image.  The tumor showed up as a hotspot on a Tc 99m radionuclide scan. Which of the following cells are responsible for this finding?
questions.solution:
The given CT image shows a hypervascular lesion in the liver with a central non-enhancing scar which is suggestive of focal nodular hyperplasia (FNH). FNH appears as a hotspot on Tc 99m sulfur colloid scans due to the presence of Kupffer cells.

FNH is the second most common benign tumor of the liver after hemangioma. It is commonly seen in young women. It is believed to be a hyperplastic response to an anomalous artery. Patients are mostly asymptomatic and FNH is often an incidental finding. If symptoms are noted, vague abdominal pain is the most common symptom.

On histological examination, cords of hepatocytes are seen with atypical biliary epithelium scattered throughout. 

Contrast-enhanced CT is diagnostic for focal nodular hyperplasia (FNH). It appears as a well-circumscribed lesion with a central stellate scar containing a large artery branching out in a spoke-wheel pattern. It shows intense homogeneous enhancement in the arterial phase and it is isodense as compared to the background liver in the venous phase.

The contrast-enhanced CT image of focal nodular hyperplasia (FNH) is shown below.

FNH show sufficient Kupffer cell (hepatic macrophages) activity to accumulate sulfur colloid tracer and appear as hyperintense (hotspot) on Tc 99m sulfur colloid scans.

These tumors do not have the risk of malignant transformation, therefore asymptomatic patients do not require treatment. Careful observation of symptomatic FNH with serial imaging is reasonable, as symptoms may resolve in a significant number of cases. Patients with persistent symptomatic FNH or an enlarging mass should be considered for resection.

If diagnostic uncertainty exists, resection may be necessary for histologic confirmation.

The adult liver consists of numerous cell types, including:

  • Hepatocytes - These are polyhedral cells with a central spherical nucleus, arranged in a single-cell layer. Every hepatocyte has contact with adjacent hepatocytes (with gap junctions for intercellular communication), bile canaliculus, and the space of Disse/perisinusoidal space (hepatocytes project multiple microvilli into this space for active transport of substances.)
  • Kupffer cells (hepatic macrophages) are phagocytic cells lining the sinusoids. 
  • Hepatic stellate cells (Ito cells/perisinusoidal cells) are involved in scar deposition in cirrhosis of the liver and have a role in vitamin A storage.
  • Sinusoidal endothelial cells - flat cells with a central nucleus, these are separated from hepatocytes by the space of Disse (perisinusoidal space). 

The microarchitecture of the liver is shown below.
