questions.text: As a part of evaluation, a psychiatrist enumerates all the colors of the rainbow to his patient. The next day, when the patient was asked to recollect these colors, he was unable to recollect the 6th color. The doctor mentioned the first few letters of the color, and then the patient answered. The function of which part of the brain is evaluated here?
questions.solution:
In the given clinical scenario, priming is being assessed, which depends on the functioning of the neocortex.

Priming is a form of nondeclarative memory that helps in recognizing words or objects to which the person was exposed previously. It is usually assessed by checking for increased reading speed, faster naming of objects, and faster recollection of getting a clue when presented with previously exposed information.

Memory is usually divided into two forms:

  • Explicit or declarative memory is associated with consciousness or awareness.
  • Implicit or non-declarative memory does not involve awareness and its retention. It does not involve the hippocampus in its processing.

Memory can also be classified as:

Short-term memory- lasts for a few seconds to minutes. Working memory is a form of short-term memory. It keeps the information available, usually for a very short time, until the individual plans some action based on it.

Long-term memory can be recollected after years or even for a lifetime. These memories are stored in various parts of the neocortex. The various types of the memories such as visual, auditory, olfactory, etc., are localized to the cortical regions.

Other options:

Option 1: Striatum forms a part of the basal ganglia and is involved in decision-making functions, such as motor control, emotion, habit formation, and reward.

Option 2: Amygdala, a component of the limbic system, is responsible for the control of emotions, behavior, and memory formation. 

Option 3: Cerebellum is responsible for the coordination of movement, maintaining posture and balance, muscle tone, and motor learning.

Related Pearl: Forms of Memory

From physiologic point of view memory is divided into explicit and implicit forms.

Related Pearl: Tests for evaluating attention, concentration and memory

Memory:

Memory is of 3 types:

  • Immediate memory and recall are usually tested by digit span/ digit repetition test.
    • Digit span test: Digits spelled at the rate of 1 digit per second. It is of two types: Digit forward and Digit backward.
    • Digit forward: Reproduction of increasingly longer digits. E.g., Examiner says 2 - 4 –8 –1 –5 –7 - 9. The person has to repeat in the same order 2 – 4 – 8 –1 –5 –7 –9.
    • Digit backward: Reproduction of longer digits in the backward direction. Eg: Examiner says 2 - 4 –8 –1 –5 –7 - 9. The person has to repeat it backward. 9 -7 -5 -1 -8- 4- 2.
    • The above tests should be stopped when there are 2 successive failures. Hence 2 skips are not allowed.
  • Recent memory: Ask them how they reached the hospital or what they ate for breakfast.
  • Remote memory: Relevant questions from the past like close relative's birth dates. 

Attention:

  • Is the patient's attention easily aroused and sustained?
  • Digit span test.

Concentration:

  • Is the patient easily distractable or can they concentrate?
  • Serial subtraction test: Minimum of five subtractions done serially is taken into account
  • Count backward from 20.
  • Enumerate the months in reverse order.

questions.text: A person working in a dye factory presented with nausea, vomiting, dark bloody stools, conjunctivitis, and a burning sensation in the throat and stomach. Which poisoning do you suspect in this case?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of an industrial worker presenting with nausea, vomiting, dark bloody stools, conjunctivitis, burning in the throat and stomach is suggestive of acute arsenic poisoning.

There are 3 types of arsenic poisoning,

  • Gastroenteric type is a common form and resembles bacterial food poisoning. There is a sweetish metallic taste. Features include:
    • GIT: Constriction in the throat and dysphagia, burning, and colicky pain in the esophagus, stomach, and bowel occur. Intense thirst and severe vomiting are constant symptoms. Involuntary and frequent dark-colored, stinking, and bloody stools that later become colorless, odorless, and watery resembling rice-water stools of cholera. A garlicky odor of breath and feces may be noted
    • Renal: Oliguria, uremia, albuminuria, red cell casts.
    • Cardiovascular system: Acute circulatory collapse with vasodilation, increased vascular permeability, ventricular tachycardia, and fibrillation.
    • Central nervous system: Headache, vertigo, hyperthermia, convulsions, coma. Peripheral neuropathy is more sensory than motor.
    • Death is usually due to circulatory failure.
  • Fulminant type: Massive doses of arsenic when rapidly absorbed cause death in one to three hours. Death occurs due to shock and peripheral vascular failure. Arsenic also has a direct action on the heart muscle. In this type gastrointestinal symptoms are absent.
  • Narcotic type: The gastrointestinal symptoms are minimal. There is giddiness, formication, delirium. Arseniuretted hydrogen when inhaled as a gas, destroys hemoglobin and causes hemolysis, hemoglobinuria, and renal failure. Death is instantaneous.

Treatment:

  • Repeated stomach washes with warm water and milk.
  • Emetics should not be used
  • Oral hydrated ferric oxide is given in small doses. It converts toxic arsenic to non-toxic ferric arsenite
  • Dimercaptosuccinic acid (DMSA) is preferred, if not available British anti-Lewisite (BAL) is used.

Other options:

Option A: Potassium permanganate causes burning pain from the mouth to the stomach, intense thirst, dysphagia, stridor, and a persistent cough. The oral cavity is discolored, inflamed, and superficially corroded. Soon after poisoning the color is purple-brown, but later it appears coal-black.

Option C: Thallium poisoning is characterized by a triad of symptoms of acute gastrointestinal upset, painful combined polyneuropathy, and hair loss after poisoning. Other symptoms include muscle and joint pain, convulsions, optic neuritis, delirium. Loss of the outer third of eyebrows is significant. Maculo-papular butterfly-shaped skin eruption on the face is characteristic. There may be Mees lines on the nails. 

Option D: Acute Lead poisoning causes dry throat, burning abdominal pain, peripheral circulatory collapse, insomnia, paraesthesias, depression, coma, and death. Cerebellar ataxia is common in children with acute lead poisoning. A screening test for lead poisoning is the presence of porphyrinuria, mainly due to coproporphyrin III. Peripheral smear shows basophilic stippling. A Burtonian line may be visible on the gums.

questions.text: A 7-year-old boy was brought with multiple ring-shaped lesions in the scalp with patchy hair loss and pruritis for a few weeks. He was started on an oral antifungal drug acting on point A in the following diagram. This drug is most likely to be:
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario of multiple ring-shaped lesions in the scalp with patchy hair loss and pruritis is suggestive of tinea capitis. The drug acting on point A in the above diagram is griseofulvin. 

Griseofulvin is a fungistatic antifungal agent. Griseofulvin disrupts the fungal cell division by inhibiting microtubule function and thereby disrupts the assembly of the mitotic spindle. 

It is administered orally and its absorption is improved when taken with a fatty meal. It gets deposited in the keratin precursor cells and binds tightly to keratin. Thereby, it provides prolonged resistance to fungal invasion. 

They are only effective against dermatophytes Microsporum, Epidermophyton, and Trichophyton. It is the drug of choice for tinea capitis and tenia pedis.

Griseofulvin induces hepatic CYPs and thereby increases the rate of metabolism of warfarin and low-estrogen oral contraceptive agents. Side effects of griseofulvin include headache, gastrointestinal disturbance, and hepatotoxicity.

Other options:

Option A: Amphotericin B binds to ergosterol in the fungal membrane and forms pores or channels (point C) in the fungal cell membrane and allows the leakage of cytosolic molecules and ions, leading to loss of membrane integrity.

It is a broad-spectrum antifungal that can be used against Candida, Cryptococcus neoformans, Blastomyces dermatitidis, Histoplasma capsulatum, Sporothrix schenckii, Coccidioides, Paracoccidioides braziliensis, Aspergillus, Penicillium marneffei, Fusarium, and Mucorales.

Option B: Itraconazole is triazole that inhibits 14-alpha-sterol demethylase (point D) and impairs the biosynthesis of ergosterol which leads to accumulation of the toxic product 14 alpha-methyl-3,6-diol resulting in growth arrest. 

Itraconazole is the drug of choice for nonmeningeal infections due to B. dermatitidis, H. capsulatum, P. brasiliensis, and Coccidioides immitis. The drug also is useful in the therapy of invasive aspergillosis particularly after the infection has been treated with amphotericin B.

Option C: Terbinafine inhibits fungal squalene epoxidase (point B) and reduces ergosterol biosynthesis. They are more effective against nail onychomycosis than itraconazole.

Related Pearl: Mechanism of action of Antifungal drugs

questions.text: A 7-year-old boy presents with a visual acuity of 6/6 in the right eye and only hand movements in the left eye. On fundoscopy, the right eye appears normal. Left eye fundoscopic appearance is as given below. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a young boy in his first decade of life with a unilateral decrease in visual acuity with fundus showing telangiectasia and severe lipid deposition points to the diagnosis of Coats' disease.

Coats' disease is a congenital vascular disorder of the eye typically seen in boys in their first decade and is usually unilateral. In children, Coats’ disease is typically diagnosed as a result of recognition of poor vision, strabismus, or leukokoria.

Early stages of ocular manifestations include discrete zones with dilated and tortuous retinal blood vessels and a number of small aneurysms near the posterior pole and around the disc. The ophthalmoscopic picture shows retinal vascular abnormalities associated with large areas of intra and subretinal yellowish exudates and hemorrhages.

Given below is the fundus picture of Coats’ disease showing aneurysmal dilatation, telangiectasia, exudation, and severe macular lipid deposition.

 

Other options:

Option A- Central serous retinopathy is characterized by spontaneous serous detachment of the neurosensory retina in the macular region, with or without retinal pigment epithelium detachment. The fundus findings include mild elevation of the macular area, absent or distorted foveal reflex, and subretinal deposits. The given below is the fundus picture of central serous retinopathy.

 

Option B- Purtscher retinopathy is characterized by multiple retinal white areas around the optic nerve head and fovea (Purtscher flecken), cotton wool spots, and minimal intraretinal hemorrhages. The given below is the fundus picture of Purtscher retinopathy.

 

Option D- Best's disease is a hereditary macular disorder which shows the presence of egg yolk lesion or scrambled egg lesion in the macula. The given below is the fundus picture of Best's disease showing an egg yolk lesion in the macula.

questions.text: What is the intensity or loudness of sound is expressed in?
questions.solution:
The intensity or loudness of sound is expressed in decibels (dB).

Loudness or intensity depends upon the amplitude of vibrations. People can tolerate up to 85 dB of daily exposure without substantial damage to hearing.

The frequency of sound is expressed in hertz (Hz.) and 1 hertz is equal to one wave per second. The human ear can hear frequencies from about 20 to 20,000 Hz. Phon is an expression of the psychoacoustic index of loudness which considers both the intensity and frequency of sound.

Candela is the measure of luminous intensity.

Becquerel is the unit of radiation activity. 

Related Pearl: Properties of Sound and Noise

I) Loudness

  • Loudness or intensity depends upon the amplitude of vibrations and it is measured in decibels (dB).
  • The daily exposure of up to 85 dB is the limit that people can tolerate without substantial damage to hearing. This limit is the maximum acceptable noise limit.
Normal conversation 60 – 65 dB
Whispering 20 – 30 dB
Heavy street traffic 60 – 80 dB
Boiler factories 120 dB
  • Acceptable noise levels are expressed in terms of unit dBA, which is decibels conform to a weighting curve called curve A.

  Living room 40
Commercial Office 35 – 45
  Conference 40 – 45
  Restaurants 40 – 60
Industrial Workshop 40 – 60
  Laboratory 40 – 50
Educational Classroom 30 – 40
  Library 35 – 40
Hospitals Wards 20 – 35

II) Frequency

  • It is expressed in Hertz (Hz.) and 1 Hertz is equal to one wave per second
  • The human ear can hear frequencies from about 20 to 20,000 Hz
  • Below 20 Hz. the vibrations are infra-audible and above 20,000 Hz. they are ultra-sonic

Related Pearl: Effects of Noise Exposure

  • Auditory effects
    • Auditory fatigue appears at 90 dB and is greatest at 4000 Hz. Whistling and buzzing in ear occurs with auditory fatigue.
    • Temporary deafness or hearing loss occurs after a single exposure to a noise, usually at a frequency range of 4000 – 6000 Hz. It disappears after 24 hours following noise exposure.
    • Permanent hearing loss can result after continuous or repeated exposure to noises around 100 dB. It occurs commonly as occupational hearing loss.
    • Exposure to noise above 160 dB may rupture the tympanic membrane and cause permanent hearing loss.
  • Non-auditory effects
    • Interference with speech occurs when sound has a frequency of 300 – 500 Hz
    • Annoyance is a psychological response to noise which can greatly affect efficiency and concentration
    • Noise has also been known to cause some physiological changes like increased blood pressure, intracranial pressure, increased sweating, etc.

questions.text: A full-term primigravida has asked for epidural labor analgesia at the first stage of labor. Which of the following local anesthetic is commonly used to provide sensory blockade along with fentanyl?
questions.solution:
The most commonly used local anesthetic to provide sensory blockade along with fentanyl is bupivacaine. In concentrations of 0.0625% - 0.125%, bupivacaine is used in epidural labor analgesia to provide maximum sensory blockade with a minimum motor blockade.

Lumbar epidural analgesia is the mainstay of pain relief during the early stages of labor. Epidural analgesia is usually performed between L2-L3 and L4-L5 since the spinal cord typically terminates at the L1 level. An appropriate labor analgesic should provide a sensory blockade without motor blockade or other maternal or fetal effects.

The doses of local anesthetics can be reduced by combining them with opioids like fentanyl or sufentanil. The lesser concentration of local anesthetic used leads to greater preservation of motor function and makes ambulation of the patient possible (walking or mobile epidural). Moreover, by reducing the concentration of the drugs, adverse effects like hypotension and drug toxicity are minimized.

Concentrations used for epidural:

The dose of opioid used:

  • Fentanyl : 2–3 mcg/mL 
  • Sufentanil: 0.3–0.5 mcg/mL

Ropivacaine (0.0625% - 0.2%) is the other commonly used local anesthetic for epidural analgesia and is the preferred one due to reduced cardiotoxicity as with bupivacaine.

Procaine, tetracaine, and mepivacaine are not commonly used for epidural labor analgesia.

Other options:

Option A: Chloroprocaine is a chlorinated derivative of procaine, used in spinal anesthesia for ambulatory surgeries.

Option C: Tetracaine is used in topical anesthetic preparations. It is also used in spinal anesthesia when a longer duration of action is needed

 Option D: Mepivacaine has a longer duration of action when compared with lidocaine. It leads to transient neurological symptoms, hence the use of the drug is reduced.

  • Mepivacaine
  • Prilocaine

questions.text: Which of the following is an incorrect statement regarding chest compression during CPR in an infant?

choices.text: Depth should be 1/5th of the depth of the infant’s chest
Done 1 cm below the nipples over the sternum

questions.solution:
The depth of the chest compression in a one-month-old child receiving CPR is 1/3rd the depth of the infant’s chest.

Effective chest compressions in infants (<1 year):

  • 100 to 120 compressions per minute (30 compressions for every 15-18 sec).
  • One provider: Place two fingers, one between the nipple line and the other 1 cm below.
  • Two providers: Encircle the infant's torso with both hands with both thumbs pointing cephalic positioned 1cm below the nipples over the sternum. 
  • Depth of compressions should be at least 1.5 inches or 1/3 the depth of the infant’s chest.
  • Press hard and fast.
  • Allow for full chest recoil after every compression.

Effective chest compressions in a child older than 1 year and up to puberty:

  • The compression rate is 100-120/min (30 compressions for every 15-18 sec).
  • One or both palms are placed in the midline.
  • The depth of compression is 2 inches.
  • Press hard and fast.
  • Allow for full chest recoil after every compression.

The compression-to-ventilation ratio for pediatric CPR depends on the number of rescuers present:

  • For a single rescuer: 30:2 (30 chest compressions followed by 2 breaths)
  • For two rescuers: 15:2 (15 chest compressions followed by 2 breaths)

Related Pearl: High quality CPR for adults

  • Push hard: 5-6cm depth
  • Push fast: 100-120/min frequency
  • Allow for complete chest recoil
  • Minimize interruptions in compressions <10 seconds
  • Avoid excessive ventilation
  • Rotate compressor every 2 min or earlier if fatigued
  • If no advanced airway, 30:2 compression-ventilation ratio

Attempt to improve CPR quality if :

  • Quantitative waveform capnography - PETCO2 <10mmHg, 
  • Intra-arterial pressure - If relaxation phase (diastolic) pressure <20mmHg

questions.text: You are posted as the in-charge medical officer for a special vaccination drive for measles. You would advise avoiding measles vaccination in all of the following individuals except ____.

choices.text: A patient who has a high fever
A patient in early stages of HIV infection
A patient with history of an anaphylactic reaction to gelatin

questions.solution:
A patient in the early stages of HIV infection is not a contraindication for measles vaccination.

Measles vaccination is contraindicated

  • if the patient has a high fever, 
  • pregnant women,
  • severely immunocompromised due to congenital disease,
  • severe HIV infection,
  • advanced leukaemia or lymphoma,
  • serious malignant disease,
  • history of an anaphylactic reaction to neomycin, gelatin
  • treatment with high-dose steroids, alkylating agents or antimetabolites, or immuno-suppressive therapeutic radiation

The measles vaccine is a live attenuated vaccine which is safe and effective with no evidence of person-to-person transfer of vaccine strains. In general, live vaccines are contraindicated in immune deficiency diseases and immunosuppressive states(malignancies, steroid therapy, chemotherapy with anticancer drugs, radiation) and in pregnancy.

Measles vaccine can be given in combination with other live attenuated vaccines such as mumps, and rubella vaccines (MMR vaccine), measles, mumps, rubella and varicella (MMRV), and measles and rubella (MR).

Measles is caused by an RNA paramyxovirus. Contact with large droplets or small-droplet aerosols is the route of transmission. Infection results in respiratory tract epithelial necrosis and lymphocytic infiltration. Clinical features include high fever, cough, coryza, and a rash. Koplik spots appear 1-4 days before the onset of the rash at the level of the premolars. This is followed by the appearance of the rash that starts on the forehead, neck, and behind the ears. It then spreads to involve the torso and extremities.

Diagnosis can be made by IgM assay. Affected children need to be isolated for 4 days after the beginning of the rash to prevent its spread. Treatment is mainly supportive.

Most of the complications are secondary to bacterial infections. It includes pneumonia, acute otitis media, croup, bronchiolitis, encephalitis, and subacute sclerosing panencephalitis. Secondary attack rates in susceptible contacts are usually ≥90%. Vaccination against measles is the most effective way to prevent the condition.

 

Related Pearl: Measles vaccine

Measles vaccine: 

  • Type: Live attenuenated, lyophilized (freeze dried), vaccine (Tissue culture vaccine- chick embryo or Human diploid cell line).

  • Strains used: 1. Edmonston Zagreb strain (most common). 

                            2. Schwartz strain.

                            3. Moraten strain.

  • Dose: 0.5ml.

  • Route: Subcutaneous.

  • Site: Right arm (usually).

  • Age of administration in National immunization schedule (India): 9 months (can be lowered to 6-9 months in epidemics and malnutrition) and 16-24 months.

  • Diluent for reconstitution: Distilled water or sterile water. (To be used within 4 hours after reconstitutuion).

  • Measles (and MMR) vaccine can lead to Toxic shock syndrome.

  • Measles vaccine is contraindicated in pregnancy.

  • Cold chain temperature for storage: +2 to +8 degree Celcius.

  • Protective efficacy: >90% with one dose; >99% with two doses.

  • Duration of protection: Life long.

  • IP of vaccine induced measles: 7 days.

  • Ideal gap between two successive doses: 6 months.

questions.text: A young woman reports that she checks if the front door of her home is locked 10-15 times a day, which leads to poor performance at work. She mentions that if she tries to prevent herself from doing this, she feels extremely anxious. Which of the following is associated with a good prognosis of the given condition?
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario is suggestive of obsessive compulsion disorder (OCD). The presence of precipitating events is associated with a good prognosis.

OCD is a disorder characterized by repetitive and intrusive thoughts, preoccupations, and repetitive behaviors that the person feels compelled to do. The feelings, ideas, sensations, and intrusive thoughts, are referred to as obsessions. Conscious repetitive behaviors are called compulsions.

Symptom patterns of OCD are:

  • Contamination - This is the most common pattern. Objects are thought to be contaminated, the patient washes them repeatedly or avoids touching them.
  • Pathological doubt - This is the second most common pattern. The patient presents with a doubt and a compulsion to check. For example, patients do multiple checks on whether the stove is turned off or the door is locked.
  • Intrusive thoughts - These patients have repetitive thoughts of sexual or aggressive acts without a compulsion.
  • Symmetry - This presents as a need to do tasks with precision or symmetry. This leads to slowing of their work. For example, taking hours to shave.

A good prognosis for OCD is associated with the following:

  • A good social and occupational adjustment
  • The presence of precipitating event
  • Episodic nature of symptoms.

The following are associated with a bad prognosis in OCD:

  • Present since childhood (option A)
  • Coexisting major depressive disorder (option C)
  • Acceptance of obsessions and compulsions
  • Bizarre compulsions and coexisting delusional beliefs
  • OCD that requires hospitalization
  • Personality disorder – especially schizotypal personality (option D)

Related Pearl: Obsessive-compulsive disorder

Key points:

  • Most common:
    • Obsession: Contamination
    • Compulsion: Checking, cleaning
  • Treatment: Exposure and Response prevention - 1st line, Cognitive Behavioural Therapy(CBT), CBT with ERP, Pharmacotherapy.
  • Drug of choice: High dose SSRI
  • Treatment in nonresponsive patients: Clomipramine or antipsychotic augmentation
  • Treatment of severe or refractory cases: Deep brain stimulation

questions.text: A 68-year-old man presents with low backache for three months. On examination, his ankle and knee jerk reflexes were absent. But, pain and temperature sensations were preserved. MRI shows lumbar disc prolapse at L3-L4. What is the diagnosis of this patient?
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario is suggestive of cauda equina syndrome secondary to a lumbar disc prolapse.

Compression of the lumbosacral nerve roots below the level of termination of the spinal cord that is L1-L2 results in cauda-equina syndrome (CES). Common causes of CES include ruptured lumbosacral intervertebral disc, epidural hematoma, vertebral fracture, and compressive tumor. 

Patients with CES usually present with low back pain, asymmetrical weakness, variable areflexia, diminished sensation in the buttocks and posterosuperior thighs, and perineal region. Absent bulbocavernosus, patellar (knee), and Achilles (ankle) reflexes are characteristically seen in CES.

MRI of the entire spine must be done promptly.

Management includes starting dexamethasone immediately, radiation therapy plus glucocorticoids in case of spinal cord compression, and surgical decompression by laminectomy or diskectomy for disc rupture.

Other options:

Option A: Central cord syndrome results due to damage to the gray matter nerve cells and the spinothalamic tract crossing the central canal. Patients present with features are loss of pain and temperature sensation which are not seen in this patient.

Option B: Conus medullaris syndrome is characterized by bilateral saddle anesthesia, and prominent bowel and bladder dysfunction. Also, anal and bulbocavernosus reflexes are absent. 

Option D: Brown-Sequard syndrome is a hemi-transection of the spinal cord. It presents with ipsilateral weakness (corticospinal tract), ipsilateral loss of position, vibration sense (posterior column), and contralateral loss of pain and temperature one or two levels below the lesion.

questions.text: The electroretinogram (ERG) of a person is given below. In this ERG, wave B is due to?
questions.solution:
The image shown is a normal electroretinogram (ERG) in which wave B is due to Muller cells.

Electroretinography measures the changes in the resting potential of an eye, induced by the light stimulus. Waves of ERG include a,b and c. Among these, a and c are negative waves and b is a large positive wave as shown below. The c wave is only seen in the dark-adapted eye. 

Uses of ERG:

  • Diagnosis and prognosis of retinal disorders
  • Early detection of functional abnormalities of the outer retina up to the bipolar cell layer
  • Assessment of retinal function in babies with possible impaired vision and in cases where fundus examination is difficult (in the presence of dense cataracts and corneal opacity).
  • Focal ERG is used to evaluate the diseases of the macula.

Note: Diseases involving ganglion cell layer and higher visual pathways may show a normal ERG.

Abnormal ERG response:

  • Subnormal b-wave response is seen in early cases of retinitis pigmentosa.
  • Extinguished response is seen when there is a complete failure of rods and cones function e.g., advanced retinitis pigmentosa, complete retinal detachment, central retinal artery occlusion.
  • A negative response is seen in gross disturbances of the retinal circulation.

questions.text: A middle-aged woman presents with right groin pain. She is a known case of systemic lupus erythematosus for which she has been on steroids for several years. On examination, there is decreased passive and active range of motion of the right hip. You suspect avascular necrosis of the femoral head but the X-ray findings are inconclusive. Which of the following would be the investigation of choice in this scenario?
questions.solution:
The clinical vignette of a patient on systemic steroids with groin pain and reduced range of motion in the hip but a normal radiograph is indicative of avascular necrosis of the femoral head. The investigation of choice to diagnose early avascular necrosis is MRI.

MRI allows the identification of avascular necrosis of the femoral head in earlier stages and also helps determine the exact stage and extent of the pathologic process.

Avascular necrosis or osteonecrosis is a degenerative bone condition caused by interruption of the blood supply. It commonly affects the epiphysis of long bones that make up weight-bearing joints. 

The common areas that are affected by avascular necrosis are: 

  • Head of the femur after a fracture of the neck of the femur or hip dislocation
  • Proximal scaphoid after a scaphoid waist fracture
  • Lunate bone after a dislocation
  • Body of the talus after a fracture of the neck of the talus

It is considered to be an early complication of injury, however, it is not clinically evident until weeks to months after the inciting event. There are generally no symptoms associated with avascular necrosis. However, if the fracture does not unite, then there will be a pain. 

An X-ray will reveal increased density. This occurs due to disuse osteoporosis in the surrounding areas and the collapse of trabeculae compacts the bone. There may also be deformity due to the collapse of necrotic bone and osteoarthritis. 

In osteonecrosis of the femur, an X-ray will reveal a crescent sign which is pathognomonic. The sign refers to the subchondral fracture that overlies the necrotic segment of the femoral head. 

The X-ray below shows flattening of the femoral head and degenerative changes associated with osteonecrosis.

The image below shows a crescent sign. 

A bone scan may reveal a 'cold area' before radiological features are evident. MRI is the imaging modality of choice in avascular necrosis as it allows for staging and determination of the extent of involvement. 

It is treated depending on the joint involved. Weight-bearing should be delayed until it is revascularized, a process that may take 6-8 months. Revascularization can be done by using vascularized bone grafts taken from the greater trochanter in the case of a fracture of the femur neck. The avascular segment should be excised followed by a total joint replacement. 

Related Pearl: Avascular Necrosis (AVN)

It is a rare but severe complication of certain fractures when the blood supply to a segment of bone is affected. 

Common sites of AVN are:

  • Head of the femur in fracture neck of femur and posterior dislocation of the hip
  • Body of talus in a fracture through the neck of talus
  • Proximal pole of the scaphoid in a fracture through the waist of the scaphoid
  • Head of the humerus
  • The capitulum

Non-traumatic causes of AVN are:

  • Idiopathic
  • Steroids
  • Sickle cell disease
  • Caisson's disease
  • Gaucher's disease
  • Lupus Erythematosus
  • Radiation therapy
  • Alcoholism
  • Hyperlipidemia

Important signs related to avascular necrosis:

  • Crescent sign- Seen in osteonecrosis of the femoral head. It is a subchondral fracture overlying the necrotic segment of the femoral head.
  • Hawkin's sign- Seen secondary to the fracture of the neck of the talus. It refers to subchondral lucency of the dome of the talus due to subchondral atrophy. The presence of this sign indicates that the blood supply to the talus is adequate and chances of avascular necrosis are low.

questions.text: A cast was applied to a patient with a wrist injury as shown below. What is this cast known as?
questions.solution:
The cast applied to a patient in the glass holding position is known as the scaphoid cast. It is used to treat scaphoid fractures.

To apply a scaphoid cast, the wrist is held in slight dorsiflexion and the thumb is in abduction and slight flexion as if the glass is being held between the index finger and thumb. It extends from just below the elbow to just proximal to the metacarpal necks of the digits. On the thumb, the cast extends just proximal to the interphalangeal joint.

Scaphoid fracture presents with pain and swelling over the radial aspect of the wrist. A fall on an outstretched hand could result in such a fracture. The fracture can be confirmed (when an x-ray does not show a fracture) if there is pain elicited in the anatomical snuff box on the radial border of the wrist.

An oblique x-ray of the wrist should be able to show a scaphoid fracture.

questions.text: Cancer cells often have reduced expression of class I MHC antigens. Which of the following cells of the immune system can exploit this property to kill cancer cells?
questions.solution:
Natural killer cells can exploit the property that cancer cells have reduced amounts of surface proteins like class I MHC antigen to kill them. The cytotoxicity of NK cells is not antibody dependent or MHC restricted.

Natural killer cells (NK cells) are also known as large granular lymphocytes. They are essential cells of innate immunity. They act against malignant and virus-infected cells. NK cells are identified by CD16, CD56, and CD94 cell surface receptors. 

NK cells' activity is augmented by interferons and upon activation, they bind to glycoprotein receptors on the surface of target cells and release perforins. Perforins create pores in the membrane of the target cells. Through these pores, cytotoxic factors like tumor necrosis factor-beta (TNF-β) enter the cells and destroy them by apoptosis.

A subset of large-granular lymphocytes are called Antibody dependent cytotoxic cells (ADCC). These cells have the capability of killing target cells that are coated by IgG antibodies. These cells were formerly called killer cells, but are now classified under NK cells.

questions.text: Large bulky friable vegetations are characteristic of
questions.solution:
Large bulky friable vegetations are characteristic of sub-acute bacterial endocarditis.

Infective endocarditis is characterized by the presence of large, friable, irregular vegetations on heart valves, that may extend onto the chordae. Aortic and mitral valves are more commonly affected.

Vegetations may be single or multiple and may involve one or more valves. They are potentially destructive lesions and contain fibrin, inflammatory cells, bacteria or other organisms. They can erode into the underlying myocardium and form a ring abscess. Embolization often occurs and may lead to septic infarcts or mycotic aneurysms at the site of lodgement due to the presence of virulent organisms in the emboli. Vegetations in sub-acute endocarditis are less destructive to the heart valves than in acute type. Microscopy shows granulation tissues at the bases which are suggestive of healing in sub-acute endocarditis.

Invasive Streptococcus pyogenes infections result in streptococcal toxic shock syndrome characterized by shock, bacteremia, respiratory failure, and multiorgan failure. These fulminant symptoms include necrotizing fasciitis, myositis, and soft tissue infections at other sites. Such

Localised infection of superficial layers of skin is called impetigo. It presents with superficial vesicles that may later get eroded and crusted. It can be of a bullous and a non-bullous type and most commonly occurs in children.

Erysipelas is caused by the entry of S. pyogenes, β-Hemolytic Group A Streptococci into the skin. It presents with raised, erythematous sharply demarcated rapidly spreading skin lesions, along with systemic symptoms. Leg and face are the most common sites.

Cellulitis :

It is usually an acute rapidly spreading infection of the skin and subcutaneous tissues presenting with diffuse erythema, warmth and swelling. It is most commonly caused by group A streptococcus. It occurs following mild trauma, burns, wounds, or surgical incisions. In cellulitis, the lesion is not raised, and the line between the involved and uninvolved tissue is indistinct. This helps in differentiating it from erysipelas.

questions.text: The following drain was placed in a patient post thyroidectomy. This is usually removed within:
questions.solution:
The drain placed after thyroidectomy as given in the image is a Romovac drain and it is a closed type of drain. Drains used in surgeries like thyroidectomy are usually removed within 24 hours. Their main purpose is to cover postoperative bleeding. 

Romovac drain is a negative suction drain closed drain kept in the subcutaneous tissue. Romovac drain is indicated in modified radical mastectomy, subcutaneous swelling excision, and amputations. 

Drains are placed at surgical sites to freely collect the air or fluids that may accumulate. This enhances wound healing by preventing the formation of unnecessary cavities. Drains are prophylactic in elective surgeries and therapeutic in emergency surgeries. Drains can be:

  • Open- they are based on the principle of gravity 
  • Semi-open- their action is based on capillary effect
  • Closed- they carry out their actions through suction

Suction drains are commonly used in chest, breast, abdominal, thyroid, and plastic surgeries. They remove intraperitoneal secretions, anastomotic leaks, and blood from hemorrhage at the surgical site. 

Removal of drain:

The catheter at the site is milked for residual collections. It is then clamped and the suture holding the catheter is cut. The tube is then gently pulled out and any clots at the perforation end are removed. The time of removal of drains for various conditions is as given below:

  • Drains used in surgeries like thyroidectomy are usually removed within 24 hours. Their main purpose is to cover postoperative bleeding. 
  • In a mastectomy, a drain is placed for 5 days to collect serous collections.
  • Drains used to cover the colorectal anastomoses are placed for 5-7 days
  • Common bile duct T-tube drains are usually placed for 10 days
  • Drains for infections are removed when the infection subsides or when the content of the drain is minimal 

After the drain is removed, a folded gauze is placed over the drain insertion area. The dressing can be removed after 24 hours. The patient may be given an antibiotic ointment to apply over the area for a week.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man presented with recurrent episodes of heartburn and regurgitation of food for the past few years. Upper gastrointestinal endoscopy was done, and the biopsy showed the following histopathological finding.  Which of the following statements is false?

choices.text: This condition occurs as a complication of GERD
Obese white men are at a higher risk
Increases risk of squamous cell carcinoma
It affects the area above the gastroesophageal junction

questions.solution:
This patient's clinical features and biopsy findings showing intestinal metaplasia are suggestive of Barrett's esophagus which increases the risk of adenocarcinoma, not squamous cell carcinoma.

Barrett's esophagus is a complication of chronic gastroesophageal reflux disease, and it is estimated to occur in about 10% of individuals with symptomatic GERD. Symptoms include heartburn, regurgitation and sometimes dysphagia. Obese white men over the age of 60 years represent the highest-risk group.

It is characterized by intestinal metaplasia within the esophageal squamous mucosa above the gastroesophageal junction. Microscopically, it is seen as the replacement of the squamous esophageal epithelium with goblet cells. The greatest concern in Barrett's esophagus is that it confers an increased risk of esophageal adenocarcinoma.

A histological image showing goblets cells is given below:

On endoscopy, Barrett's is recognized as areas of red, velvety mucosa extending proximally from the gastroesophageal junction. Such areas alternate with normal pale squamous esophageal mucosa. questions.text:
Arrange the following structures of the femoral triangle from medial to lateral.
  1. Femoral nerve
  2. Sartorius
  3. Femoral vein
  4. Femoral artery
  5. Adductor longus
questions.solution:
The correct sequence of structures of the femoral triangle from medial to lateral is 5-3-4-1-2 i.e. adductor longus - femoral vein - femoral artery - femoral nerve - sartorius. 

The femoral triangle is an intermuscular space present in the anterior, proximal thigh. It is an inverted and depressed triangular space. The boundaries of the triangle include:

  • Base - inguinal ligament
  • Medial border - adductor longus
  • Lateral border - sartorius
  • Apex - confluence of the sartorius and adductor longus. 

Contents of the femoral triangle from medial to lateral are as follows- deep inguinal lymph nodes, femoral vein, femoral artery, and femoral nerve. 

The cadaveric image given below shows the contents of the femoral triangle.

The image given below shows the muscles forming the floor of the femoral triangle.

questions.text: A child treated for complaints of earache and discharge from the left ear now presents with mild hearing loss. On otoscopy, a bulging tympanic membrane is seen. What is the next best step?
questions.solution:
Myringotomy and aspiration of fluid is the next best step in serous otitis media, which the above clinical features are suggestive of. 

Serous otitis media is a condition with non-purulent effusion in the middle ear. The fluid is nearly sterile. Two mechanisms are associated with its pathogenesis - malfunctioning eustachian tube and increased secretory activity of the middle ear mucosa. 

Medical management of the condition includes topical decongestants, antibiotics, and anti-allergic measures. Frequently performing the Valsalva maneuver to aerate the middle ear is also helpful. Surgical treatment is indicated when medical management fails. Myringotomy and aspiration of fluid is the procedure carried out. If this fails, grommet insertion is carried out for sustained aeration of the middle ear.

The condition is mostly seen in children of the age group 5-8. They present with hearing loss, delayed or defective speech, and earaches. On otoscopy, the tympanic membrane is usually dull and opaque with a loss of light reflex. Mobility of the tympanic membrane is restricted. Tuning fork tests and audiometry usually reveals conductive hearing loss.

Atrophic tympanic membrane, tympanosclerosis, and ossicular necrosis are some of the sequelae of long-standing disease.

Myringotomy is used to describe an incision of the tympanic membrane to drain any effusion or to aerate the middle ear in the presence of a eustachian tube dysfunction. The procedure is carried out under general anesthesia in children, using a myringotome shown in the image below. 

Other options:

Option A: Tympanoplasty includes inspection of the middle ear cavity to ensure ossicular integrity in addition to repair of the tympanic membrane. 

Option B: Myringoplasty is the closure of a perforation in the pars tensa of the tympanic membrane. It is done in chronic suppurative otitis media with perforation.

Option D: Meatoplasty is done in acquired atresia or stenosis of the external auditory meatus.

Related Pearl: Myringotomy

Indications:
  • Acute suppurative otitis media:
    • Severe earache with the bulging tympanic membrane.
    • Incomplete resolution with opaque drum and persistent conductive deafness.
    • Complications of acute otitis media,e.g.facialparalysis, labyrinthitis or meningitis with the bulging tympanic membrane.
  • Serous otitis media.
  • Aero-otitis media (to drain fluid and “unlock” the eustachian tube).
  • Atelectatic ear (grommet is often inserted for long-term aeration).

Contraindication: Suspected intratympanic glomus tumor.

Incisions: 

  • In acute suppurative otitis media, a circumferential incision is made in the posteroinferior quadrant of the tympanic membrane, midway between the handle of malleus and tympanic annulus, avoiding injury to the incudostapedial joint.
  • In serous otitis media, a small radial incision is given in the anteroinferior quadrant and all the effusion is sucked out.

Complications:

  • Injury to incudostapedial joint or stapes.
  • Injury to jugular bulb with profuse bleeding, if jugular bulb is high and floor of the middle ear dehiscent.
  • Middle ear infection.

questions.text: A patient presents with seizures, severe abdominal pain, and dark-colored urine. She has a previous history of repeated hospital admission for similar complaints. A diagnosis of acute intermittent porphyria was made after a detailed workup. Which of the following drugs is contraindicated in this patient?
questions.solution:
The administration of barbiturates is contraindicated in acute intermittent porphyria.

Acute intermittent porphyria is a disorder of heme synthesis, characterized by a deficiency of hydroxymethylbilane synthase (HMBS).

Barbiturates are enzyme inducers and they result in the increased synthesis of porphyrins and subsequent precipitation of acute intermittent porphyria. The biochemical basis for the worsening of porphyria by barbiturates is the de-repression/induction of ALA synthase.

Barbiturates are metabolized by microsomal CYP450, a heme-protein oxidase system found in the liver. In patients with porphyria, barbiturates precipitate an attack of porphyria by the following mechanism:

 Barbiturates increase the synthesis of CYP450
 ↓
Enhanced consumption of heme
↓
A decrease in heme concentration in the liver 
↓
De-repression/induction of ALAS-1
↓
Increased synthesis of heme precursors
↓
Precipitation of porphyria


Other options:

Theophylline, chlorpromazine, and benzodiazepine are not contraindicated in acute intermittent porphyria.

questions.text: A 24-year-old woman was found dead at a cafe around midnight. Her face was congested with marked petechiae and her tongue was protruded and swollen. On examination, signs of struggle and a pale transverse mark completely encircling her neck below the thyroid cartilage were noted. Which of the following is the likely cause of her death?
questions.solution:
The given scenario and examination findings of a pale transverse mark completely encircling her neck below the thyroid cartilage with signs of struggle point toward a diagnosis of strangulation by ligature.

Strangulation is a type of asphyxia where there is neck constriction without suspension of the body. The pressure on the neck is applied either by bare hands, a ligature, or by any other instrument.

When strangulation is done by using a ligature like a constricting band or rope, it is called ligature strangulation. The constricting band is tightened by a force other than the victim's body weight. It is characterized by the ligature mark which is transverse and completely encircling the neck below the thyroid cartilage. There is no dribbling of saliva. Bleeding may be present in the ears, nose, and mouth.

Other options:

Option A: In a cafe coronary syndrome, the victim is usually healthy but grossly intoxicated and dies suddenly and unexpectedly during a meal with no signs of respiratory distress or of asphyxia. The autopsy reveals a bolus of food lodged in the pharynx or larynx. The cause of death in these patients is mechanical asphyxia leading to vasovagal reflex causing reflex cardiac inhibition.

Option B: Throttling or manual strangulation occurs due to compression of the neck by humans leading to asphyxia. Thumb impression and finger marks may be seen over the victim's neck. It is characterized by autopsy findings showing carotid intimal tear and muscle hematoma with nail marks on the neck and absence of ligature marks.

Option D: Mugging is a method of strangulation wherein the neck of the victim is caught in the bend of the assailant's elbow as shown below. Pressure is usually applied either in front of the larynx or at one or both sides of the neck.

questions.text: During a hearing assessment of a patient, he is able to tell the direction from which the sound is heard. Which of the following is responsible for the detection of the direction of sound?
questions.solution:
The lateral superior olivary nucleus is responsible for the detection of the direction of the sound. It is the starting point for the localisation of sound.

The mechanism by which it detects the direction of the sound is by comparison of the difference in intensities of the sound reaching the two ears and sending the signals to the auditory cortex that can detect the direction.

Other options:

Option B: Lateral geniculate body is seen in the visual pathway. It has two principal functions:

  • It relays visual information from the optic tract to the visual cortex by way of optic radiation
  • To gate the transmission of signals to the visual cortex. It controls how much of the signal is allowed to pass to the cortex.

Option C: The nerve fibres stimulated by the hair cells lead to the spiral ganglion of Corti, which lies in the centre of the cochlea. The spiral ganglion neuronal cells send axons into the cochlear nerve. 

Option D: Nerve fibres from the spiral ganglion of Corti enter the dorsal and ventral cochlear nuclei located in the upper part of the medulla. At this point, all the fibres synapse, and second-order neurons pass mainly to the opposite side of the brain stem to terminate in the superior olivary nucleus.

questions.text: A woman had a last menstrual period (LMP) of 13/2/2021. Calculate the expected date of delivery according to Naegele’s rule.
questions.solution:
As per Naegele’s rule, the expected date of delivery (EDD) of this woman is November 20, 2021.

Naegele’s rule states that EDD is obtained by adding 7 days and subtracting 3 months from the last menstrual period (LMP). The LMP is the 1st day of the last menstrual period. Another method is adding 9 months and 7 days to LMP. Less than 5% of births follow Naegele's rule. 

It is based on a 28-day regular cycle. If the cycle is shorter/longer than 28 days, corrected EDD is calculated as follows:

  • For a 35-day cycle, add another 7 (35-28=7) days to the calculated EDD to get the corrected EDD.
  • For a 25-day cycle, subtract 3 (28-25=3) days from the calculated EDD to get the corrected EDD.

questions.text: A young male patient presents with a high-grade fever, headache, and weakness for 4 days. The microscopic examination of the thin blood smear is given below. What is the most probable causative agent?
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario along with the thin blood smear showing the maltese cross appearance (black arrow) and ring form (yellow arrow) is suggestive of Babesia microti infection.

Babesia microti causes babesiosis. It is a zoonotic infection that resembles malaria. It is transmitted by a bite of ixodid ticks. The definitive host for Babesia is ixodid ticks whereas humans are the incidental, dead-end hosts.

Patients present with febrile illness, headache, and weakness. Lab investigations show hemolysis and hemoglobinuria.

On microscopic examination by Giemsa stain, Babesia trophozoites appear as intraerythrocytic round or pyriform or ring form. The ring form is the most common and it lacks the central hemozoin deposit which differentiates it from P. falciparum.

Other distinguishing features are the absence of schizonts and gametocytes and the presence of tetrads/ maltese crosses, which are pathognomic of B. microti or B. duncani.

Treatment:

Mild: Atovaquone + Azithromycin
Severe: Clindamycin + quinine
Fulminant case: exchange transfusion

questions.text: A 17-year-old girl presents with small bumps on the cheeks and nasolabial folds as shown in the image below. She is a known case of seizure disorder on medication. On examination, there is a hypopigmented oval patch on the lower back. What is the inheritance pattern of this disease?
questions.solution:
The given scenario of facial angiofibromas, seizures, and a hypomelanotic oval patch on the back suggests tuberous sclerosis (TS). It has an autosomal dominant pattern of inheritance.

Tuberous sclerosis is a multisystem disorder with an autosomal dominant inheritance mode. The mutations involve the TSC1 gene that encodes hamartin on chromosome 9 and the TSC2 gene that encodes a protein tuberin on chromosome 16.

Tuberous sclerosis is diagnosed when at least two major or one major plus two minor features are present.

  • Major features: 
    • Cortical dysplasias (including tubers and cerebral white matter migration lines)
    • Subependymal nodules
    • Subependymal giant cell astrocytoma
    • Facial angiofibromas (≥3) or forehead plaque
    • Ungual fibromas (≥2)
    • Hypomelanotic macules (≥3, ≥5 mm in diameter)
    • Shagreen patch
    • Multiple retinal nodular hamartomas
    • Cardiac rhabdomyoma
    • Renal angiomyolipoma
    • Pulmonary lymphangioleiomyomatosis
  • Minor features: 
    • Dental enamel pits (>3)
    • Intraoral fibromas (≥2)
    • Retinal achromic patch
    • Confetti skin lesions
    • Nonrenal hamartomas
    • Multiple renal cysts

The CT image given below shows subependymal nodules seen in TS.

Note: When these lesions are calcified, they project into the ventricular cavity having a candle-drip appearance.


Children are usually treated symptomatically with anticonvulsants and surgery for tumors. Vigabatrin can be used as a first-line agent for the treatment of infantile spasms in patients with tuberous sclerosis. Medical treatment with an mTOR inhibitor everolimus may be used for treating subependymal giant cell astrocytoma, and renal angiomyolipomas. Sirolimus, another mTOR inhibitor, is approved for management of lymphangioleiomyomatosis.

It is a neurocutaneous disorder (phakomatosis) characterized by the development of multiple benign tumors of the embryonic ectoderm (e.g. skin, eyes, and nervous system). It is an autosomal dominant condition.  The mutations are involved in the TSC1 gene that encodes hamartin on chromosome 9 and the TSC2 gene that encodes a protein tuberin on chromosome 16.

  • Mental retardation
  • Adenoma sebaceum

Skin lesions in tuberous sclerosis:

Shagreen patch consists of a roughened, raised lesion with an orange-peel consistency, located primarily in the lumbosacral region. Shagreen is shark skin used as a decorative material present in the right image given below.

The typical hypomelanotic ash leaf–type macules on the trunk and extremities are seen in 90% of the patients. It is visualized by the use of a wood ultraviolet lamp.

Facial angiofibromas (adenoma sebaceum) develop between 4 and 6 years of age; they appear as tiny red nodules over the nose and cheeks and are sometimes confused with acne. Later, they enlarge, coalesce, and assume a fleshy appearance.

Periungual fibroma are small fibromas or nodules of skin, which form around fingernails or toenails in some adolescent patients

Confetti skin lesions are seen less commonly as a minor feature of tuberous sclerosis.

questions.text: A patient came with complaints of dyspnea. Examination showed tender hepatomegaly, pedal edema, and jugular venous distension. On auscultation, a diastolic murmur was heard on the left lower sternal border. JVP waveform of the patient is given below. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The patient's congestive symptoms (hepatomegaly, pedal edema, and jugular venous distension), JVP showing giant a wave, and the presence of diastolic murmur in the tricuspid area — all point to a diagnosis of tricuspid stenosis.

Tricuspid stenosis does not occur as an isolated lesion, and is usually seen in association with mitral stenosis. It generally occurs as a consequence of rheumatic heart disease. Patients present with features of venous congestion, such as hepatomegaly, ascites, and edema. There is jugular venous distension, with giant a waves (due to increased RA pressure to pump the blood through the stenosed valve) and slow y descent (due to obstruction to emptying of the RA due to the stenosed valve).

On auscultation, a diastolic murmur is heard, appreciated best along the lower left sternal border and xiphisternum. The intensity of the murmur increases on inspiration and decreases during expiration and the Valsalva maneuver due to decreased blood flow across the tricuspid valve.

ECG shows features of right atrial enlargement which includes tall and peaked P waves in lead II and upright P waves in lead V1. Surgical treatment of TS is carried out at the time of MS repair.

questions.text: A 1-month-old infant was brought to you with hypotonia, a weak cough, and tongue fasciculations. A diagnosis of spinal muscular atrophy was made. Which of the following marked regions is affected in this condition?
questions.solution:
The region marked 1 which shows the anterior horn of the spinal cord is affected in spinal muscular atrophy.

Spinal muscular atrophy (SMA) is an autosomal recessive pattern disease characterized by progressive degeneration of the motor neurons. It results from a continuation of apoptosis that normally occurs in the embryonal period. This results in extensive neuronal degeneration and gliosis of the anterior horns of the spinal cord and brainstem motor nuclei.

Clinically SMA is classified into four types:

  • SMA type I/ Werdnig-Hoffmann disease
  • SMA type II
  • SMA type III/ Kugelberg-Welander disease
  • SMA type IV

SMA type I is seen before the age of six months. Children present with hypotonia, proximal muscle weakness, frog-leg posture, and tongue fasciculations. Involvement of the intercostal respiratory muscles causes a paradoxical abdominal breathing pattern and weak cough. Deep tendon reflexes are usually absent. It should be kept as one of the differential diagnoses for floppy infant syndrome.

SMA type II is seen between the age of 6-18 months. Children present with developmental delay, scoliosis, speech, and deglutition problems.

The proximal muscles involving the shoulder girdle are affected in SMA type III. Muscle hypertrophy might be present rather than atrophy.

SMA type IV (adult phenotype) presents with mild muscle weakness in the second or third decade of life. 

The gold standard for diagnosis is testing for SMN1 (survival motor neuron) gene deletion/ mutation. Supportive therapy enabling the patient to be maximally functionally independent is the mainstay in management.

questions.text:
An EEG conducted during sleep in a normal individual is given below. Identify the most likely change in neurotransmitters in the highlighted period.

EEG: Electroencephalogram
questions.solution:
In the given EEG, waves highlighted in red show the typical saw-tooth appearance of rapid eye movement (REM) sleep. The most likely change in neurotransmitters during this period is an increase in acetylcholine.

The other change in neurotransmitters during REM sleep is a decrease in serotonin and norepinephrine. 

An EEG is a recording that represents the electrical activity of the brain. It is used in localizing neuropathological lesions.

The brainstem ascending arousal system is composed of several groups of neurons like:

  • Locus coeruleus secrets norepinephrine
  • Raphe nucleus  secretes serotonin
  • Pontine nucleus secretes acetylcholine

During wakefulness, the locus coeruleus and raphe nucleus are dominant and the pontine is suppressed. Therefore, when a person is awake the norepinephrine and serotonin are increased and acetylcholine is decreased. There is also decreased GABA and increased histamine during wakefulness.

REM sleep occurs when the pontine nucleus is dominant and locus coeruleus and raphe nucleus are suppressed. Therefore acetylcholine is increased and norepinephrine and serotonin are decreased. 

NREM (non-rapid eye movement) sleep occurs when there is suppression of the thalamus and cortex due to an increase in GABA and a decrease in histamine. 

Other options: Increase in serotonin, norepinephrine, and histamine is seen during wakefulness. 

The image given below shows EEG patterns in different stages of sleep.

questions.text: A young woman is undergoing evaluation for infertility. Her cervical mucus sample shows the following appearance on microscopy. She had her menstrual period 22 days ago. Which of the following inferences can be drawn from this finding?

choices.text: This finding occurs due to progesterone
The woman is in mid luteal phase

questions.solution:
The presence of a fern pattern on the 22nd day of her menstrual cycle indicates that she has not ovulated. 

Estrogen makes the cervical mucus thinner and more alkaline to promote easy survival and transport of sperms. When the mucus is spread on the slide, it shows the fern pattern. After ovulation and during pregnancy, the levels of progesterone rise, and this hormone thickens the cervical mucus. The ferning pattern will no more be seen. 

The mucus is thinnest at the time of ovulation due to the increased levels of estrogen. It can be stretched into a long, thin thread that may be 8–12 cm or more in length. This is called the spinnbarkeit phenomenon.

 The tests for ovulation are:

  • The body temperature decreases during ovulation by 1/2°F. Thereafter, it increases by 1/2 to 1°F due to the thermogenic action of the progesterone.
  • Endometrial biopsy is usually done 1-2 days before menstruation. The presence of secretory changes in the endometrium suggests that ovulation has occurred. 
  • Fern test- Appearance of fern pattern is seen before ovulation. After ovulation, the progesterone thickens the cervical mucus leading to the loss of fern pattern.
  • Ultrasound- It is used to monitor the maturation of the Graafian follicle and ovulation.

Hormonal studies

  • Increased levels of plasma progesterone (~15 ng/mL) in the mid-luteal phase (22–23rd day) suggest that ovulation has occurred.
  • Determining the LH surge by urine or blood levels.

questions.text:
You are studying the lung volumes of a patient with COPD using an instrument shown below. Which of the following lung volumes cannot be measured using this instrument?

COPD: Chronic obstructive pulmonary disease
questions.solution:
The given image shows a spirometer. Residual volume (RV) cannot be measured using this instrument. It also cannot measure any capacity that involves residual volume i.e., functional residual capacity (FRC) and total lung capacity (TLC).

Residual volume is the amount of air remaining in the lung after forceful expiration. As we cannot expire this air, it cannot be directly measured by spirometry.

To measure RV, we need to first measure FRC by the helium dilution technique and then calculate RV by subtracting expiratory reserve volume (ERV) from FRC.

RV = FRC - ERV

A typical basic spirometer consists of a drum inverted over the chamber of water, along with a drum counterbalanced by a weight. When a person breathes into and out of the chamber, the drum rises and falls and recordings are made.

The image below shows a typical basic spirometer.

In the modern dry spirometer, the patient is asked to breathe in and exhale forcefully. The spirometer calculates the volume of air passing through it as a function of time. It hence gives us various parameters useful for the diagnosis of pulmonary/airway disease.

The image below shows the modern dry spirometer.

questions.text: A 65-year-old man presents with complaints of sudden onset pleuritic chest pain and dyspnea. On examination, his heart rate is 122 beats/minute and jugular venous pressure is elevated. Split S2 is heard on ascultation. He underwent inguinal hernia repair 3 weeks ago and was treated for deep vein thrombosis 6 months ago. His ECG findings are given below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario along with signs of acute cor pulmonale (right heart dysfunction) and ECG showing S1Q3T3 changes is most likely suggestive of acute pulmonary embolism (PE). 

Pulmonary embolism is very likely in this patient as his modified Well's score is 4.5 (>4 = PE likely):

  • Heart rate >100 beats/min- score 1.5
  • Recent history of immobilization due to abdominal surgery- score 1.5
  • Past history of deep vein thrombosis- score 1.5

ECG changes in acute PE (shown below) are characterized by the classic S1Q3T3 changes, due to right ventricular strain and ischemia:

  • A prominent S wave in lead I (blue arrow)
  • Q wave in lead III (red arrow)
  • An inverted T wave in lead III (green arrow)

 

Clinically, patients present with sudden onset of dyspnea, syncope, chest pain, and hypotension. Occlusion of the pulmonary artery may cause pulmonary artery hypertension and eventually leads to cor pulmonale/right ventricular dysfunction.

Cor pulmonale can be defined as an alteration in the structure and function of the right ventricle of the heart caused by a primary disorder of the respiratory system resulting in pulmonary hypertension. Patients present with elevated jugular venous pressure, split S2, ankle edema, hepatomegaly, and ascites.

The following algorithm guides the diagnosis of pulmonary embolism in a patient with a probability of PE.

 

Other options: 

Option B: Patients with pleural effusion present with pleuritic chest pain, progressive dyspnea, and cough. On examination, stony dullness on percussion, decreased tactile fremitus, and diminished breath sounds on the side of the effusion. ECG appears normal or may show non-specific findings such as low voltage QRS, axis deviation, and/or electrical alternans.

Option C: Acute pericarditis is the inflammation of the pericardial sac and is characterized by pleuritic chest pain as seen in this patient with PE. However, examination findings reveal a pericardial friction rub, and ECG shows diffuse ST-segment elevation and PR-segment depression.

Option D: Tricuspid stenosis (TS) is associated with elevated JVP as seen in this patient. However, TS is characterized by features of fatigue, hepatomegaly, and ascites due to the chronic nature of the disease. Auscultation reveals an opening snap and a diastolic murmur. ECG changes include tall, peaked P waves in lead II and prominent, upright P waves in V1.

Pulmonary embolism rule out criteria (PERC):

This is a quick OPD/casualty tool to rule out pulmonary embolism in patients with low clinical probability. It comprises eight clinical variables. If the patient meets all eight criteria, there is no need for further investigations. The variables include: 

  1. Age <50 years
  2. Heart rate <100 bpm
  3. SpO2 ≥95%
  4. No unilateral leg swelling
  5. No hemoptysis
  6. No recent trauma or surgery
  7. No history of venous thromboembolism
  8. No use of hormonal therapy.

Related Pearl: Chest X Ray signs in pulmonary embolism

McConnell's sign (indirect sign of PE seen in transthoracic echo): hypokinesis of the right ventricular free wall with normal motion of the right ventricle apex.

Knuckle or sausage’ sign: dilatation of the pulmonary artery, proximal to the embolus with collapse or constriction of the distal arteries resulting in an abrupt tapering of these arteries.  

Note - A normal chest X-ray does not rule out pulmonary embolism in a patient with unexplained acute tachypnea or hypoxemia.

questions.text: A 70-year-old woman was brought with complaints of progressive memory loss that began three years back. She recently forgot her way back home while returning from a market. There is no history of personality changes, rigidity, or gait disturbances. Which of the following is not a risk factor for the development of this disease?

choices.text: Use of non steroidal anti-inflammatory drugs
E4 allele of Apo E gene

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of progressive memory loss in an elderly woman, without any associated symptoms, is suggestive of Alzheimer’s disease (AD). The use of non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAID) is not a risk factor for this disease.

Alzheimer's disease is a condition characterized by progressive deterioration of memory. It is the most common cause of dementia in the elderly.

The risk factors include:

  • Age >70 years and female gender
  • Positive family history and Apo ε4 allele
  • Diabetes, hypertension, elevated levels of homocysteine and cholesterol 
  • Diminished intake of folic acid, fruits, vegetables, red wine, and low levels of exercise
  • Down's syndrome.

Use of NSAIDs has been shown to be protective against AD.

Pathology shows the presence of neuritic plaques and neurofibrillary tangles. A central core of amyloid, proteoglycans, ApoE, α-antichymotrypsin, and other proteins form the neuritic plaques while neurofibrillary tangles are composed of silver-staining neuronal cytoplasmic fibrils made of abnormally phosphorylated tau proteins. 

Patients may have the following features

  • Memory impairment gets unrecognized in the early stages. Eventually, interference with daily activities like difficulty in keeping track of finances, driving, shopping, and housekeeping may be seen. In severe impairment, the patient easily gets lost and confused.
  • Language deficits appear as impairment in naming followed by comprehension and fluency.
  • Patients have difficulty dressing, eating, copying geometric figures, and reading the clock due to their visuospatial deficits.

It is treated with cholinesterase inhibitors like donepezil, galantamine, rivastigmine, and NMDA receptor antagonist like memantine.

Related Pearl: Alzheimer’s disease

Alzheimer’s disease:

  • Age of onset > 60 years
  • Mini-mental state examination (MMSE) < 24
  • Diagnosis: Clinical
    • 2 or more areas of cognitive deficits
    • Progressive worsening of memory and other cognitive function
    • No disturbance in consciousness
    • Other systemic causes must be ruled out 

Risk Factors:

  • Most important risk factor: Old age
  • Other risk factors – Family history, presenilin-1, presenilin-2, Apolipoprotein E4 (ApoE ε4 allele), Ubiquitin, Down syndrome and smoking.

Protective factors: NSAIDs and Apolipoprotein E2

Causes: Decrease in acetylcholine causing depletion of the cholinergic neurons in the nucleus basalis of Meynert resulting in short-term memory defects. 

Early findings:

  • Anterograde memory loss (immediate recall affected, distant memories preserved)
  • Visuospatial deficits (lost in own neighborhood)
  • Language difficulties (difficulty finding words)
  • Cognitive impairment with a progressive decline
  • Anosognosia 
  • Visual processing dysfunction (posterior cortical atrophy syndrome)
  • Difficulties with naming and repetition (logopenic aphasia)

Late findings:

  • Psychotic symptoms: delusions
  • Apraxia: Difficulty to perform learned motor tasks
  • Lack of insight regarding deficits
  • Non-cognitive neurologic deficits: Pyramidal and extrapyramidal, myoclonus and seizures
  • disrupted sleep - wake pattern.
  • Urinary incontinence.
  • Loss of procedural memory

Histopathology:

  • Senile plaques (amyloid deposits), neurofibrillary tangles (composed of tau proteins), neuronal loss, synaptic loss, and granulovacuolar degeneration of neurons.

The image below shows neurofibrillary tangles in Alzheimer's disease.

CT/MRI:

  • Later stages: Cortical and subcortical atrophy prominent in parietal and temporal lobes, particularly hippocampus. 

Treatment:

  • NMDA antagonist: memantine
  • Cholinesterase inhibitors: donepezil, galantamine, rivastigmine.
  • Monoclonal antibodies against the N-terminus of the Aβ peptide - lecanemab, donanemab

questions.text: An anxious woman presents to you with complaints of watering of the right eye while eating. She gives a history of transient facial weakness a few months back. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of crocodile tear syndrome or Bogard syndrome (gustatory lacrimation). It is due to residual facial paralysis or faulty regeneration of the nervus intermedius of the facial nerve. It presents as unilateral lacrimation during eating and drinking.

It is seen in cases where the facial nerve is damaged proximal to the geniculate ganglion. During regeneration, the fibres supplying the salivary gland aberrantly supply the lacrimal gland.

It can be treated by section of the greater superficial petrosal nerve or tympanic neurectomy.

questions.text: A  hosteller developed papules with excoriation in the interdigital web spaces, groin, and under-surface of the breasts. She tells that lesions are intensely pruritic at night and her roommate has similar complaints. Identify the wrong statement about the vector causing this condition, shown in the image below.

choices.text: Life cycle of  the vector has 4 stages
Male parasite burrows into the epidermis
The entire life cycle takes about 15 days

questions.solution:
The clinical background is probably suggestive of scabies. The given image depicts an itch mite also called Sarcoptes scabiei. The incorrect statement is that the male parasite burrows into the epidermis.

The female parasite burrows into the stratum corneum layer of the epidermis and lays eggs in the burrow. A single female may lay about 30 eggs at a rate of 2 to 3 per day and ultimately dies at the end of the burrow. The larval stage, which emerges from the eggs, has 3 pairs of legs. After the larvae moult, the resulting nymphs have 4 pairs of legs.

The life cycle has 4 stages- egg, larva, nymph, and adult. It takes about 10-15 days to progress from egg to adult. However, the adult mites live for 1 to 2 months.

Itching is a hypersensitivity reaction to the eggs and dead parasites in the epidermis. Clinical features include itching severe at night, superficial burrows in the affected site, and secondary infection of the lesions leading to crusted papules and pustules. Multiple members of a household may be affected, hence simultaneous treatment of all the household contacts is essential.

 

The diagnosis is made by visualizing the parasite in skin debris under a microscope. Permethrin cream - 5% is the treatment of choice.

questions.text: An elderly woman presents to you with multiple joint pains. On examination, you notice the following deformity over the ring and little finger. This deformity is called:
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario is suggestive of rheumatoid arthritis. The is showing hyperextension of distal interphalangeal (DIP) joints and flexion at proximal interphalangeal (PIP) joints suggestive of Boutonniere deformity.

Rheumatoid arthritis (RA) is a chronic inflammatory disease of symmetric polyarthritis, mainly affecting the small joints of the hands and feet. The wrists and metacarpophalangeal and proximal interphalangeal joints are most frequently involved. Clinically, patients present with early morning joint pain and stiffness lasting >1 hour that relieves with activity.

A Boutonniere deformity occurs due to the rupture of the central slip of the extensor tendon. Normally, the central slip of the extensor tendon inserts into the base of the middle phalanx. Following rupture of the central slip, the lateral slips also separate creating a gap. The head of the proximal phalanx goes through the gap, resembling a button going through a buttonhole.

The image below shows the two most common deformities in RA.

Being a systemic disease, RA causes various extra-articular manifestations, like subcutaneous nodules, lung involvement, pericarditis, peripheral neuropathy, vasculitis, and anemia of chronic disease.

Patients may have elevated ESR (erythrocyte sedimentation rate), and CRP (C reactive protein). Rheumatoid factor and anti-CCP (cyclic citrullinated peptide) antibodies are helpful in prognosis. Progression of joint damage is assessed by plain X-ray.

Management includes non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs), glucocorticoids, and DMARDs (disease-modifying anti-rheumatoid drugs) like methotrexate, hydroxychloroquine, sulfasalazine, leflunomide. Biological agents such as TNF-α inhibitors, abatacept, anakinra, rituximab, and interleukin -6 inhibitors are also helpful in RA.

questions.text: An elderly man with a long-standing history of memory loss and behavioral changes passed away. On autopsy, brain atrophy was noted. A histopathology section of his brain showed the following finding. This protein is most likely to be:
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of Alzheimer’s disease and the above image shows neurofibrillary tangles inside the neuron. These are formed from helical filaments of abnormal tau proteins.

In Alzheimer’s disease, neurofibrillary tangles and amyloid plaques are found in the brain, especially in the hippocampus. Neurofibrillary tangles are deposited inside the neurons, whereas amyloid plaques are deposited around the neurons.

Other options:

Option A: Amyloid plaques are made of beta-amyloid precursor protein (APP). They are deposited around the neurons. Amyloid plaque is shown in the image below:


Option B: Prions deposit in the neurons and cause apoptosis. The degeneration of these neurons leads to spongiform encephalopathy. The protein gets deposited as plaques.

The image given below shows the spongiform appearance of the brain seen in prion disease.


Option D: Alzheimer's disease may also have Lewy body. Lewy bodies are formed due to the clumping of abnormal alpha-synuclein protein in the neurons. They predominantly cause Lewy body dementia but can also be found in Parkinson’s and Alzhiemer's disease.

The image given below shows Lewy body.
