  • Loss of procedural memory

Histopathology:

  • Senile plaques (amyloid deposits), neurofibrillary tangles (composed of tau proteins), neuronal loss, synaptic loss, and granulovacuolar degeneration of neurons.

The image below shows neurofibrillary tangles in Alzheimer's disease.

CT/MRI:

  • Later stages: Cortical and subcortical atrophy prominent in parietal and temporal lobes, particularly hippocampus. 

Treatment:

  • NMDA antagonist: memantine
  • Cholinesterase inhibitors: donepezil, galantamine, rivastigmine.
  • Monoclonal antibodies against the N-terminus of the Aβ peptide - lecanemab, donanemab

questions.text: A young HIV-positive male presented with headache and nuchal rigidity to the emergency room. India ink preparation of cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) is given below. Which of the following is false regarding the causative organism?

choices.text: Smooth, mucoid and creamy white colonies on culture
Infection is by inhalation of the yeast cells
Patients with sarcoidosis are immune to this infection.
Treated with amphotericin B with flucytosine

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and the India ink preparation of CSF showing capsulated budding yeast cells are highly suggestive of cryptococcal meningitis, caused by Cryptococcus neoformans. The false statement is option C, as patients with sarcoidosis are at higher risk of getting the infection.

Cryptococcus neoformans is an opportunistic fungus that mainly affects patients suffering from AIDS, Sarcoidosis, and patients on glucocorticoid therapy. It is found as a saprophyte in soil enriched with pigeon droppings. Infection is by inhalation of the yeast cells(option B).

The image given below shows the life cycle of Cryptococcus neoformans.

The primary pulmonary infection may be asymptomatic or may mimic an influenza-like respiratory infection, often resolving spontaneously. Cutaneous infection results in ulcers, and granulomata.

In immunocompromised, the yeasts may multiply and disseminate to other parts of the body but preferentially to the central nervous system, causing cryptococcal meningoencephalitis presenting with headache and nuchal rigidity.

Diagnosis is established by microscopic examination of cerebrospinal fluid, BAL fluid or blood samples. India ink preparation reveals capsulated budding yeast cells.

Mucicarmine stain can also be used in the identification of cryptococcus. The image given below shows mucicarmine stained specimen of lung tissue containing cryptococci:

Culture on Sabouraud dextrose agar (SDA) at 37'C appears as smooth, mucoid, and creamy white (option A). The cryptococcal antigen(in serum and CSF) is sensitive and specific and can be demonstrated by the latex agglutination test.

Treatment of cryptococcal meningitis involves combination therapy of amphotericin B with flucytosine (option D). Fluconazole can be added with these drugs in AIDS patients to prevent relapse.

questions.text: A 10-year-old boy comes with complaints of diminished vision. On examination, the macula shows a ‘beaten-bronze’ appearance. Furthermore, visual fields show a central loss. The choroid is characteristically ‘dark’ in fluorescein angiography. All of the following about this disease are true except:

choices.text: Vitamin A supplementation should be given
Accumulation of lipofuscin within retinal pigment epithelium
It is inherited in autosomal recessive pattern

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario suggests a diagnosis of Stargardt disease. Vitamin A supplementation is avoided as it may accelerate lipofuscin accumulation.

Stargardt disease/ fundus flavimaculatus is the most common type of macular dystrophy occurring in childhood or adolescence. It is commonly inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern due to mutation in the ABCA4 gene. It is characterized by the accumulation of lipofuscin within the retinal pigment epithelium(RPE). 

Macular signs

  • May initially be normal, later progressing to an oval ‘snail slime’ or ‘beaten-bronze’ appearance and subsequently to geographic atrophy.
  • Numerous yellow-white round, oval or fish-shaped lesions at the level of the RPE.

Investigations:

  • Visual fields show a central loss.
  • Electroretinography - Pattern ERG is completely extinguished while full-field ERG may remain normal.
  • FFA- Dark choroid, the macula shows mixed hyper and hypofluorescence.
  • Indocyanine green angiography (ICGA) shows hyperfluorescent spots.

Image A shows the fundus with macular yellow flecks and B shows the angiofluoresceingraphy (AFG) of the silent choroid and atrophic retinal pigment epithelium at the macular area.

questions.text: Identify the instrument.
questions.solution:
The given image is that of an enucleation spoon. This is identified by the central cleavage that engages the optic nerve in enucleation.

 

Other options:

Option A- Evisceration spatula consists of a small but stout rectangular blade with a slightly convex surface and blunt edges attached to a handle. It is used to separate out the uveal tissue from the sclera during evisceration operation.

 

Option C- Chalazion clamp consists of two limbs like forceps, which can be clamped with the help of a screw. The tip of one limb is flattened in the
form of a round disc while the tip of the other arm has a small circular ring. It is used to fix the chalazion and achieve hemostasis during the incision and curettage operation.

 

Option D- Bone punch consists of a stout spring handle and two blades attached at a right angle. It is used to enlarge the bony opening during
dacryocystorhinostomy (DCR) operation by punching the bone from the margins of the opening.

questions.text: A 30-year old male patient presents with complaints of frequent, long-standing respiratory tract infections. He is a known case of cystic fibrosis. Which among the given organisms is more commonly implicated in such patients?
questions.solution:
Among the given options, Pseudomonas aeruginosa is a common etiological agent associated with chronic airway infection in patients with cystic fibrosis (CF).

Cystic fibrosis is an autosomal recessive exocrinopathy affecting multiple epithelial tissues. In this condition, due to the CFTR protein defect, there is thick inspissated mucus and impaired mucociliary clearance. Due to these factors, P. aeruginosa can cause chronic infection/colonization of the respiratory tract in patients of CF.

A complex bacterial flora that includes Staphylococcus aureus, Haemophilus influenzae, and Pseudomonas aeruginosa is routinely cultured from CF sputum. Infection with Pseudomonas aeruginosa is common in adults with CF

Pseudomonas aeruginosa is a gram-negative, catalase-positive, oxidase-positive, non-lactose fermenting bacteria that shows swarming motility.

The GIF below shows swarming motility seen in Pseudomonas aeruginosa.

They produce a characteristic blue-green pigment called pyocyanin and a greenish-yellow pigment called fluorescein/pyoverdin. Other pigments produced by these organisms include pyorubin (Red), pyomelanin (Brown).

The image given below shows green coloured colonies of Pseudomonas aeruginosa on a nutrient agar.

Diseases caused by Pseudomonas aeruginosa:

  • Burns infections
  • Opportunistic and nosocomial infections
  • Shanghai fever: severe enteric disease and sepsis
  • Malignant otitis externa in diabetics
  • Jacuzzi syndrome (Hot tub folliculitis)
  • Ecthyma gangrenosum
  • Green-nail syndrome

Other options:

Option A: Stenotrophomonas maltophila, formerly called Pseudomonas maltophila, is an opportunistic pathogen that causes wound infection, urinary tract infection, and septicemia. It is sensitive to cotrimoxazole.

Option B: Burkholderia pseudomallei, formerly called Pseudomonas pseudomallei, is the causative agent of melioidosis, a disease that can manifest as acute septicemia, pneumonia, hemoptysis resembling tuberculosis, or a chronic form with abscess formation in the skin and subcutaneous tissues, bones, and internal organs.

Option D: Burkholderia cepacia, formerly called Pseudomonas cepacia, is an opportunistic pathogen that causes fatal necrotizing pneumonia.

Stenotrophomonas maltophila, Burkholderia pseudomallei, Burkholderia cepacia infections have also been found to be associated with CF. However, among the given options, Pseudomonas aeruginosa infections are more commonly seen in such patients.

questions.text: The tumor cells as shown in the image are seen in:
questions.solution:
The cells shown in the slide are cloverleaf or flower cells with multilobulated nuclei that are frequently observed in adult T-cell leukemia/lymphoma.

Adult T-cell leukemia/ lymphoma occurs in adults infected by human T-cell leukemia retrovirus type 1 (HTLV-1). It is a neoplasm of CD4+ cells and is a rapidly progressive disease that is fatal within months to 1 year.

Common findings include skin lesions, generalized lymphadenopathy, hepatosplenomegaly and hypercalcemia.

Peripheral smear blood shows characteristic cloverleaf cells or flower cells which are tumour cells with multilobulated nuclei. Lymphocytosis is also observed.

Other options:

Mantle cell lymphoma is a type of Non-Hodgkin lymphoma in which the proliferation consists of a homogeneous population of small lymphocytes with irregular to occasionally deeply cleft (cleaved) nuclear contours. 

Peripheral T cell lymphoma is composed of malignant T cells of varied sizes with infiltration of reactive cells, such as eosinophils and macrophages. 

Anaplastic large cell lymphoma occurs due to mutation in ALK gene. It consists of large anaplastic cells with horseshoe-shaped nuclei and spacious cytoplasm (hallmark cells).

questions.text: A patient with chronic angina was prescribed a new drug, ranolazine. This drug acts by which of the following mechanism?

choices.text: Inhibit funny currents in SA node

questions.solution:
Ranolazine acts by late sodium current inhibition in the heart. It is used in the prophylaxis of angina.

Late sodium current (INa) facilitates the entry of calcium via the sodium-calcium exchanger. Inhibition of INa, therefore, reduces the intracellular calcium concentration which in turn reduces the diastolic tension and cardiac contractility.

At higher doses, it may also modify the fatty acid oxidation (pFOX inhibitor), which improves the efficiency of cardiac oxygen utilisation but whether this actually occurs at therapeutic doses is still being studied. It also has mild beta-blocking activity.

Ranolazine is the second-line FDA-approved drug for heart failure. Side effects of ranolazine include dizziness, headache, and postural hypotension.

Other options:

Option A: Ivabradine selectively blocks the funny current (If) channel involved in the generation of automaticity in the SA node. It reduces heart rate and thereby oxygen demand. It does not have any effect on cardiac contractility. It is an FDA-approved drug for the treatment of heart failure. It is also used for treating stable angina.

Option C: Fasudil acts by inhibiting smooth muscle Rho kinase and reduces coronary vasospasm.

Option D: Nicorandil acts as an agonist at ATP-sensitive potassium (KATP) channels i.e. potassium channel opener. It decreases afterload and preload of the heart by its vasodilatory properties at both arterioles and venules. It is used for the treatment of stable angina.

Note: Trimetazidine is a pFOX inhibitor that partially inhibits fatty acid oxidation in the myocardium. Thereby, it decreases the oxygen requirement. It is also used as an anti-anginal agent.

Related Pearl: Anti-anginal drugs

Anti-anginal drugs can be divided into the following categories:

  • Nitrates - dilates veins > arteries, reduces preload
  • Calcium channel blockers - blocks L-type calcium channels
    • Dihydropyridines - amlodipine, nifedipine
    • Non-dihydropyridines - verapamil, diltiazem
  • Beta-blockers - decreases heart rate, contractility and oxygen demand
  • Other drugs: 
    • Ranolazine - late Na+ channel blocker
    • Ivabradine - inhibit funny currents in SA node
    • Nicorandil - K+-ATP channel agonist
    • Trimetazidine - pFOX inhibitor
    • Fasudil - rho-kinase inhibitor

questions.text: A person after having a meal had a sense of fullness and feels that he can no longer eat. Which area of the hypothalamus acts as the centre for the given physiological process?
questions.solution:
The physiological process explained in the question stem is that of satiety. The ventromedial nucleus of the hypothalamus acts as the centre for satiety.

A centre that reduces the desire for food is known as a satiety centre. These centres are sensitive to blood glucose concentration and cause satiety in hyperglycemic states. The hypothalamic areas that regulate satiety are:

  • Ventromedial nucleus 
  • Arcuate nucleus (also acts as a centre for hunger)
  • Paraventricular nucleus (also regulates oxytocin release and water conservation)

Other options:

Option A: Supraoptic nucleus regulates vasopressin release.

Option B: Medial preoptic area regulates bladder contraction, heart rate and blood pressure.

Option D: Lateral hypothalamic area is responsible for causing thirst and eating. It also stimulates rage and fighting.

questions.text: McNaughten rule is concerned with ______.
questions.solution:
The McNaughten rule is concerned with the criminal responsibility of the insane. In India, the law of criminal responsibility is under Sec 84 I.P.C.

  • McNaughten’s Rule was formed by the Judges of McNaughten’s case, to clarify the common law of insanity in England during 1843. It is similar to IPC 84 which states “Nothing is an offence which is done by a person who at the time of doing it by reason of unsoundness of mind is incapable of knowing the nature of the act, or that he is doing what is either wrong or contrary to law.
  • Curren's rule of 1961 states that an accused person is not criminally responsible if, at the time of committing the act, he did not have the capacity to regulate his conduct to the requirements of the law, as a result of mental disease or defect.
  • Durham's rule of 1954 States that an accused person is not criminally responsible if his unlawful act is the product of mental disease or mental defect. 

 

Other options - 

Option A: Criminal responsibility for voluntary intoxication - An intoxicated person (voluntary intoxication) is criminally responsible if he had the intention or knowledge of committing a crime (Sec 86 IPC).

Option B: Criminal responsibility for involuntary intoxication - An act done by a person, who is incapable of knowing the nature of the act due to intoxication is not an offence, if the thing which intoxicated him was administered to him without his knowledge or against his will (Sec 85 IPC)

Option D: Criminal responsibility of a child - Any act which is done by a child under seven years of age is not an offence (Sec 82 IPC). A child between 7-12 years is presumed to be capable of committing an offence, if he attained sufficient maturity of understanding to judge the nature and consequences of his conduct on that occasion (Sec. 83 IPC). This maturity is presumed in a child unless proved otherwise by the defence.

questions.text: Surgical consultation is planned for a neonate in the neonatal intensive care unit. On examination, the following findings were found along with a bifid uvula. Which of the following is the most appropriate management for this child?

choices.text: Cleft soft palate repair at 9 to 12 months
Cleft lip and soft palate repair at 5 to 6 months
Cleft soft and hard palate repair at 12-15 months

questions.solution:
The most appropriate management for this patient would be cleft lip and soft palate repair at 5 to 6 months. 

As the neonate in question has a unilateral right-sided cleft lip along with cleft hard and soft palate, the appropriate management for this patient would be (two separate procedures):

  • Cleft lip and soft palate repair at 5 to 6 months, followed by 
  • Hard palate repair with or without a revision surgery for the lip and soft palate at 15 to 18 months.

The different types of facial clefts are shown below:

  1. Unilateral cleft lip with alveolar involvement
  2. Bilateral cleft lip with alveolar involvement
  3. Unilateral cleft lip associated with cleft palate
  4. Bilateral cleft lip and palate
  5. Cleft palate only

Clefts of the lip, alveolus and hard and soft palate are the common congenital anomalies of the orofacial structures.

Cleft-lip repair techniques:

  • Millard’s rotation advancement technique (most common)
  • Thompson
  • Le Mesurier
  • Tennison–Randall

Techniques of hard palate closure include the use of the following:

  • Unipedicled hard palate mucoperiosteal flaps as in the Wardill-Veau-Kilner repair 
  • Bipedicled hard palate mucoperiosteal flaps as in the von Langenbeck repair

questions.text: A preterm baby was treated with a high flow of oxygen for respiratory distress syndrome. During fundus screening, you observe the development of a white ridge from the demarcation line. What is the stage of retinopathy of prematurity as per the international classification of retinopathy of prematurity staging?
questions.solution:
As per the international classification of retinopathy of prematurity staging, the development of a white ridge from the demarcation line comes under stage 2.

Retinopathy of prematurity is a proliferative disease of the retina occurring in premature infants with low birth weight who are treated with a high concentration of oxygen. 

The international classification of retinopathy of prematurity (ICROP) establishes the anatomical location (zone) and the severity (clinical stage) of the disease.

Location:

Zone I: Circular area with a radius twice the distance from the disc to the fovea, with the disc as the centre. 
Zone II: It covers the area beyond zone I circumferentially till nasal Ora Serrata.
Zone III: It consists of residual temporal crescent anterior to zone II.

Its stages are as follows: 

 

Important risk factors for retinopathy of prematurity are preterm babies, especially less than 32 weeks, low birth weight less than 1500 g and supplemental oxygen therapy.

Screening all preterm babies for ROP forms the mainstay in early diagnosis and treatment of the disease to prevent blindness. Babies with birth weight <1500 g or born before 32 weeks of gestation should be screened with indirect ophthalmoscopy for retinopathy of prematurity at 4 weeks after birth. Babies with birth weight  <1200g or born before 28 weeks of gestation should be screed at 2-3 weeks after birth.

questions.text: A newborn is being evaluated after a difficult birth. A deformity is present in the left arm as shown in the image below. Which of the following nerve root is most likely affected?
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario with the image showing a claw hand with a supinated forearm and the flexed elbow is likely suggestive of Klumpke's palsy. The C8-T1 nerve roots are affected in this condition. 

Klumpke's palsy occurs following an injury to the 8th cervical nerve and the 1st thoracic nerve. It is commonly seen after deliveries involving excessive traction on the brachial plexus. It results in a paralyzed hand where the intrinsic muscles of the hand (T1) and the ulnar flexors of the wrist and fingers (C8) are mainly affected.

Clinically, the baby lies with the forearm supinated and the elbow flexed. There is a loss of intrinsic muscle power and reflexes in the hand. There may be a unilateral Horner’s syndrome, characterized by ipsilateral ptosis and miosis if the sympathetic fibers of the 1st thoracic root are also injured.

Immobilization and prevention of contractures form the mainstay of treatment in Klumpke's palsy.

The image given below shows clinical features seen in Klumpke's palsy.

Narakas classification for babies delivered via cephalic presentation with brachial plexus injury is as follows: 

  • Group 1: C5/C6
  • Group 2: C5/C6/C7
  • Group 3: Entire plexus involved
  • Group 4: Entire plexus with Horner's sign

Other options: 

Option A: Median nerve palsy (C6 -T1) presentation depends on the level of the lesion. Low lesions present as impaired abduction of the thumb and loss of sensation over the radial 3 1/2 digits. High lesions will have the features of low lesions, but will also have paralysis of the radial wrist flexors and forearm pronator muscles. The hand will be held with the ulnar fingers flexed and the index straight (pointing index sign). 

Option B: In a total plexus injury, C5 - T1 are injured. Here, the baby's arm is flail and pale. There is paralysis of all the fingers and unilateral Horner's syndrome. 

Option D: C5 - C6 injury is seen in Erb's palsy. It is typically seen in overweight babies with shoulder dystocia at delivery. There is paralysis of the abductors, external rotators of the shoulder, and the supinators. The arm will be held to the side in internal rotation and pronation with loss of finger extension.

The following image shows the clinical presentation of Erb's palsy.

questions.text: An adolescent girl with primary amenorrhea and short stature presents with exercise intolerance and difficulty breathing. Examination revealed a difference in blood pressure between the upper and lower limbs and a continuous murmur in the infra-scapular region. Which of the following conditions is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The findings of the difference in blood pressure between upper and lower limbs and continuous murmur in the infra-scapular region are suggestive of coarctation of the aorta.

Coarctation of the aorta is a congenital heart disease in which there is a narrowing of the descending aorta, usually distal to the origin of the left subclavian artery. It is commonly associated with Turner's syndrome, which is characterized by short stature, webbed neck, and primary amenorrhea. 

Clinical features include differences in blood pressure and pulse in upper and lower extremities, prominent pulsations, radio femoral delay, and continuous murmur over the infra-scapular region or the scapula.

It is associated with the bicuspid aortic valve, arterial hypertension, an aortic aneurysm, left ventricular hypertrophy, left heart failure, atherosclerosis, and cerebral aneurysm.

The figure of 3 sign refers to the indentation of the aorta at the coarctation site. There is pre and post-stenotic dilatation along with left paramediastinal shadow, as shown below:

 

Notching of ribs  (Roesler's sign) due to inferior rib erosion by dilated intercostal collateral vessels, as seen the image given below:

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman at 26 weeks of gestation presented with an episode of painless bleeding per vagina. The bleeding has since resolved. She experienced abdominal pains which were determined to be contractions prior to the episode. The image given below represents her condition. Which of the following is not indicated in the management of this condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and the image showing an abnormally implanted placenta that is overlapping the internal os is suggestive of placenta previa. The digital examination is not indicated in placenta previa as it can lead to severe hemorrhage. 

Common risk factors for placenta previa include previous cesarian section or myomectomy, advanced maternal age (>35 years), smoking, multiple gestation, multiparity, and prior curettage.

Clinical features include painless bleeding. This usually occurs around the end of the second trimester but can occur earlier. It occurs without an inciting event or contractions and is not severe enough to be fatal and stops on its own. However, it can recur. In patients with a low-lying placenta, the bleeding may only present at the time of labor. 

Management options can be divided into expectant management and active or definite management. 

Expectant management has been described by Macafee and Johnson.

Prerequisites: Blood should be available for transfusion if required, and facilities for cesarean section should be made available 24 hours a day. 

Suitable cases for expectant management for placenta previa:

  • Mother in good health (Hb ≥10 g%; hematocrit ≥30%)
  • Duration of pregnancy <37 wk
  • No active vaginal bleeding
  • Fetal well-being is assured (USG and cardiotocography)

The components of expectant treatment include: 

  • Bed rest (Option A) with bathroom and toilet privilege
  • Investigations like hemoglobin estimation, blood grouping, urine for protein, etc
  • Periodic examination of vulval pads
  • Fetal surveillance with ultrasound at an interval of 2-3 weeks
  • Supplementary hematinics should be provided
  • If the patient is anemic, then the loss of blood is treated with adequate cross-matched blood transfusion
  • 2-3 days after the bleeding stops, the patient is allowed out of bed and examined with a gentle speculum to rule out local causes of bleeding
  • Tocolysis (Option C) if associated with contractions
  • Rh immunoglobulin to be given to Rh-negative mothers

Ideally, a hospital setting is ideal but if prolonged, then bed rest at home can be considered if the patient lives close to the hospital, has 24-hour transportation, and is well motivated to understand the risk. 

Expectant management can be continued till 37 weeks of gestation. 

Indications of definitive management (delivery) include :

  • Bleeding occurs at or after 37 weeks of pregnancy.
  • The patient is in labor.
  • The patient is in an exsanguinated state on admission.
  • Continuous bleeding and of a moderate degree.
  • Baby with nonreassuring cardiac status, dead, or known to be congenitally deformed. 

Patients with placenta previa confirmed on ultrasound are always scheduled for cesarean delivery (Option D), which is performed in patients who are near-term and are not currently bleeding. This is usually scheduled for 36-37 weeks of gestation. Vaginal delivery may be considered if the placental edge is 2-3cm away from the internal os as confirmed by ultrasound. 

The following image shows the different degrees of placenta previa.

questions.text: A young woman is brought by her mother to the psychiatry OPD for evaluation. She said that her daughter wants to leave home because she is the 'chosen one' to make some important discovery to save humanity. She appears normal with no relevant past history. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
In the given scenario, the young woman firmly believes that she is the 'chosen one' to make some important discovery, with no other symptoms. The most likely diagnosis, in this case, is delusion of grandeur.

Delusions are firm false belief, that is held despite objective and obvious contradictory proof. Other members of the culture do not share this belief. Patients with delusional disorders usually have non-bizarre delusions, i.e. situations that can happen in real life, such as making an important discovery (grandeur), having an unfaithful partner (Othello syndrome), etc. This should be differentiated from schizophrenia where patients have bizarre delusions, such as aliens controlling them or having weird creatures around them, etc.

Patients with the delusion of grandeur will have an exaggerated conception of one's importance, power, or identity.

Risk factors for delusional disorders:

  • Increasing age
  • Sensory impairment or isolation
  • Personality features (e.g.unusual interpersonal sensitivity)
  • Positive family history
  • Isolated socially
  • Recent immigration

DSM-5 criteria for diagnosis of delusional disorder:

  • The presence of one (or more) delusions with a duration of 1 month or longer.
  • Criteria for schizophrenia have never been met.
  • Functioning is not markedly impaired, and behavior is not obviously bizarre or odd.
  • If manic or major depressive episodes have occurred, these have been brief relative to the duration of the delusional periods.
  • Not attributable to substance abuse, another medical condition, or another mental disorder.

Related Pearl: Types of delusions

THE TYPES OF DELUSIONS

Delusion of control

False belief that a person’s will, thoughts, or feelings are being controlled by external forces.

Delusion of grandeur or Megalomania 

Exaggerated conception of one’s importance, power, or identity.

Delusion of infidelity or morbid jealousy or Othello syndrome

False belief that one’s lover is unfaithful. Sometimes called pathological jealousy.

Delusion of love or erotomania

False belief that another person is in love with them. In De Clerambault syndrome, the woman believes that a man, frequently older and of higher status, is in love with her.

Delusion of misidentification 

Capgras syndrome: Belief that a familiar person has been replaced by an exact double i.e. an impostor.

Fregoli syndrome: Person holds a delusional belief that different people are in fact a single person who changes his or her appearance or is in disguise.

Nihilistic delusion 

False belief that oneself, others or the world, is non-existent or about to end. When nihilistic delusion is accompanied by ideas concerning bodily function failure e.g. putrefaction of intestine etc, it is called Cotard syndrome.

Delusion of infestation 

False belief that one is infested with small but visible organisms. As a monosymptomatic delusional disorder, this is called Ekbom syndrome. 

Delusion of persecution

The most common delusion. False belief of being harassed or persecuted.

Delusion of poverty

The person strongly believes they are financially incapacitated.

Delusion of reference

False belief that the behavior of others has a particular and unusual significance, usually of a negative nature. The person may falsely feel that others are talking about them (e.g. the people on television are talking to or about the person).  

Delusion of self-accusation

False feeling of remorse and guilt. Seen in depression with psychotic features.

Related Pearl: Psychotic disorders

questions.text: Identify the correct statement regarding the given procedure:

questions.solution:
The above image shows laparoscopic gastric banding (LAGB). Post-operative nutritional deficiency is the least common complication occurring in this procedure compared to others.

Bariatric surgery involves making anatomical changes to aid weight loss. In addition to anatomical changes, it also alters the physiological responses of hormones and metabolism.

Laparoscopic gastric banding and intra-gastric balloon placement surgeries are considered to be reversible bariatric surgeries. The gastric band or the intragastric balloon can be removed once the desired weight loss or metabolic benefit is achieved.

questions.text: Q. A child is brought with the complaints of a neck swelling as shown. On examination, the swelling moves with deglutition and protrusion of the tongue. Which of the following is not a likely complication of this condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of a thyroglossal cyst. Malignant transformation is rare but when present, the most common type of cancer is papillary (85%). Medullary thyroid carcinomas are not found in thyroglossal duct cysts.

A thyroglossal duct cyst is a congenital midline neck swelling that typically presents during childhood often noticed after an upper respiratory infection.

Thyroglossal cyst represents the persistence of the track of the thyroid gland and can be found adjacent to the midline. The thyroid gland descends early in fetal life from the base of the tongue towards its position in the lower neck. At the time of descent, the hyoid bone has not been formed and the track of the thyroid gland is variable, passing in front, through, or behind the eventual position of the hyoid body. 

It can occur anywhere along the migratory course of the duct:

    • Infrahyoid (most common site)
    • Region of thyroid cartilage
    • Suprahyoid
    • Floor of mouth
    • Beneath foramen caecum

Clinical features of thyroglossal cyst:

  • Classically the cyst moves upwards on swallowing and on tongue protrusion. This indicates attachment to the hyoid bone. 
  • Swelling is smooth, soft, fluctuant (cystic), nontender, mobile, often transilluminant.
  • Thyroid fossa is empty, if there is no thyroid in normal location.

Complications of thyroglossal cyst:

  • The most common complication is infection.
  • Thyroglossal fistula is an acquired condition that either follows infection of the cyst which bursts open or due to inadequate removal of the cyst.
  • 1% of thyroglossal duct cysts are found to be malignant of which the most common type of cancer is papillary (85%).

Neck swellings that move with deglutition are:

  • Thyroid swellings
  • Subhyoid bursitis 
  • Dermoid cysts attached to the hyoid bone

However, only the thyroglossal cyst moves with tongue protrusion. This is because the duct extends from the foramen caecum of the tongue to the isthmus of the gland. 

Sistrunk’s operation is performed to excise the cyst and prevent a recurrence. It involves excision of the whole thyroglossal tract, involving removal of the body of the hyoid bone, and suprahyoid tract through the tongue base to the vallecula at the site of the primitive foramen caecum along with the core of tissue on either side.

questions.text: A 38-year-old woman comes to the clinic for evaluation of abnormal menstrual bleeding and crampy abdominal pain. Bimanual examination reveals an irregularly enlarged uterus.  All of the following are the risk factors for her condition, except _______.
questions.solution:
The clinical features of abnormal menstrual bleeding, abdominal pain, and irregularly enlarged uterus are suggestive of a fibroid uterus. Smoking reduces the risk of fibroid uterus.

Fibroids, also known as leiomyomas, are benign smooth muscle tumors mainly arising from the myometrium. Grossly, they are round rubbery masses with a whorled pattern.

  • Increased risk is seen in nulliparous women, early menarche, obesity, hyper-estrogenic state (endometriosis, endometrial hyperplasia, endometrial carcinoma), and African-American women.
  • Decreased risk in multiparous women and smoking.

Most women with leiomyomas are asymptomatic. When symptomatic, patients complain of abnormal menstrual bleeding, abdominal pain, urinary frequency, and incontinence.

Small and asymptomatic uterine fibroids do not require removal or medical treatment. They can be observed every 6 months. Large or symptomatic fibroids need treatment. Treatment may be medical, minimal invasive surgery, and surgery.

Medical treatment includes mifepristone, GnRH analogs, and Mirena IUCD. They cause shrinkage of tumor size. Minimal invasive procedures are uterine artery embolization, MRI-guided laser ablation, and laparoscopic myolysis. Surgical management includes myomectomy and hysterectomy.

Related Pearl: Risk factors and protective factors for fibroid

Risk factors:

  • Nulliparity
  • Obesity
  • Hyper estrogenic state
  • Black race

Protective factors:

  • Multiparity
  • Smoking

questions.text: A term baby is noted to have a diffuse edematous swelling on the scalp immediately after birth. He was delivered by normal vaginal delivery with vertex presentation. The most likely site of the swelling noted in this baby would be:
questions.solution:
In the given scenario, the baby has developed a diffuse edematous swelling on the scalp immediately after birth suggestive of caput succedaneum. The most likely site of this swelling is represented by the structure marked as 1 in the image.

1- Caput succedaneum is a diffuse edematous collection in the soft tissues of the scalp with vertex presentation. It can extend across skull sutures and disappears within the first week of life.

2- Cephalohematoma is a subperiosteal hemorrhage. It occurs following instrumental delivery which results in rupture of emissary veins of the skull. It does not cross suture lines. The swelling appears only several hours after birth. They are resorbed within two weeks to 3 months, depending on their size.

3- Subgaleal hemorrhage is a collection of blood under the aponeurosis of the scalp. It occurs as a result of ventouse deliveries due to tears of the emissary veins which connect to the dural venous sinuses. It can occur in hereditary coagulopathies and is associated with skull fractures.

4- Epidural hemorrhage is usually traumatic in origin. These are associated with cephalo-pelvic disproportion, prolonged labor, breech, precipitous labors, or as a result of mechanical assistance in labor. Majority resolve with no intervention.

The image given below shows various birth injuries to the head.

questions.text: A patient who underwent parotidectomy developed sweating that occurs when he smells or tastes food. It was suspected to be due to aberrant regeneration of parasympathetic fibres to the parotid gland. Which of the following foramina do these fibres pass through?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of sweating occurring while smelling or tasting food, secondary to aberrant regeneration of parasympathetic fibres, suggests Frey's syndrome. These fibres to the parotid gland pass through the foramen ovale and jugular foramen, marked as 2 and 4 in the image, respectively.

Parasympathetic nerves are secretomotor to the parotid gland. The preganglionic parasympathetic fibres begin in the inferior salivatory nucleus. These fibres travel via the glossopharyngeal nerve and reach the tympanic plexus via the tympanic branch of the glossopharyngeal nerve through the jugular foramen. Then, these fibres travel via the lesser petrosal nerve and come out of the foramen ovale to relay in the otic ganglion. The postganglionic parasympathetic fibres emerging from the otic ganglion pass via the auriculotemporal nerve to reach the parotid gland.

The image given below shows the parasympathetic pathway of the parotid gland.

Frey's syndrome occurs due to aberrant regeneration of the parasympathetic nerve fibres of the auriculotemporal nerve. This results in abnormal innervation of sweat glands on the face. Patients usually present with sweating, warmth, and redness of the face when they smell or taste food. 

The sympathetic supply to the parotid gland is derived from the plexus around the middle meningeal artery.

Sensory supply to the parotid gland is from the auriculotemporal nerve, and the parotid capsule is from the sensory fibres of the greater auricular nerve.

Foraminas marked in the image are:

  2. Foramen ovale
  3. Foramen spinosum

questions.text: A patient presents with cough, hemoptysis, evening rise of temperature, and, weight loss. After relevant lab investigations, he was diagnosed to be the case of pulmonary tuberculosis and was started on antitubercular therapy. Which of the following first-line antitubercular drugs acts by inhibiting RNA synthesis?
questions.solution:
Rifampin is the first-line antitubercular drug that acts by inhibiting RNA synthesis.

Rifampin binds to DNA-dependent RNA polymerase to form a stable drug-enzyme complex. This complex suppresses RNA synthesis.

Rifampicin is used for the treatment of latent and active M. tuberculosis and nontuberculous mycobacteria like Mycobacterium kansasii. Intracellular penetration of rifampicin is high, and it demonstrates bactericidal activity against most strains. 

The usual adult dose of rifampicin for the treatment of tuberculosis is 10 mg/kg (maximum 600 mg daily) given daily or three times weekly by directly observed therapy.

Side effects of rifampin are hepatitis, flu-like illness, and urine and secretions may become orange-red but this is harmless. 

Rifampicin is a potent inducer of cytochrome enzymes CYP3A4, CYP1A2, CYP2C9, CYP2C19. As a result, it induces the metabolism of OCPs, steroids, HIV protease inhibitors, and phenytoin which are metabolized by this microsomal enzyme.

Other options:

Option A: Isoniazid is a first-line bactericidal drug that is used for the treatment of tuberculosis. This drug enters bacilli by passive diffusion. It then gets activated to its toxic form by the enzyme catalase-peroxidase(the enzyme encoded by the Kat gene).

Normally, InhA and KasA are involved in the synthesis of mycolic acid. Upon activation, the reactive metabolite of isoniazid forms complexes with NAD that inhibit InhA and KasA. Hence, isoniazid inhibits the production of mycolic acid.

The reactive isoniazid metabolite also forms complexes with NADP. This complex inhibits mycobacterial dihydrofolate reductase which results in the interruption of DNA synthesis.

Option C: Pyrazinamide is a prodrug that is activated by the enzyme pyrazinamidase(encoded by the pncA gene). It is converted into an active metabolite pyrazinoic acid. This metabolite makes the intracellular environment acidic which collapses the transmembrane proton motive force, thereby killing the bacteria. Hepatotoxicity and hyperuricemia are the common side effects.

Option D: Ethambutol inhibits arabinose transferase III, thereby decreasing arabinogalactan biosynthesis. This results in, disruption in mycobacterial cell wall synthesis. The important side effect of ethambutol is optic neuritis, resulting in decreased visual acuity and loss of red-green discrimination.

questions.text: A 4-year-old fully immunized boy was brought to the emergency department with complaints of dysphagia, fever, and drooling. On a lateral x-ray of the neck, a characteristic thumb sign was seen. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical features of a toxic-looking child with an x-ray of the neck showing thumb sign are suggestive of acute epiglottitis. 

Acute epiglottitis is an acute rapidly progressive inflammation of the epiglottis causing obstructive laryngitis. It is caused chiefly by Haemophilus influenzae type b.

Patients present with high fever, sore throat, dysphagia, tachycardia, systemic toxicity, and drooling as patients are unable to swallow. The patient characteristically assumes a tripod position, sitting upright and leaning forward with the chin up and mouth open.

The diagnosis often is made on clinical grounds. On direct fiberoptic laryngoscopy, the typical edematous cherry-red epiglottis is visualized. Neck radiographs reveal an enlarged edematous epiglottis (thumb sign).

The image given below shows the thumb sign seen in epiglottitis.

Acute epiglottitis is a medical emergency due to sudden and unpredictable airway obstruction. The treatment includes the following:

  • Admission to the intensive care unit
  • Airway management - endotracheal or nasotracheal intubation or, less often, by tracheostomy, regardless of the degree of apparent respiratory distress
  • Antibiotics - Parenteral ampicillin or third-generation cephalosporins
  • Dexamethasone may be given to reduce pharyngeal edema
  • Adequate hydration and humidified oxygen

Other options:

Option A: Croup or acute laryngotracheobronchitis is gradual in onset and is usually preceded by prodromal symptoms. Also, fever is usually absent in such patients. X-ray of the chest shows typically a steeple sign due to narrowing of subglottic space.

The image given below shows the steeple sign seen in croup.

Option C: It is unlikely to be laryngeal diphtheria as it is mentioned that the child is fully immunized, and diphtheria is typically associated with membrane formation. 

The image given below shows membrane formation seen in diphtheria.

Option D: Retropharyngeal abscess is seen secondary to infections and usually does not present with fever. Children usually present with a bulge in the posterior pharyngeal wall, lateral to the midline. It is confirmed by a lateral X-ray of the neck which shows a widening of the prevertebral shadow.

The image given below shows x-ray findings seen in a retropharyngeal abscess.

Related Pearl: Acute Stridor/ Noisy breathing

Stridor indicates an upper airway problem. Look for a history of foreign body aspiration and signs of toxicity.

Important differentials:

Epiglottitis

Toxic child, drooling saliva

Lateral X-ray neck shows thumb sign

questions.text: A 28-year-old pregnant woman comes for routine screening of fetal anomalies at 19 weeks of gestation. Her AFP (alpha-fetoprotein) is elevated. Which of the following is unlikely to be the underlying cause?
questions.solution:
Maternal serum alpha-fetoprotein (MSAFP) is not elevated in spina bifida occulta.

It is elevated in open neural tube defects. Spina bifida occulta is a closed neural tube defect and is not associated with elevated alpha-fetoprotein. 

Defects in the fetal integument- skin, mucous membranes such as meningocele, meningomyelocele, ventral wall defects, anencephaly, etc allow alpha-fetoprotein to leak into the amniotic fluid causing raised maternal serum levels. 

Note - MSAFP concentration is checked in the second trimester, between 15 to 20 weeks gestation.

questions.text: A 23-year-old G2P1 lady with a previous history of cesarean section was found to have placenta accreta on ultrasonography. Imperfect development of which layer leads to this condition?
questions.solution:
Imperfect development of the Nitabuch layer, which is marked as 1 in the given image, leads to placenta accreta.

The other structures marked in the image are: 2 and 4 are cytotrophoblast and 3 is inner syncytiotrophoblast. 

Placenta accreta is a condition in which the placenta is directly attached to the myometrium either partially or completely without any intervening decidua. This abnormal attachment to myometrium is due to the partial or total absence of the decidua basalis and imperfect development of the Nitabuch layer.

The definitive placenta consists of the chorionic plate on the fetal aspect and a basal plate on the maternal aspect with the intervillous space between them. The structures in each of these parts are as follows: 

Morbidly adherent placenta (MAP) occurs when the placenta fails to detach from the uterine wall and these include: 

  • Placenta accreta - villi are attached to the myometrium
  • Placenta increta - villi invade the myometrium
  • Placenta percreta - villi penetrate through the myometrium and to or through the serosa

The image given below shows different types of morbidly adherent placenta.

Risk factors for MAP include prior cesarean delivery, placenta previa, prior uterine surgeries like hysterotomy, prior curettage, and endometrial ablation.

Ultrasound imaging, color doppler, and MRI have all been helpful in the diagnosis of MAP during pregnancy.

Management:

  • Partial placenta accreta - placental tissue is removed and bleeding areas are oversewed.
  • Total placenta accreta - 
    • Parous women - hysterectomy is done 
    • If the patient desires to have a child - the umbilical cord is cut close to its base so that the placenta left behind gets autolyzed
  • If MAP invades the bladder, hysterectomy and partial cystectomy are required.

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman presents with recurrent episodes of sudden-onset fever for the past 2 months. She says that the fever lasts for 3-4 days, subsides for a few days, and recurs again. Clinical examination reveals hepatosplenomegaly with mild tenderness. The image below shows the vector responsible for transmitting this infection. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario and the image showing body louse, Pediculus humanus corporis suggest epidemic relapsing fever. It is caused by the bacteria Borrelia recurrentis. 

Relapsing fever is an arthropod-borne infection due to Borrelia species. It can be of two types: 

  • Louse-borne or epidemic relapsing fever acquired from head or body louse and caused by Borrelia recurrentis
  • Tick-borne or endemic relapsing fever acquired from soft ticks. It is caused by Borrelia hermsii, Borrelia duttonii, and Borrelia parkeri (options A, C, and D)

Patients with relapsing fever present with sudden onset of fever that persists for 3–5 days and then subsides. The afebrile period lasts 4–10 days and is followed by a second attack of fever, chills, rigors, intense headache, and malaise.

During the febrile stages, organisms are present in the blood. During the afebrile periods, they are absent. It may be associated with jaundice and hemorrhages.

Treatment of relapsing fever includes tetracycline, chloramphenicol, penicillin, and erythromycin.

  Epidemic relapsing fever Endemic relapsing fever
Vector Body louse, Pediculus humanus corporis Soft tick
Transmission Crushing or rubbing the lice on an abraded skin Bite of ticks or their discharges
Causative bacteria Borrelia recurrentis Borrelia hermsii, Borrelia duttonii, and Borrelia parkeri
Location Epidemics occur in places like overcrowding, poverty,  wars, and jails Endemic areas inhabited by infected soft ticks
Clinical features A more severe form of relapsing fever A milder form of relapsing fever with high recurrence

 
The image given below shows a soft tick.

Related Pearl: Lice

  • There are 3 kinds of lice. They are:
    • Head lice (Pediculus capitis)
    • Body lice (Pediculus corporis)
    • Crab louse (pubic louse – Phthirus pubis).
  • Their morphology consists of a head with a pair of antennae, three pairs of legs attached to the thorax, and a segmented abdomen.
  • The stages in their life cycle are eggs (nits), larva (nymph), and the adult, which live for 30 to 50 days.
  • They are spread by direct or indirect contact.
  • They are vectors for epidemic typhus, relapsing fever, trench fever, and pediculosis.
  • Insecticidal control of lice is mainly by malathion in the form of lotion or powder.
  • There are reports of resistance to DDT and HCH.
  • Personal hygiene is of utmost importance to prevent infestation.

questions.text: An American woman came to the hospital for a regular physical check-up. She was classified to have class I obesity. What is her probable range of body mass index (BMI)?
questions.solution:
The range of BMI for class I obesity in the global population is 30.00-34.99.

People categorized as class I, class II, and class III obesity have moderate, severe, and very severe susceptibility to comorbidities respectively.

Body mass index (BMI) is a statistical index of weight-for-height that is commonly used to classify underweight, overweight, and obese in adults. It is defined as the weight in kilograms divided by the square of the height in meters (kg/m2).

Class I obesity is described when a person has a BMI of:

  • 30.0-34.9 in global population, or
  • 25- 29.9 in Indian population

These BMI values are age-independent and remain the same for both sexes.

The risks that are related to raising BMI are continuous and graded. They begin at a BMI above 25. BMI fails to distinguish between muscle weight and weight due to fat. The percentage of body fat mass increases in both genders till the age of 60-65 years. It is higher in women as compared to men with equivalent BMI.

Related Pearl: Body mass index

questions.text: A 24-year-old pregnant woman at 20 weeks of gestation, is confirmed to be suffering from toxoplasmosis infection. USG confirms fetal hydrocephalus and intracranial calcifications. Treatment of this case is by ____.
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is a confirmed case of perinatal transmission of toxoplasmosis with an infected fetus. Hence, the drug pyrimethamine-sulfadoxine is indicated.

Toxoplasmosis:

  • Causative organism: Toxoplasma gondii
  • Definitive host: Cat
  • Perinatal problems
    • Primary infection in pregnancy causes fetal abnormalities due to transplacental transmission.
    • Earlier infection- Increased severity of infection (maximum teratogenicity in the first trimester).
    • Risk of transmission increases with the period of gestation, but the risk of teratogenicity decreases (maximum risk of transmission in the third trimester).
    • Severe disease/ congenital toxoplasmosis: Tetrad of hydrocephalus or microcephaly, convulsions, chorioretinitis, and cerebral calcification.
  • Diagnosis: IgG and IgM antitoxoplasma-antibodies.
  • Management
    • Spiramycin: Acute infection in early pregnancy, to reduce vertical transmission. It does not cross the placenta and hence cannot be used to treat fetal infection.
    • Pyrimethamine-sulfonamide (to be avoided in the first trimester) - when the fetal infection is confirmed or maternal infection after 18 weeks.
    • There is no vaccine for toxoplasmosis.

questions.text: A 22-year-old woman comes with a history of 6 weeks of amenorrhea, vomiting, and easy fatigability. The ultrasound image of the patient is given below. What is the diagnosis of this patient?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario of amenorrhea, vomiting, and easy fatigability along with ultrasound findings of double decidual sign points to the diagnosis of normal pregnancy.

This sign can be seen in first-trimester transvaginal sonograms. In the image, the empty head red arrow points to the concentric double rings that are - the outer decidua parietalis and the inner decidua capsularis. The filled head red arrow points to the yolk sac. The presence of the yolk sac confirms the intrauterine location of the pregnancy. It usually appears by the 5th week.

Another indicator of early intrauterine pregnancy is the intradecidual sign. It is seen as an anechoic center surrounded by a single echogenic rim.

Cardiac motion is usually seen after the 6th week.

Related Pearl: Radiological Signs in Obstetrics

Bagel Sign (USG)

It is seen in unruptured tubal ectopic pregnancy. It is also known as the tubal ring sign or the blob sign. It refers to the appearance of an anechoic gestational sac in the adnexa surrounded by a hyperechoic ring.

 

Twin Peak Sign/ Lambda Sign (USG)

Chorionicity of the placenta is best diagnosed by ultrasound at 10–13 weeks of gestation. In dichorionic twins, there is a thick triangular projection of placental tissue between the two gestational sacs. This is known as the lambda sign or twin peak sign.

 

T Sign (USG)

The T sign which is seen in monochorionic diamniotic gestation is thin and T-shaped because there is no extension of placental tissue or chorion in between the amniotic membranes.

 

Double Decidual Sac Sign (USG)

It is seen in early intrauterine pregnancy as two concentric echogenic rings surrounding the gestational sac.

 

Lemon Sign (USG)

At the level of the lateral ventricles, there is inward bowing or scalloping of frontal bones giving rise to the lemon sign. It is suggestive of spina bifida. It is also characteristically associated with Chiari II Malformation.

 

Banana Sign (USG)

Anterior curvature of the cerebellum with effacement of the cisterna magna in the posterior fossa is seen as banana sign. 

 

Spalding sign (USG)

It usually appears 7 days after intrauterine death and is caused by liquefaction of the brain matter and softening of the ligamentous structures supporting the vault, leading to irregular overlapping of the cranial bones on one another.

 

Frog Eye Sign (USG)

It is seen in anencephaly. Due to the absence of calvaria, the orbits appear more prominent. This is known as the "frog-eye sign". 

 

Omphalocele (USG)

It is a congenital midline abdominal wall defect at the base of the umbilical cord insertion, with herniation of the solid abdominal viscera and/or bowel out of the fetal abdomen  (indicated with an asterisk). The extruded abdominal contents are covered in a sac.

 

Double Bubble Sign (USG)

Dilatation of stomach and first part of duodenum due to duodenal atresia.

 

Bunch of grapes sign or Snowstorm appearance (USG) 

The appearance of multiple cystic spaces or lesions in a complete mole.

 

Ball sign (X-ray)

It is due to the crumpled up spine of the fetus seen in case of intrauterine death.

 

Robert’s sign (X-ray)

The presence of gas in the fetal great vessels in case of intrauterine fetal demise is known as Robert's sign.

 

Stuck twin sign (USG)

Smaller twin is held in a fixed position along the uterine wall due to the severe oligohydramnios. It is seen in twin-twin transfusion syndrome.

 

Butterfly sign (USG)

Normal appearance of the choroid plexuses on axial imaging of the fetal brain. An absence of this sign suggests holoprosencephaly.

 

Cloverleaf skull (USG)

Seen in craniosynostosis

 

Empty amnion sign (USG)

Visualization of an amniotic sac without concomitant visualization of an embryo. It is an indicator of pregnancy failure.

questions.text: A primigravida comes with complaints of absent fetal movements. On ultrasound, there is no cardiac activity in the fetus and a gas shadow is seen in the aorta of the fetus. According to the findings, a minimum of how many hours have passed after the death of the fetus.
questions.solution:
In the given clinical scenario, a primigravida with a history of absent fetal movements and USG showing absent cardiac activity and gas shadow in the aorta of the fetus indicate 12 hours have passed after intrauterine fetal death.

Robert's sign is a gas shadow in the great vessels like the aorta, seen in fetal demise in utero. The gas shadow in the chambers of the heart and great vessels may appear as early as 12 hours but it is difficult to interpret.

A process of aseptic autolysis that occurs after the intrauterine death of the fetus is known as maceration. This process occurs when the dead fetus remains in utero for 3-4 days and is surrounded by the liquor amnii. There is a risk of putrefaction occurring when air is allowed to enter the liquor amnii after the death of the fetus.

Signs of maceration - 

  • Earliest sign - reddening of the skin with peeling in 12 hours
  • Robert's sign - radiographic finding showing gas in the great vessels like the aorta in 12 hours
  • Large blebs containing a red serous or serosanguineous fluid appear at around 24 hours 
  • Serous cavities may contain a turbid reddish fluid after 48 hours
  • Spalding's sign -  due to shrinkage of the brain after death there is loss of alignment and over-riding of bones of the cranial vault. 
  • A sweetish and disagreeable odour
  • Distended abdomen and abnormally mobile or flexible joints
  • The body is soft and pliable and flattens out when placed on an even surface

Other signs of intrauterine death - 

  • Rigor mortis at delivery
  • Mummification - when intrauterine death occurs due to deficient blood supply. Scanty liquor amnii and the absence of air in the uterus favours mummification.

Related Pearl: Radiological features of Intrauterine Death

  • Robert's sign - The presence of a gas shadow within the chambers of the heart or the greater vessels like aorta, in cases of foetal death in utero
  • Spalding sign - Loss of alignment and over-riding of bones of cranial vault and overlapping of skull bones due to shrinkage of brain after death
  • Deuel’s halo sign – Increased pericranial fat
  • Hyperflexion of spine and crowding of ribs

questions.text: A female patient with persistent nausea was prescribed an intravenous antiemetic three times a day.  After two days, she presented with painful arching of the neck and uprolling of eyes. The antiemetic most likely used is?
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario depicted is suggestive of dystonia. The antiemetic most likely used is metoclopramide. 

Metoclopramide is an antiemetic and prokinetic agent which acts by D2 receptor antagonism, 5HT4 receptor agonism, and 5HT3 receptor antagonism. 

Side effects include extrapyramidal symptoms which occur more commonly in children and young adults. These include dystonia which occurs after intravenous administration and parkinsonian-like symptoms which develop weeks after therapy.

Dystonia can present as involuntary limb movements, facial grimacing, torticollis, oculogyric crisis, rhythmic protrusion of the tongue, slurring of speech, or opisthotonus. It is managed with the discontinuation of metoclopramide and with benzodiazepines or antihistaminics.

Irreversible tardive dyskinesia can occur with chronic treatment. It can also cause galactorrhea by its dopamine antagonism. Methemoglobinemia can occur if used in infants.

Other options:

Options A and C: Ondansetron and Granisetron mainly act by 5HT3 antagonism. This class of drug is most effective in treating chemotherapy-induced vomiting.

Option D: Nabilone is a synthetic cannabinoid and acts by stimulating the CB1 subtype of cannabinoid receptors. It is used for chemotherapy-induced vomiting when other antiemetics have failed.

questions.text: A young female patient presents with abdominal distension and a palpable pelvic mass. Ultrasonography indicates the mass to be ovarian. Staging laparotomy is done and the histopathological slide from this specimen is shown below. Which of the following can act as a reliable tumor marker in post-treatment surveillance?
questions.solution:
The given clinical features and the histopathological image showing Schiller Duval bodies are suggestive of a yolk sac tumor/ endodermal sinus tumor. Serum levels of alpha-fetoprotein can act as a reliable tumor marker in posttreatment surveillance. 

Yolk sac tumor originates from embryonal structures of the yolk sac by selective differentiation. Hence, they are rich in alpha-fetoprotein. Therefore, serum alpha-fetoprotein levels are a reliable tumor marker in surveillance after treatment.

A yolk sac tumor is an aggressive malignant germ cell tumor of the ovaries. It presents as abdominal distension and a palpable pelvic mass in children and young women. On appearance, these tumors are yellow, friable (hemorrhagic), and solid mass. 

Most of the yolk sac tumors have Schiller-Duval bodies and they are pathognomonic. This structure consists of a central capillary surrounded by tumor cells, present in a cystic space that is lined by flat to cuboidal tumor cells.

Other options:

Option B: Lactate dehydrogenase(LDH) is a tumor marker in dysgerminoma ovaries.

Option C: Placental alkaline phosphatase(PLAP) is a tumor marker in dysgerminoma ovaries

Option D: Human chorionic gonadotropin(hCG) is a tumor marker in embryonal carcinoma and dysgerminoma ovaries.

questions.text: Which of the following is a small vessel vasculitis?
questions.solution:
Granulomatosis with polyangiitis is a small vessel vasculitis.

Granulomatosis with polyangiitis (previously called Wegener's granulomatosis) is a granulomatous and necrotizing vasculitis of the small arteries and veins. It is characterized by a triad of

  1. Necrotizing granulomas in the upper and lower respiratory tracts
  2. Focal necrotizing vasculitis most prominent in the lungs and upper airways
  3. Focal necrotizing glomerulonephritis, which is often crescentic

The radiograph below shows cavitating nodules in a patient with granulomatosis with polyangiitis.

Other options:

Option B: Temporal or Giant cell arteritis is a large vessel vasculitis that causes chronic granulomatous inflammation of temporal, vertebral, ophthalmic arteries and aorta. The temporal artery is often biopsied to establish the diagnosis.

Option C: Kawasaki disease is an acute self-limiting illness affecting medium-sized arteries in children less than 4 years of age. Coronary arteries are affected which may cause aneurysm, thrombosis or myocardial infarction.

Option D: Takayasu arteritis is a large vessel disease primarily affecting the aortic arch and its branches. It causes ocular disturbances and weak pulse in the upper extremities, hence called pulseless disease.

 

Related Pearl: Classification of vasculitis - Modified Chapel Hill classification

Related Pearl: Granulomatosis with polyangiitis

Granulomatosis with polyangiitis (previously called Wegener’s granulomatosis) is a necrotising vasculitis of small arteries and veins along with granuloma formation.

It presents as a triad of upper and lower respiratory tract involvement with glomerulonephritis.

Important organs involved are:

  • Upper respiratory tract- Presents with paranasal sinus pain, serous otitis media, nasal septal perforation.
  • Lower respiratory tract- Presents with cough, hemoptysis, and multiple bilateral cavitary nodular infiltrates.
  • Renal- Presents with rapidly progressive renal failure, crescentic glomerulonephritis.
  • Eye- Presents with conjunctivitis, scleritis, episcleritis and dacryocystitis
  • Skin- Papules, vesicles, palpable purpura and subcutaneous nodules.

Histopathology shows necrotizing vasculitis of small arteries and vein with granuloma formation.

The important laboratory features are elevated ESR, positive cANCA  antibodies and mild elevation of rheumatoid factor.

Treatment:

  • Induction phase- Cyclophosphamide combined with steroids
  • Remission phase- Methotrexate/Azathioprine

Related Pearl: Microscopic polyangiitis v/s granulomatosis with polyangiitis

Both microscopic polyangiitis and granulomatosis with polyangiitis are small vessel vasculitides that are mainly caused due to antineutrophil cytoplasmic antibodies (ANCA). Therefore, they share common clinical features with some differences.

questions.text: A G2P1L1 woman at 33 weeks of gestation presents with complaints of excessive fatigue and palpitations. On examination, severe pallor and pedal edema are present with an oxygen saturation of 89%, and there is evidence of impending heart failure. Her hemoglobin is 5.9 g/dL. Which among the following is the best treatment option for this patient?
questions.solution:
The best treatment option for this patient is packed cell transfusion.

The treatment of choice for anemia with hemoglobin between 5-7 g/dL at <34 weeks period of gestation with hypoxia and impending signs of heart failure like pedal edema is packed cell transfusion. Only packed cell transfusions are carried out and about 80-100 mL of blood is infused at a time and repeated only after 24 hours. 

The following precautions are taken prior to blood transfusions:

  • Administration of antihistaminics intramuscularly
  • Administration of diuretics intramuscularly at least 2 hours prior to transfusion to produce negative fluid balance
  • Adjustment of the drip rate to 10 drops/minute
  • Observation of the pulse, respiration, and basal lung crepitations

The complications of blood transfusions include premature labor, increased chances of worsening cardiac failure, and transfusion reactions.

Following are the RCOG guidelines for initiating blood transfusion during pregnancy:

  • Antepartum period
    1. Pregnancy <34 weeks:
      1. Hb <5 g/dL with or without signs of cardiac failure or hypoxia
      2. Hb 5-7 g/dL – in presence of impending heart failure
    2. Pregnancy >34 weeks:
      1. Hb <7 g/dL even without signs of cardiac failure or hypoxia
      2. Severe anemia with decompensation
    3. Anemia not due to hematinic deficiency:
      1. Hemoglobinopathy or bone marrow failure syndromes
      2. Consult hematologist
    4. Acute hemorrhage:
      1. Always indicated if Hb <6 g/dL
      2. If the patient becomes hemodynamically unstable due to ongoing hemorrhage
  • Intrapartum period
    1. Hb <7 g/dL 
    2. The decision of blood transfusion depends on medical history or symptoms
  • Postpartum period
    1. Hb <7 g/dL 
    2. Anemia with signs of shock/acute hemorrhage with signs of hemodynamic instability

Other options given are parenteral formulations of iron therapy that are not indicated according to the criteria given above. Parenteral iron therapy is indicated in the following conditions:

  •  Contraindications of oral therapy such as severe gastrointestinal side effects of taking oral iron (nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, teeth staining, epigastric distress)
  •  Non-cooperative patient 
  •  Cases that are seen for the first time during the last 8–10 weeks with severe anemia.

questions.text: Identify the instrument shown below.
questions.solution:
The image is that of a Hasson trocar which is used in the open method of creating pneumoperitoneum.

There are two methods used for the creation of a pneumoperitoneum:

  1. Closed method
  2. Open method

The open method is preferred for patients who have undergone previous abdominal surgeries as the small bowel may be adherent to the undersurface of the abdominal wound. The use of the open technique for creating a pneumoperitoneum avoids the morbidity related to a blind puncture.

To achieve this, a 1 cm vertical or transverse incision is made at the level of the umbilicus, stay sutures are applied, and the fascia is dissected. Free penetration into the abdominal cavity is confirmed by the gentle introduction of a finger. A Hasson trocar (shown below) is inserted and anchored, and a pneumoperitoneum is created. This is the Hasson or modified Hasson approach. 

The closed method using the Veress needle has a small but significant potential for intestinal or vascular injury on the introduction of the needle or trocar. Proper placement of the needle can be determined by the inability to re-aspirate injected saline. The normal insufflation rate is 4-6 litres/min.

The image below shows a Veress needle.

questions.text: Pregnancy is a pro-coagulant state. Which of the following is not true about hematological changes in pregnancy?
questions.solution:
Clotting factor XIII decreases during pregnancy.

  • The most common cause of decreased platelet count in pregnancy is benign gestational thrombocytopenia (may be due to hemodilution and increased platelet consumption and women are asymptomatic).

questions.text: A 5-year-old boy is brought to the pediatrician with sudden-onset fever, decreased oral intake, abdominal pain, and one episode of vomiting. On examination, the child is tired, tachycardic, and has enlarged anterior cervical lymph nodes. Which of the following is the most common causative organism?
questions.solution:
Beta hemolytic streptococcus is the most common causative organism of acute tonsillitis, which the above clinical vignette along with the image points to. The image shows enlarged tonsils with purulent exudates.

Acute tonsillitis affects children of school-going age and is rare in infants and the elderly. It causes high-grade fever, sore throat, and dysphagia. The tonsils and tonsillar fossa are innervated by the glossopharyngeal nerve and any irritation can cause referred otalgia through its tympanic branch (Jacobson's nerve). An examination may show erythema of pillars, and enlarged tonsils with purulent exudates. The jugulodigastric lymph nodes can be enlarged and tender. 

Treatment involves bed rest, hydration, analgesics, and antibiotics (penicillin). In recurrent cases, tonsillectomy may be done.

Other options:

Option A: Corynebacterium diphtheriae causes diphtheria, a bacterial infection with much slower onset of symptoms. There is dirty gray membrane formation on the tonsils which extends into the pharynx and palate

Option B: Hemophilus influenzae B causes acute epiglottitis. It is usually seen in children of ages 2-7. There is rapid onset of symptoms such as dyspnea, stridor, fever, and sore throat. It can be fatal unless treated. 

Option D: Parainfluenza virus, type I and II, is responsible for acute laryngo-tracheo-bronchitis (Croup). Male children between 6 months and 3 years of age are commonly affected. Symptoms include hoarseness of voice, croupy cough, fever, and inspiratory stridor.

questions.text:
A young adult male presented with chronic fatigue and gallstones. His father had a similar illness for which splenectomy was done. Investigations were done and shown below. Which of the following protein defects is not seen in this condition?

Hemoglobin- decreased
Mean corpuscular hemoglobin concentration- increased
Mean corpuscular volume - decreased
Red cell distribution width - increased
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario, lab investigations and peripheral smear showing numerous spherocytes are suggestive of Hereditary spherocytosis (HS). Laminin is not involved in the pathogenesis of hereditary spherocytosis. 

Laminins form part of the basement membrane which binds to both hemidesmosomes and anchoring filaments. Mutations in laminin and laminin alpha 2 (merosin) result in the blistering phenotype of junctional epidermolysis bullosa (JEB) and congenital muscular dystrophy (CMD) respectively.  

Hereditary spherocytosis is a type of hemolytic anaemia that is most commonly inherited in an autosomal dominant pattern. Mutations in α-spectrin, β-spectrin, ankyrin, band 4.2, and band 3 weaken the association of the membrane skeleton with the overlying plasma membrane, making them spheroid and less deformable. This causes red cells to shed membrane vesicles and transform into spherocytes. The non-deformable spherocytes get trapped in the splenic cords and phagocytosed by macrophages.

The ankyrin gene mutation is the most likely genetic mutation seen in autosomal-dominant hereditary spherocytosis. Mutations in the spectrin gene result in the most severe form of HS.

 

Patients usually present with anemia, fatigue, splenomegaly, and jaundice and the age of presentation varies with the severity of the disease. The unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia predisposes the patient to develop gallstones.

An aplastic crisis might occur when red cell production is halted due to parvovirus infection. This lasts 1 to 2 weeks, usually the time required for the immune system to clear the virus. Blood transfusions may be needed during this period.

Based on family history, peripheral smear findings, and laboratory investigations an adequate diagnosis is made. Increased osmotic fragility is seen in the majority of the cases. They show normocytic normochromic anemia, an increased MCHC (mean corpuscular hemoglobin concentration) due to cellular dehydration, raised RDW(red cell distribution width) and normal or reduced MCV (mean corpuscular volume).

The most common peripheral smear finding is spherocytosis, which presents as small, dark-staining (hyperchromic) red cells without the central zone of pallor. This is, however, a non-specific finding. Other features seen are reticulocytosis, Howell-Jolly bodies (dense basophilic nuclear remnants in the RBCs), marrow erythroid hyperplasia and hemosiderosis.

Splenectomy is the current treatment of choice in HS.

questions.text: A 60-year-old chronic smoker presented with progressive dyspnea and mild cough associated with scanty sputum. His chest x-ray showed hyperinflated lung fields and pulmonary function tests showed reduced diffusion capacity of the lung. The gross specimen of a patients lung with similar findings is shown below. What could be the possible diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and the gross specimen image showing large subpleural bullae in the lung apex are suggestive of emphysema.

Emphysema is a chronic obstructive pulmonary disease commonly seen in patients who are between 50–75 years of age characterized by irreversible dilation and destruction of airspaces distal to the terminal bronchiole (alveoli).

Emphysema is particularly severe in patients with α1-antitrypsin deficiency, and in smokers. Lung tissue destruction is caused by toxic injury, protease- antiprotease imbalance, oxidative stress and infection. As a result, the diffusing capacity may be reduced.

In emphysema, the upper two-thirds of the lungs are markedly affected. Due to hyperinflation, the lungs become voluminous completely eclipsing the heart anteriorly. 

Patients present with chronic cough with expectoration, with dyspnea that progressively worsens, are the disease progresses. their breathing is characteristically through pursed lips. This style of breathing increases airway pressure and prevents bronchial collapse during expiration. They are often referred to as "pink puffers" due to their typical thin non-cyanotic (pink) appearance with severe dyspnea even at rest. 

On microscopy, a thin septum with focal centriacinar fibrosis is seen between abnormally large alveoli. Airspaces with blebs or bullae are seen in advanced disease. There is a loss of elastic tissue in the walls of alveoli in the proximity of bronchioles, due to which there is respiratory collapse during expiration. 

X-ray shows the presence of hyperinflated lung fields as shown below.

The severity of COPD is assessed by using the Global Initiative for Lung Disease (GOLD) criteria. In pulmonary function testing, a postbronchodilator FEV1/FVC ratio of <0.70 is considered diagnostic for COPD.

III

FEV1/FVC <0.7 and FEV1 ≥30% but <50% predicted

IV

FEV1/FVC <0.7 and FEV1 <30% predicted

Other options:

Option B: Chronic bronchitis is a form of COPD, characterised by hyperplasia and hypersecretion of the mucous glands, due to insult by tobacco smoke or air pollutants, mostly in the bronchus and presents with persistent cough and sputum production for 3 months, in at least 2 consecutive years, without any other identifiable cause.

Option C: Bronchiolitis is a disease of the small airways like bronchioles, characterized by scarring of the airways affected due to inflammation and obstruction. The chief symptoms include cough and dyspnea.

Option D: Bronchiectasis is a lung pathology characterized by irregular and irreversible dilatation of bronchi and bronchioles due to the permanent destruction of smooth muscle and elastic components in their walls. Patients present with fever, in addition to symptoms like cough and purulent sputum production.

questions.text: A 12-year-old child is brought to the pediatrician with complaints of recurrent nasal obstruction, mouth breathing, and declining scholastic performance. An X-ray is done which is shown below. Which of the following would not be seen in this condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and the x-ray showing enlarged adenoids are suggestive of adenoid hypertrophy. Rhinolalia aperta(Hypernasality) would not be seen in this condition, but rhinolalia clausa(Hyponasality) would be seen instead.

Adenoids also known as nasopharyngeal tonsils are prone to physiological enlargement during childhood. Affected children typically present with symptoms of nasal obstruction, nasal discharge, sinusitis, and rhinolalia clausa (loss of nasal tone of voice). They may also experience aprosexia (inability to concentrate) leading to declining scholastic performance. These children have characteristic adenoid facies marked by a dull expression, open mouth, pinched in nose, high arched palate, and crowded upper teeth. 

When symptoms are bothersome, it is removed by adenoidectomy. Otherwise, decongestant nasal drops and antihistamines can be used.

Indications for adenoidectomy:

  • Symptoms like snoring, mouth breathing, and rhinolalia clausa due to adenoid hypertrophy
  • Recurrent ear discharge
  • Dental malocclusion
  • Recurrent rhinosinusitis
  • Chronic otitis media with effusion secondary to adenoid hyperplasia

Contraindications for adenoidectomy:

  • Cleft/ submucous palate: Adenoidectomy leads to velopharyngeal insufficiency in these cases and may cause rhinolalia aperta.
  • Bleeding disorders
  • Active local infection
