questions.text: A 2-year-old boy presented with low-grade fever, biphasic stridor, and a barking cough. The following was noted on X-ray. Which of the following is the most likely causative organism?
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario is suggestive of laryngotracheobronchitis which is caused by Parainfluenza.

Laryngotracheobronchitis, also known as croup, is usually seen in children aged 6 months to 3 years. Children with croup present with a barking cough, biphasic stridor, and low-grade fever.  Chest x-ray shows a steeple sign due to subglottic narrowing.

Management:

  • Racemic epinephrine nebulization leads to the improvement of upper airway obstruction. 
  • Dexamethasone, by the least invasive route (Oral>IV>IM ), is indicated in all the grades of croup.
  • Oxygen should be administered to children who are hypoxemic (SpO2 <92 %)

Antibiotics are usually not indicated in laryngotracheobronchitis.

Other options:

Option A: Moraxella causes acute otitis media. Children present with otalgia, fever, crying, and irritability.

Option B: Haemophilus influenza causes acute epiglottitis. Children present with an acute sore throat, high fever, muffled voice, inspiratory stridor, marked dysphagia, and drooling.

Option D: Staphylococcus aureus causes tracheitis. Children present with a history of croup, brassy cough, and expiratory or biphasic stridor. X-ray neck shows an irregular tracheal wall.

Related Pearl: Acute Stridor/ Noisy breathing

Stridor indicates an upper airway problem. Look for a history of foreign body aspiration and signs of toxicity.

questions.text: A young man was brought dead following deliberate consumption of the given plant. All of the aspects of this plant are true, except ______.

choices.text: Smoke from burning plant carries the toxic material
Can be detected even from the burnt dead body

questions.solution:
The given plant is Nerium odorum, all parts of the plant are poisonous, except the roots.

Oleanders: They are of two varieties - 

  • Nerium odorum or white oleander -
    • Bears with white or pink flowers
    • All parts of the plant are poisonous except the roots
    • They contain cardiac glycosides - primarily oleandroside (oleandrin) and nerioside (nerin)
    • The nectar of the flower yields poisonous honey
  • Cerbera thevetia or yellow oleander -
    • All parts of the plant are poisonous
    • All active principles are glycosides

The manifestations of Nerium odorum poisoning includes contact dermatitis, headache, dizziness, respiratory difficulty and nausea. Ingestion may lead to vomiting, abdominal pain, frothy salivation and diarrhea. Initially, there is bradycardia followed by tachycardia and again weak pulses. Other changes include hypotension, fibrillation, AV block, mydriasis, tetanic spasms, lock-jaw, drowsiness, and coma. Death is usually from cardiac failure. 

The manifestation of Cerbera thevetia poisoning include burning sensation in the mouth, tingling of the tongue, dryness of the throat, vomiting, diarrhea, headache, dilated pupils, irregular action of the heart followed by drowsiness, coma, collapse, and death.

Postmortem appearances: Organs appear congested. The Nerium resists heat, therefore can be detected even from the burnt dead body.

Medicolegal aspects: Suicide with this is common among villagers, accidental poisoning can also be seen, but homicide is rare. It is also used as cattle poison. Smoke from burning plants carries toxic material.

questions.text: A young woman with a previous history of dilatation and curettage for elective abortion presents with hypomenorrhea. Hysterosalpingography shows irregular, angulated filling defects. Which of the following investigations is used for the definitive diagnosis of this condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of Asherman syndrome. Hysteroscopy is used for the definitive diagnosis of Asherman syndrome.

Asherman syndrome refers to the presence of uterine synechiae, due to the destruction of the endometrium. It can occur as a result of trauma to the endometrium following vigorous curettages for elective abortion, tuberculous endometritis, and uterine surgeries.

Depending on the degree of scarring, patients may have amenorrhea, hypomenorrhea, or recurrent pregnancy loss because of inadequate placentation.

Hysterosalpingography is performed to assess the uterine cavity and tubal patency. Intrauterine adhesions are characteristically seen as irregular angulated filling defects in the uterine cavity with a classic 'moth-eaten' appearance. 

Definitive diagnosis (gold standard) and management are done by hysteroscopy. Hysteroscopic adhesiolysis is the surgical treatment of choice.

Hormonal assays also aid in the diagnosis of anatomical causes of amenorrhea such as Asherman syndrome. All women with amenorrhea in the reproductive age group are considered pregnant unless proven otherwise by negative urinary or serum β-HCG levels. Once negative for pregnancy, further testing is done by a progesterone challenge test.

This test is done by administering medroxyprogesterone acetate as a 10-mg daily oral dose for 10 days. If the woman bleeds, then she is assumed to produce estrogen and to have a developed endometrium, and the presence of a patent outflow tract is confirmed. If she does not bleed, then she is given estrogen followed by progesterone treatment in the form of combined OCPs. If she fails to bleed after completing the 21 hormone-containing pills, then an anatomic abnormality is diagnosed such as Asherman syndrome.

Given below is an algorithm for the evaluation of amenorrhea.

Option A: Transvaginal ultrasonography is a noninvasive imaging technique using the transvaginal approach. It provides a more detailed evaluation of the pelvic organs as compared to the transabdominal approach.

questions.text: A 1-year-old baby was brought by his mother with growth failure and developmental delay. Laboratory investigations revealed a hemoglobin of  8 g/dL and normal levels of vitamin B12 and B9. His peripheral smear is given below. What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario with a peripheral smear showing hypersegmented neutrophils with normal vitamin B12 and B9 levels is suggestive of orotic aciduria.

Orotic aciduria is a rare autosomal recessive condition. It occurs due to an error in the de novo synthesis of pyrimidine resulting in the failure of conversion of orotic acid to uridine. As a result, there is increased excretion of orotic acid in urine. It is of two types:

  • Type I - deficiency of both orotate phosphoribosyl transferase and OMP decarboxylase (together called UMPsynthase)
  • Type II - deficiency of only orotidylate decarboxylase.

Children clinically present with megaloblastic anemia that is unresponsive to vitamin B12 and folic acid, failure to thrive, developmental delay, and intellectual disability.

Confirmation of the diagnosis requires an assay of the transferase and decarboxylase enzymes in the patient's red blood cells. Anemia responds well to the administration of uridine.

Other options:

Option A: Gout is a metabolic disease associated with hyperuricemia. It is characterized by the deposition of monosodium urate crystals in joints and connective tissue. It usually presents as painful monoarthritis that mainly involves the metatarsophalangeal joints of the first toe.

Option B: Severe combined immune deficiency (SCID) occurs due to a deficiency in adenosine deaminase, an enzyme of purine metabolism. This results in the accumulation of adenosine metabolites. This causes premature cell death of B, T and NK cells. Children with SCID present with recurrent oral candidiasis, failure to thrive, diarrhea and interstitial pneumonitis.

Option D: Copper deficiency is usually seen in a condition called Menkes kinky hair syndrome. Children usually present with intellectual disability, hypocupremia, and decreased circulating ceruloplasmin.

questions.text: An anesthetist used the airway device shown in the image given below on a patient. Which among the following statements is true regarding the adjunct?

choices.text: It can cause damage to the teeth
It can be used in conscious patients
It can be safely used in facial trauma cases

questions.solution:
The image shows a nasopharyngeal airway and its insertion. The true statement is that it can be used in conscious patients. 

A nasopharyngeal airway is used to provide artificial airway passage to the hypopharynx. To place a nasopharyngeal airway, the device should be lubricated and inserted into the nose with the bevel facing the nasal septum, at a 90-degree angle to the longitudinal axis of the body. It bypasses the gag reflex as they do not go through the mouth. Thus, it can be used in conscious patients or those who have been lightly anesthetized.

Care should be taken to avoid excessive force as damage to the nasal mucosa can result in epistaxis. The nasal approach should be avoided in conditions that put patients at higher risk for epistaxis. These conditions include but are not limited to coagulopathy, pregnancy, hereditary hemorrhagic telangiectasia, and uncontrolled hypertension. Absolute contraindications include basilar skull fractures, facial trauma, midface disruption, and injury to the roof of the mouth.

An oropharyngeal airway is used to maintain the airway in anaesthetized patients. This adjunct prevents the tongue and epiglottis from falling back against the posterior pharynx and blocking the airway. They can cause coughing, retching, or laryngospasm in conscious patients.

To place an oropharyngeal airway, the device is inserted with the curved portion (concave) facing upwards. It is then rotated 180 degrees to be put in place. The below image shows the oropharyngeal airway:

Other options: 

Option A: Nasopharyngeal airways bypass the mouth so they do not cause damage to the teeth. Oropharyngeal airways can cause damage to the teeth. 

Option C: Nasopharyngeal airways can cause laryngospasm. Any foreign body that enters the nasal or oral cavities can cause local stimulation leading to reflex closure of the vocal cords. 

Option D: Its usage is contraindicated in facial trauma.

questions.text: A middle-aged man complains of the frequent dropping of handheld things and tripping while walking. On examination, the patient appeared as shown in the image below. Strength is 4/5 in the intrinsic muscles of the hand. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario and the image showing the patient with frontal balding, and a typical hatchet-faced appearance are suggestive of type 1 myotonic dystrophy.

Myotonic dystrophy is an autosomal dominant disorder. It is caused due to CTG trinucleotide repeat in DMPK gene on chromosome 19. It is mainly of two types: myotonic dystrophy type 1 (DM1), and myotonic dystrophy type 2 (DM2).

Clinically, patients will have a typical hatchet-faced appearance due to wasting of the temporal and masseter muscles. Frontal baldness and a high-arched palate are also seen. 

It is associated with weakness in the distal muscles of the wrist, fingers, and foot. Involvement of the palatal, pharyngeal, and tongue muscles causes dysarthria and dysphagia. Involvement of the diaphragm and intercostal muscles leads to respiratory insufficiency. Proximal muscles remain unaffected.

Diagnosis is mainly clinical. ECG shows conduction abnormalities in the form of first-degree heart block. Electromyography may show myotonia in DM1, however, it is patchy in DM2. Creatine kinase levels in the serum may be normal or mildly elevated.

The histopathological finding of muscle biopsy in both DM1, and DM2, shows internalized nuclei seen in individual muscle fibers, and the presence of several atrophic fibers with pyknotic nuclear clumps.

Treatment is mainly symptomatic. However, mexiletine is indicated for both DM1 and DM2 help in reducing myotonia.

Other options:

Options A and B: Duchenne and Becker muscular dystrophies present with proximal muscle weakness. These are x-linked recessive dystrophies. Therefore, family history would reveal that mainly men in the family are affected.

Option D: In Pompe's disease or acid maltase deficiency is a glycogen storage disease. Affected children present with hypotonia, myocardiopathy, and hepatosplenomegaly. Respiratory muscle weakness leading to ventilatory insufficiency may be a prominent feature.
